The UK's National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has rejected two new Alzheimer's drugs for NHS provision, deeming them poor value for taxpayers. The treatments, donanemab and lecanemab, represent the first medications proven to slow Alzheimer's progression.

These drugs work by clearing amyloid protein buildup in patients' brains. However, trials showed they only delay cognitive decline by four to six months. On an 18-point dementia scale, patients improved by just 0.45 points on average. They do not stop or reverse the disease.

The decision considered the drugs' enormous cost burden. Priced at £20,000-£25,000 yearly per patient in the US, providing them to 70,000 eligible NHS patients in England could cost approaching £1.5 billion annually. Additional expenses for IV infusions and frequent brain scans would further strain resources.

NICE director Helen Knight stated: "Funding them could displace other essential treatments, as the benefits were modest at best." The agency noted that even including potential care savings, the drugs remained unaffordable.

Industry and Patient Reactions

Pharmaceutical companies Eisai (lecanemab) and Eli Lilly (donanemab) plan appeals. Eli Lilly's UK head Chris Stokes criticized: "If the system can't deliver scientific firsts to NHS patients, it is broken." Eisai's Nick Burgin claimed the NHS was unprepared for Alzheimer's treatments.

Alzheimer's charities expressed disappointment. Alzheimer's Society's Fiona Carragher lamented: "The science is flying but the system is failing." Alzheimer's Research UK's Hilary Evans-Newton called the decision "painful," warning patients could miss future innovations.

Expert Support for Decision

Some dementia experts defended NICE's stance. University of Nottingham's Tom Dening called the benefits "minimal" and a "distraction" from providing better dementia care services. St George's University professor Atticus Hainsworth stated: "NICE is simply doing its job."

The ruling, applicable to England, Wales and Northern Ireland, becomes final on July 23 unless appeals succeed. With 138 other dementia drugs in development globally, Edinburgh University's Tara Spires-Jones noted hope remains for more effective future treatments.

fields.title: Heatwave Guidance for UK Schools and Workplaces
fields.summary: Amid UK heatwave conditions with temperatures exceeding 30°C, schools remain open with adapted safety measures while workplaces follow reasonable temperature guidelines, as forecasters predict continued heat before weekend cooling.
fields.content:
Much of the UK faces heatwave conditions, with the UK Health Security Agency issuing an amber heat alert across England through Monday. Despite extreme temperatures, schools are expected to remain operational, as attendance is considered essential for children's well-being according to government policy.

Schools must implement safety adjustments during hot weather since children are particularly vulnerable to heat-related illnesses. Measures include relaxing uniform requirements, permitting lightweight clothes or PE kits instead of blazers and ties, modifying strenuous physical activities, and ensuring access to shade, sun protection, and drinking water.

Staff should monitor pupils for symptoms of heat stress such as irritability, nausea, headaches, or fainting. Classroom management tips involve opening windows overnight to release heat, closing them during peak temperatures, keeping blinds drawn, minimizing artificial lighting, and using fans below 35°C.

What temperature is too hot to go to work?

UK workplace regulations require reasonable indoor temperatures without specifying legal limits. Employers must provide clean air and comfortable conditions despite the heat, though no defined maximum temperature exists.

When will the heatwave come to an end?

Temperatures will peak in the mid-to-high twenties nationally until Saturday, potentially reaching low thirties in southern and eastern England. Nights will remain exceptionally warm, holding at 20°C or above in southern regions. By Sunday, cooler conditions will arrive in Scotland, Northern Ireland, and Wales (16-20°C), while eastern areas stay warm before possible southern temperature rebounds next week.

fields.title: Plastic Bag Regulations Reduce US Shoreline Litter by 25%, Study Finds
fields.summary: US bans or fees on plastic bags have reduced their presence on shorelines by at least 25% according to shoreline cleanup data analysis, though researchers warn overall plastic pollution continues to rise despite policy successes.
fields.content:
Policies restricting plastic bags in the US have significantly reduced their presence on shorelines, a comprehensive study of nationwide litter reveals. Cleanup data shows plastic bags decreased by 25% to 47% as a proportion of total litter in areas that implemented bans or fees compared to those without regulations.

The effectiveness varied by implementation level, with statewide policies outperforming local ordinances. Reductions were also more substantial in regions that had higher baseline levels of plastic bag pollution before regulations took effect.

Despite these encouraging results, researchers cautioned that the overall percentage of plastic bags found during cleanups continues to increase nationwide. Policies merely slowed rather than reversed the trend of growing plastic pollution, making plastic bags the fifth most common shoreline litter item after cigarette butts, food wrappers, bottle caps, and drink bottles.

The US served as an ideal research environment due to its patchwork of regulations across states, counties, and municipalities. Policies studied included full bans, partial bans (targeting thinner bags), mandatory charges per bag, and pre-emption laws that prevent local governments from enacting their own restrictions.

Researchers analyzed 45,067 shoreline cleanups conducted between 2016 and 2023 that tracked plastic bags as a proportion of collected litter. They employed statistical models to compare 182 regulatory approaches, revealing the relative decrease in bag waste.

On average, plastic bags constituted 4.5% of all shoreline litter collected during cleanups. Models demonstrated that areas with plastic bag regulations consistently showed fewer bags relative to other trash items.

Plastic bags 'only part of the problem'

Lead author Anna Papp emphasized the study demonstrates policy effectiveness in combating plastic pollution. She highlighted the upcoming global plastics treaty negotiations in August, involving 175 nations, as a critical opportunity for broader solutions.

"Stronger results in areas with a higher baseline of plastic bag litter means these policies may be especially effective in these areas," Papp stated. "But plastic bag policy addresses just one part of the problem. More comprehensive solutions are needed across production, consumption, and waste management to make meaningful progress."

The research notes that despite the relative declines, plastic bag percentages increased in absolute terms across all areas - both with and without regulations - due to the overwhelming growth in overall plastic pollution. This indicates current efforts only partially counteract the expanding waste stream.

Similar effects occurred in other regions, with UK beach surveys showing an 80% drop in plastic bags found after introducing charges starting in 2011.

fields.title: Texas Instruments Unveils Record $60 Billion US Semiconductor Expansion
fields.summary: Texas Instruments is committing over $60 billion to expand semiconductor manufacturing across seven facilities in Texas and Utah, creating 60,000 jobs in what it calls the largest foundational chip investment in US history amid political pressure to boost domestic production.
fields.content:
Computer chip manufacturer Texas Instruments (TI) announced a massive $60 billion investment plan for expanding US semiconductor production facilities. The project will fund seven new or upgraded chip-making plants across sites in Texas and Utah, generating approximately 60,000 jobs, though the company has not provided a detailed implementation timeline.

The Dallas-based firm described this investment as the 'largest investment in foundational semiconductor manufacturing in US history.' It follows similar pledges from other chipmakers like Micron, which recently increased its planned US spending to $200 billion.

US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick linked the announcement to President Donald Trump's manufacturing priorities, stating, 'President Trump has made it a priority to increase semiconductor manufacturing in America. Our partnership with TI will support US chip manufacturing for decades to come.' Industry analysts suggest such massive spending announcements may partially aim to appease Trump, who has threatened to cancel the $52.7 billion CHIPS and Science Act established under Joe Biden's administration.

TI's commitment includes previously allocated funds, building on a December agreement where the Biden administration granted the company a $1.6 billion subsidy for its $18 billion facility expansion plan. This investment occurs amid Trump's warnings about imposing new tariffs on semiconductor imports.

Unlike AI-focused companies like Nvidia, TI specializes in foundational chips used in everyday devices including smartphones and automobiles. With Apple, SpaceX, and Ford as key clients, the company faces growing competition from Chinese manufacturers in producing these essential components. TI currently operates 15 global manufacturing sites.

fields.title: Chinese PhD student jailed for life over serial rapes in UK and China
fields.summary: A Chinese PhD student identified as one of Britain's most dangerous sexual predators has received a life sentence with a minimum 24-year term for drugging and raping 10 women in London and China between 2019 and 2023, with police suspecting dozens more potential victims.
fields.content:
Warning: This article contains distressing details.

Zhenhao Zou, a Chinese national studying in the UK, has been sentenced to life imprisonment with no chance of parole for at least 24 years for multiple sexual assaults. Metropolitan Police investigators described the 29-year-old as "one of the most prolific predators" they had encountered.

Court proceedings revealed Zou raped three women in London and seven in China between September 2019 and May 2023. While only three victims have been formally identified, police confirmed 24 additional women have come forward with allegations since the trial began.

Court proceedings

At Inner London Crown Court, Judge Rosina Cottage KC characterized Zou as a manipulative "sexual predator" who used a "charming mask" to gain victims' trust before assaulting them. Surveillance footage showing some assaults caused courtroom observers to weep, according to the judge.

Zou was convicted of 11 rape charges (including two against one victim), three counts of voyeurism, ten charges of possessing extreme pornography, one count of false imprisonment, and three counts of drug possession with intent to commit sexual assault.

The assaults often involved Zou drugging his victims before raping them while they were unconscious. He filmed nine attacks and maintained a "trophy box" containing personal items stolen from women he assaulted.

Judge Cottage stated Zou treated victims as "sex toys" in an elaborate campaign demonstrating "no understanding of consent." She emphasized his "distorted thinking" poses an indefinite danger requiring prolonged confinement.

Victim impact statements

One victim recalled being pressured to drink excessively before being raped when trapped in Zou's apartment. "I have lost faith in human beings," she wrote, describing recurring flashbacks when encountering strangers.

A second victim, assaulted in Zou's London flat near Russell Square in October 2021, stated the experience would remain "etched into my soul forever." Directly addressing Zou, she declared: "I will never forgive him."

Metropolitan Police Commander Kevin Southworth urged additional potential victims to come forward, promising they would be treated "with empathy, kindness and respect." Crown Prosecution Service representative Saira Pike praised victims' courage in securing the conviction, calling Zou a "serial rapist and a danger to women."

fields.title: Israeli jets strike Iran's Arak nuclear reactor amid escalating conflict
fields.summary: Israeli warplanes bombed Iran's unfinished Arak heavy water nuclear reactor during escalating hostilities between the two nations. The strike, confirmed by global nuclear inspectors, specifically targeted components that could enable plutonium production for weapons, despite Iran's denial of nuclear weapons ambitions.
fields.content:
Israeli fighter jets struck the unfinished Arak heavy water nuclear facility in central Iran during the seventh day of conflict between the two countries. The military stated its objective was to destroy the reactor's core seal to prevent potential nuclear weapons development.

The International Atomic Energy Agency confirmed the reactor was hit, clarifying that no nuclear material was present at the time. Spent fuel from such reactors contains weapons-grade plutonium, though Iran maintains its nuclear program is exclusively peaceful.

Iran had committed to modifying Arak under a 2015 international agreement to eliminate weapons-grade plutonium production capabilities. By 2016, the IAEA reported the reactor core's removal rendered it inoperable, though recent inspections noted ongoing minor construction for projected 2025 commissioning.

Israel accused Iran of deliberately stalling the conversion process to pressure Western nations. Military-released aerial footage showed explosions at the domed reactor building in Khondab, 250 km southwest of Tehran.

Iranian state television broadcast images of smoke plumes rising from the facility, with officials claiming the site was secured in advance to prevent radioactive contamination. Satellite imagery revealed significant roof damage and apparent destruction of adjacent distillation towers.

The attack extended to Iran's uranium enrichment plant at Natanz, where a prior strike had destroyed above-ground infrastructure and potentially disabled underground centrifuges through power disruption. Four buildings were demolished at the Isfahan Nuclear Technology Centre, while the Fordo enrichment site sustained minimal damage.

US President Donald Trump reportedly considered joining strikes on Fordo, the only facility requiring specialized bunker-busting munitions. This follows his 2018 withdrawal from the nuclear accord and reimposition of sanctions, which prompted Iran to progressively violate enrichment limits.

The IAEA recently expressed alarm over Iran amassing sufficient 60%-enriched uranium - technically close to weapons-grade purity - for nine nuclear bombs. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu claimed Iran could rapidly develop nuclear weapons if unchecked.

Iran's foreign minister condemned the reactor attacks as crossing a red line, reiterating Tehran's opposition to nuclear weapons. The conflict has yielded significant casualties, with Iran reporting 224 deaths (unofficial estimates reach 639) and Israel confirming 24 killed in retaliatory missile attacks.

fields.title: UK Implements Strict Emissions Rules for Oil and Gas Projects
fields.summary: The UK government has introduced new regulations requiring oil and gas operators to account for full climate impacts, including emissions from burning fossil fuels, in environmental assessments for new projects. This move affects controversial fields like Rosebank and Jackdaw, with decisions expected by summer's end.
fields.content:
New government guidance mandates that oil and gas operators must now calculate the complete environmental impact of their projects, including greenhouse gases released when extracted fuels are eventually burned. Previously, environmental assessments only considered emissions from extraction operations.

Legal requirements and field implications

This policy shift stems from a landmark Supreme Court ruling that required assessment of "downstream" or Scope 3 emissions. In January, Edinburgh's Court of Session applied this retroactively to the Rosebank and Jackdaw developments. Shell's Jackdaw gas field was approved in 2022, while Equinor's Rosebank field gained approval in late 2023.

Lord Ericht permitted preparatory work on both fields to continue but mandated no extraction until the government re-evaluates applications with the new emissions criteria. Energy Minister Michael Shanks stated this provides clarity for the industry's future, though decisions won't come before late summer.

Industry and environmental reactions

Campaign groups Uplift and Greenpeace UK argue new developments contradict climate commitments. Tessa Khan of Uplift stated Rosebank is "incompatible" with UK climate goals, noting it would generate emissions equivalent to 56 coal plants annually. Greenpeace's Mel Evans called for focus on renewable energy instead.

Shell emphasized Jackdaw's importance for national energy needs, claiming it could heat 1.4 million homes. First Minister John Swinney acknowledged the guidance recognizes all emissions must be considered in decision-making. The government will balance environmental impacts against economic factors, though Energy Secretary Ed Miliband previously condemned Rosebank as "climate vandalism".

Approvals remain pending as regulators await revised applications. The guidance follows a £200 million investment in Aberdeenshire's carbon capture scheme and anticipated plans for Grangemouth refinery's future.

fields.title: Police Start Staff Interviews in Maternity Failings Investigation
fields.summary: Police have begun interviewing current and former staff as part of a criminal investigation into catastrophic maternity failings at Shrewsbury and Telford hospitals, where over 200 baby deaths and nine maternal deaths may have been caused by substandard care.
fields.content:
Police investigators have started questioning current and former hospital staff members regarding maternity service failings at two healthcare facilities. Called Operation Lincoln, this probe examines potential criminal culpability at Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital NHS Trust for severe care deficiencies spanning nearly two decades.

West Mercia Police launched this criminal investigation in June 2020, overlapping with an independent review led by senior midwife Donna Ockenden. That review eventually identified catastrophic failings across 1,600 examined cases of concerning maternity care between 2000 and 2019.

Ockenden's findings revealed that these institutional failures potentially contributed to more than 200 infant fatalities, nine maternal deaths, and cases where babies sustained life-altering injuries. Hundreds of these cases have been analyzed by Operation Lincoln investigators.

Detective Superintendent Carl Moore confirmed this interview phase marks a significant development, stating the police will keep affected families informed throughout the process. The investigation specifically assesses whether the trust or individuals violated criminal laws.

Hospital Trust Improvements

Jo Williams, chief executive of Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital NHS Trust, issued a formal apology: "We are truly sorry for the harm caused to those families who rightfully expected a safe experience under our care, and who were let down by us."

The trust assured the public its maternity departments remain fully operational and highlighted recent improvements. A 2023 Care Quality Commission (CQC) inspection rated maternity services as "good", citing enhanced staffing levels, better training protocols, improved risk assessments, and strengthened patient feedback systems.

While acknowledging ongoing improvements, the trust pledged continued collaboration with staff and communities to elevate care standards further.

fields.title: Climate Scientists Warn Just Three Years Left to Limit Warming to 1.5C
fields.summary: Leading climate scientists warn that humanity has roughly three years left at current emissions rates before exhausting the carbon budget for a 50% chance to limit global warming to 1.5C. The assessment highlights record-high CO2 emissions and accelerated climate impacts like extreme weather and sea-level rise.
fields.content:
Humanity may have only three years remaining before exhausting the carbon budget needed to limit global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels, according to a stark warning from over 60 leading climate scientists. This critical timeline stems from current carbon dioxide emission rates reaching approximately 40 billion tonnes annually.

Nearly 200 countries committed to the 1.5C threshold in the landmark 2015 Paris Agreement to avoid catastrophic climate impacts. However, sustained record consumption of fossil fuels and widespread deforestation have dramatically undermined this target.

Climate change effects are already evident through intensified weather extremes like the UK's 2022 40°C heatwave and rapidly rising sea levels threatening coastal communities globally. Professor Piers Forster of the University of Leeds stated, "Things are all moving in the wrong direction. We're seeing some unprecedented changes and the heating of the Earth accelerating."

Scientists calculate that the remaining "carbon budget" – the maximum CO2 that can be emitted for a 50% chance of staying below 1.5C – has shrunk from 500 billion tonnes in early 2020 to 130 billion tonnes in 2025. Maintaining current emission levels would exhaust this budget in about three years, potentially triggering a Paris Agreement breach by around 2030.

Last year marked the first 12-month period where global average temperatures exceeded 1.5C above pre-industrial levels, reaching 1.36°C primarily from human-caused warming. The warming rate has accelerated to 0.27°C per decade, approximately twice as fast as between 1970-1990. While technological solutions for CO2 removal are being explored, researchers warn against overreliance on such methods.

'Every fraction of warming' matters

The rate of heat accumulation in Earth's climate system has more than doubled since the 1970s, with recent increases about 25% higher than a decade ago. "That's a really large number, a very worrying number," emphasized Dr. Matthew Palmer from the UK Met Office. Approximately 90% of this excess heat is absorbed by oceans, disrupting marine ecosystems and accelerating sea-level rise through thermal expansion and glacier melt.

Global sea-level rise has doubled in speed since the 1990s, intensifying flood risks for millions. Despite slowing emission growth due to clean technology adoption, scientists stress that "rapid and stringent" reductions are now critical. Professor Joeri Rogelj of Imperial College London underscores that each incremental temperature increase worsens impacts: "Every fraction of warming that we can avoid will result in less harm and suffering, particularly for vulnerable populations."

fields.title: The Global Spread of Untraceable 3D-Printed Firearms
fields.summary: Untraceable 3D-printed firearms are spreading globally through social media platforms and online guides, potentially becoming weapons of choice for criminals and extremists despite platform policies against such content.
fields.content:
3D-printed firearms could become preferred weapons for violent extremists and criminals worldwide due to their untraceable nature, experts warn. These DIY guns have appeared in multiple criminal cases, including the killing of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson where a partially 3D-printed firearm was allegedly used.

A BBC investigation tracked their proliferation across Telegram, Facebook, and Instagram, with websites offering downloadable blueprints. These ghost guns evade traditional gun laws and have evolved significantly over the past decade, with current models capable of firing multiple rounds without component failure.

Social Media Vulnerabilities

Hundreds of weapon advertisements—including for 3D-printed and ghost guns—were found on Meta's platforms in October 2024, violating company policies. BBC discovered similar active ads months later within Meta's ad database. Many directed buyers to encrypted platforms like Telegram.

On Telegram, channels openly offered weapon sales with global shipping. One account operator using the name Jessy promptly offered BBC reporters a Liberator pistol or Glock switch—a device converting pistols to automatic weapons—for £160 via Bitcoin. Jessy claimed ability to bypass UK customs despite acknowledging the illegality, stating: "I run my business, sell some straps [weapons] online."

Meta stated the highlighted ads were automatically disabled per policies, while Telegram reported proactively removing Jessy's account. Telegram emphasized weapon sales violate its terms, with moderators using AI tools to remove millions of harmful content daily.

Accessible Weapons Manufacturing

Criminals can also manufacture firearms themselves using freely available online guides. Designs like the FGC-9 utilize 3D-printed plastic and repurposed metals, requiring no commercial gun parts. Dr. Rajan Basra of King's College London cautions that while accessible, these weapons demand expertise: "It's not as easy as printing off a sheet of A4 paper."

Matthew Larosiere, a gun rights attorney providing such guides, defended the practice as sharing information: "It's ones and zeros." When asked about potential misuse in attacks, he responded: "I thank God that has not happened," citing Myanmar as a positive example.

Frontline Experiences

Myanmar represents the only documented military conflict where 3D-printed guns were deployed extensively, with resistance fighters using FGC-9s costing a tenth of black-market alternatives. However, most groups have since abandoned them.

Rebel leaders cited Myanmar's junta restricting essential materials like metal and glue. Additionally, they now possess superior conventional weapons like RPGs and machine guns. This experience demonstrates the weapons' military limitations despite their global spread. Countries are considering laws criminalizing blueprints, while others propose manufacturers implement printing restrictions similar to currency protection systems.

fields.title: Judge Rules Swift-Lively Messages Must Be Disclosed in Legal Battle
fields.summary: A US federal judge has ordered Taylor Swift to surrender private communications with Blake Lively regarding workplace conditions during film production, ruling they are relevant evidence in Lively's harassment lawsuit against actor-director Justin Baldoni and his studio.
fields.content:
Communications between Taylor Swift and Blake Lively about the working environment on the film set of 'It Ends With Us' must be disclosed in Justin Baldoni's legal battle with Lively, ruled US District Judge Lewis Liman. The decision, delivered Wednesday, states these messages could prove or disprove Lively's harassment allegations against Baldoni.

Lively initially sued Baldoni and Wayfarer Studios last December, claiming she endured sexual harassment on set and that Baldoni attempted to 'destroy' her reputation. Baldoni counter-sued, though a judge dismissed his defamation lawsuit against Lively last week.

Baldoni previously attempted to subpoena Swift directly for the messages in May, but Swift's legal team objected to what they called an 'unwarranted fishing expedition,' prompting withdrawal of the subpoenas. Lively subsequently sought to block disclosure requests through normal legal channels, arguing the conversations were irrelevant to the case.

Lively's spokesperson contends Baldoni has disproportionately produced fewer documents overall while trying to involve Swift 'since last summer' for publicity. The spokesperson stated, 'We will continue to call out Baldoni's relentless efforts to exploit Ms. Swift's popularity... to distract from the serious accusations.' Judge Liman rejected the PR argument as insufficient justification for withholding evidence.

'Tabloid clickbait' claims

Swift's representatives previously characterized the legal maneuver as an effort to generate 'tabloid clickbait,' emphasizing the singer-songwriter had no film creative input: 'She was not involved in any casting or creative decision... never saw an edit or made any notes.' This followed Baldoni's claim that Swift and Reynolds served as Lively's 'dragons' during script-change discussions.

Baldoni's attorneys also alleged Lively threatened to leak Swift's past texts unless Swift publicly supported her—a claim Lively's lawyers dismissed as 'unequivocally and demonstrably false.' The trial is scheduled to commence in March 2026.

fields.title: Government Whip Quits Over Disability Benefit Cuts Plan
fields.summary: Labour MP Vicky Foxcroft has resigned as a government whip in protest against planned disability benefit reductions, stating cuts are "not part of the solution" despite acknowledging budget pressures.
fields.content:
Labour MP Vicky Foxcroft has stepped down from her role as a government whip due to objections over proposed cuts to disability benefits. Her resignation comes amid government efforts to reduce welfare spending.

In a letter to the prime minister, Foxcroft recognized the need to address "the ever-increasing welfare bill" but argued that reductions to personal independence payments and universal credit should "not be part of the solution." She emphasized that these cuts would disproportionately impact disabled individuals.

Foxcroft revealed she had extensively deliberated over the decision, torn between resigning or attempting to drive internal policy changes. Ultimately, she concluded: "Sadly it now seems that we are not going to get the changes I desperately wanted to see."

This story is developing and will be updated with further details as they emerge.

fields.title: Trump Administration Cuts Funding for LGBTQ Youth Suicide Hotline Option
fields.summary: The Trump administration has eliminated funding for the LGBTQ youth option within the national suicide prevention hotline, calling it a promoter of 'radical gender ideology.' The Trevor Project, which ran the service, will shut down the option within 30 days, warning the move endangers vulnerable young people.
fields.content:
The administration has discontinued funding for a specialized part of the national suicide prevention hotline catering to LGBTQ youth, describing the service as promoting radical views. It emphasized that the broader 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline would continue operating and assisting all callers.

The Trevor Project, which helped administer the LGBTQ youth service, condemned the decision. CEO Jaymes Black stated: "Suicide prevention is about people, not politics," revealing the service must close within 30 days. He called ending the "bipartisan, evidence-based service" incomprehensible due to its support for high-risk youth.

The announcement coincided with Pride Month and followed a US Supreme Court decision upholding Tennessee's ban on transition-related healthcare for transgender minors. Notable legislation passed in 2020 mandated specialized services for LGBTQ people within the hotline, citing research showing they face significantly higher suicide risks.

Service Details and Legislative Context

The 988 Lifeline provides free mental health support via call, text, or chat, funded through the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration. Historically, LGBTQ youth could select option 3 to connect with trained counselors.

After closing this dedicated service, all callers would be directed to general support, with SAMHSA stating the hotline would "no longer silo LGB+ youth services"—omitting "T" and "Q" from the acronym. Officials from Health and Human Services recently proposed the cut, alleging counselors encouraged minors to embrace gender ideology without parental consent.

Broader Policy Shifts

This decision aligns with wider efforts to curtail transgender support across federal agencies. President Trump has moved to end diversity, equity, and inclusion policies, remove transgender individuals from the military, and legally recognize only two sexes. The State Department also eliminated "X" gender markers on passports.

Despite support from Trump for the 2020 legislation creating specialized hotline services, his administration now argues such targeted programs normalize what it calls radical ideologies.

Mental health resources remain available worldwide through organizations like Befrienders Worldwide (www.befrienders.org) and BBC Action Line in the UK.

fields.title: Ukraine's Digital Triumph: Revolutionizing Governance During War
fields.summary: Despite Russia's full-scale invasion, Ukraine has become a global leader in digital governance through its Diia app, which provides citizens with 40 government services ranging from tax payments to war-related claims. The nation's success stems from its 300,000-strong tech workforce and innovative data systems, transforming bureaucracy even amid conflict.
fields.content:
Driving through Kyiv on February 24, 2022, Oleksandr Bornyakov encountered a fierce gun battle between Russian saboteurs and Ukrainian forces during the invasion's first hours. Amid burning vehicles and casualties, Ukraine's Deputy Minister of Digital Transformation evacuated westward to continue his crucial mission: advancing the country's digital governance platform, Diia.

Launched in 2019, the Diia app initially offered driver's licenses but expanded significantly during the pandemic by adding COVID certificates, gaining millions of users. Today, the platform hosts 40 government services—including tax payments, car registration, marriage applications—and stores 30 digital documents like gun licenses and insurance. Remarkably, Ukrainians even select Eurovision entries through Diia.

With 22.7 million users accessing services or documents, Diia represents digital governance on an unprecedented scale. Bornyakov asserts Ukraine now leads globally in this domain, rivaling only Saudi Arabia while surpassing Estonia's renowned e-government system due to its user numbers and integrated approach.

Foundations of Success

Ukraine achieved this digital leap through its vast pool of tech talent. For two decades, international companies outsourced complex IT projects to Ukrainian developers, creating an estimated 300,000 skilled software engineers. Bornyakov emphasizes this highly capable workforce developed Diia efficiently at just $5-10 million—a fraction of Western development costs.

According to David Eaves, Digital Government professor at University College London, Ukraine's key breakthrough was establishing a national data exchange system before building Diia. This infrastructure enables efficient information sharing across agencies, eliminating redundant data entry. Citizens authorize access to existing records like addresses or income tax details, streamlining applications.

War-Driven Innovation

The conflict with Russia unexpectedly accelerated digital progress. Fifteen war-specific services emerged, including property damage compensation claims and Russian troop location reporting. Eaves notes warfare created unprecedented urgency, allowing officials to bypass bureaucratic obstacles that often hinder innovation.

Looking forward, Ukraine plans AI integration to refine user experiences. Bornyakov envisions AI guiding citizens through complex procedures, stating: "We want to redefine the approach to government services." Eaves cautions developers need reliable data infrastructure with careful safeguards, comparing AI adoption to "driving a Ferrari—you need good roads."

fields.title: UK Lawmakers Approve Assisted Dying Bill in Landmark Vote
fields.summary: The UK House of Commons has approved legislation allowing terminally ill adults in England and Wales to seek medically assisted deaths, passing by 314 votes to 291. The bill now moves to the House of Lords for further scrutiny, with implementation possible by 2029 if approved.
fields.content:
In a landmark decision, members of the UK Parliament voted to approve the Terminally Ill Adults Bill, which would grant terminally ill adults in England and Wales the legal right to end their lives with medical assistance. The legislation passed with 314 votes in favor and 291 against, securing a 23-vote majority despite previous wider support in earlier debates.

The bill now progresses to the House of Lords for review, where approval could lead to implementation within four years, potentially making assisted dying available by 2029. During a free vote not bound by party policy, Prime Minister Keir Starmer supported the bill while Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch opposed it. Labour MP Kim Leadbeater, instrumental in advancing the legislation, expressed emotional relief following the result.

Supporters including broadcaster Esther Rantzen hailed the vote as protecting patients from "the agony and loss of dignity created by a bad death." However, opponents like Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson raised concerns that disabled individuals feel "absolutely terrified" about potential coercion under the law.

Hundreds of campaigners gathered outside Parliament during the vote, with advocates from Dignity in Dancing celebrating while opponents warned of risks to vulnerable groups. Pamela Fisher, a Church of England preacher backing the bill, called it "a major step forward to a more compassionate society." Disability rights campaigner George Fielding countered that the legislation would "endanger the most vulnerable people in our society" and called for strengthened palliative care alternatives.

Lawmakers amended the bill during debate to exclude eligibility based solely on anorexia-induced malnutrition and to require a palliative care review within a year of passage. They rejected 170-117 a proposal prohibiting assisted dying for those with mental health conditions.

Conservative MP Danny Kruger noted the reduced majority signaled diminishing support and hopes the Lords will substantially revise the legislation. Parliament spent over three hours debating the bill, with Labour MP Peter Prinsley defending it as honoring "the sanctity of human dignity" through choice.

fields.title: Young Iranians Divided Over Israel Strikes Amid Regime Opposition
fields.summary: Young Iranian dissents opposing the Islamic regime express polarized views on Israel's recent military strikes, with some welcoming the attacks as potential catalysts for change while others distrust Israeli motives and fear civilian casualties.
fields.content:
Israel launched extensive air strikes against Iran last Friday, triggering retaliatory missile barrages from Tehran. In a video statement, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared these operations aimed not only to disrupt Iran's nuclear program but also to clear a path to "achieve your freedom" for the Iranian people.

These comments exposed divisions within Iran's fragmented opposition movement. With no authorized opposition groups operating domestically due to decades of government crackdowns, dissidents remain scattered abroad, including monarchist supporters of Reza Pahlavi and the exiled Mojahedin-e Khalq Organisation (MEK).

Journalists face difficulties contacting people inside Iran due to internet restrictions, but several young anti-regime activists across the country shared their perspectives anonymously for safety.

Support for Military Action

Twenty-six-year-old Tara accused authorities of intentionally hindering civilian safety: "When Israel issues evacuation warnings, they shut off internet access so people won't find out - increasing casualties." She claimed officials create traffic blockages near targets to immobilize citizens.

Sima, 27, expressed exhaustion with the regime: "I wish Israel would finish the job quickly... I want them to eliminate the threat of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps and Ali Khamenei." Recent attacks have killed senior IRGC commanders, including chief Hossein Salami.

Twenty-three-year-old Amir voiced unambiguous backing: "I support the strikes 100%... We tried protesting and they killed us in the streets. I'm joyful seeing those who crushed us finally face fear." He referenced Iran's 2022 crackdown that killed 537 protesters during the 'woman, life, freedom' uprising.

Doubts and Opposition

Navid, 25, who was detained during earlier protests, questioned the cost: "Israel kills ordinary people too. This approach could push citizens to support the regime... How can we overthrow the government without destroying Iran?"

Darya, 26, interpreted the absence of mass protests as rejection: "I wouldn't demonstrate even if Israel bombed my house. Netanyahu uses Iranian slogans while attacking homes. It'll take years to rebuild."

Twenty-two-year-old Arezou described painful ambivalence: "Hating the regime doesn't mean trusting Netanyahu. Seeing Gaza's destruction, I wonder—does he care about us? This is Israeli politics, not liberation. It feels like choosing between two evils."

Mina, 27, rejected both sides: "I want regime change—but not through bombs and deaths. Israel isn't our savior. Trading one terror for another isn't justice. We deserve better solutions."

fields.title: River Island to Close 33 UK Stores Amid Financial Losses
fields.summary: British fashion chain River Island plans to shut 33 UK stores, risking hundreds of jobs, as it faces mounting financial losses and adapts to shifting consumer habits towards online shopping combined with rising operational costs.
fields.content:
River Island has announced plans to close 33 of its UK stores, putting hundreds of jobs at risk as the retailer restructures its business. The clothing chain cited increasing consumer preference for online shopping and higher operational costs as key factors behind the decision.

The company is also negotiating rent reductions for an additional 71 outlets considered vulnerable. River Island currently operates 230 shops nationwide with approximately 5,500 employees but has reported significant financial strain.

Chief executive Ben Lewis stated that despite being a beloved high street brand, River Island's store network no longer aligns with customer expectations. He highlighted a sharp rise in business costs over recent years and emphasized that restructuring is essential alongside ongoing turnaround efforts.

River Island recorded a £33.2 million loss in 2023 after sales plummeted 19%, according to latest accounts. While specific closure locations remain undisclosed, the company will consult affected staff and attempt redeployment where possible. No head office positions will be impacted.

Creditors will vote on the proposals on August 4, with a court decision expected by August 7. Founded in 1948 as Lewis and Chelsea Girl before rebranding in the 1980s, the family-owned retailer faces intense competition from online giants like Shein, Temu, and Boohoo.

Financial analyst Susannah Streeter noted that recent increases in employer National Insurance contributions have compounded pressures on physical retailers. With consumer confidence weakened by inflation and fierce competition from budget-conscious rivals, the retail sector remains highly challenging for traditional chains.

fields.title: UK Parliament Backs Landmark Assisted Dying Legislation
fields.summary: The UK House of Commons has voted to allow assisted dying in England and Wales, signaling a major social policy shift following a separate vote easing abortion restrictions. The legislation now moves to the House of Lords amid strong public support and comparisons to historic reforms like same-sex marriage legalization.
fields.content:
Westminster has witnessed two significant socially liberal policy shifts within days. Parliament first voted to amend abortion legislation to prevent women in England and Wales from facing prosecution for ending pregnancies. Then the House of Commons approved assisted dying legislation for the same jurisdictions.

This assisted dying vote, while not final, marks a pivotal moment as the bill advances to the House of Lords. The change is considered a societal transformation comparable to the 1967 Abortion Act, abolition of capital punishment, and legalization of same-sex marriage. Both decisions emerged through free votes in Parliament.

The recent influx of Labour MPs following the general election facilitated the passage of both bills. Public sentiment played a key role, with recent YouGov polls indicating over 70% of Britons supporting assisted dying proposals.

During parliamentary debate, opponents voiced concerns about implementation specifics while accepting the principle of assisted dying. Some objected to the term "assisted dying," advocating instead for "assisted suicide." This vote overturned previous Commons rejections of similar legislation in 1997 and 2015.

Proponents anticipate the bill will become law following potential amendments in the House of Lords. The decisive 170-vote margin in favor reflects shifting attitudes after years of legislative stalemate on the issue.

fields.title: Historic Vote Paves Way for Legal Assisted Dying in England and Wales
fields.summary: The UK Parliament has approved a landmark bill to legalize assisted dying in England and Wales, marking the most significant vote on bodily autonomy since the 1967 abortion legalization. The legislation introduces strict safeguards for terminally ill patients but faces further scrutiny in the House of Lords before potential implementation by 2030.
fields.content:
In a historic decision, UK Parliament members have approved legislation to legalize assisted dying in England and Wales, following an emotionally charged debate. The vote represents the most significant development in bodily autonomy rights since abortion was legalized in Great Britain in 1967.

Hundreds of campaigners gathered in Parliament Square, displaying banners and photos of loved ones to voice both support and opposition to the bill. Demonstrators expressed deep personal convictions about end-of-life choices amid concerns about protecting society's vulnerable members.

What happens next?

The Terminally Ill (End of Life) Bill moves to the House of Lords for detailed scrutiny, with potential return to the Commons around October for final approval. Government estimates suggest implementation could take up to four years, with the first medically assisted deaths unlikely before 2029-2030.

Health Minister Stephen Kinnock emphasized the need for "safe and effective implementation" of this "entirely new service with robust safeguards." The proposed legislation restricts eligibility to mentally competent adults in England and Wales with terminal illnesses and less than six months to live.

Applicants must make two separate witnessed declarations of their "clear, settled and informed" wish to die, approved by two independent doctors who confirm no coercion. After a seven-day gap between assessments, a panel of experts including a psychiatrist, social worker, and lawyer reviews each case.

Approved applicants undergo a 14-day reflection period, reducible to 48 hours if death is imminent. The bill's architect, Kim Leadbeater, acknowledged the extensive process could span two months, potentially risking terminally ill patients dying while awaiting approval.

Training for doctors

Should the bill become law, Health Secretary Wes Streeting must establish an NHS-assisted dying service, despite having voted against the legislation. This requires developing specialized doctor training for assessing patient capacity and detecting coercion, plus safeguards for individuals with learning disabilities.

Original provisions requiring High Court approval for each case have been replaced with an expert panel. Oversight will fall to a voluntary assisted dying commissioner, likely a serving or retired senior judge responsible for appointing review panels and monitoring compliance.

Elsewhere in the world

The UK proposal differs significantly from international models. Unlike California where patients can store lethal medication at home without medical supervision, the UK bill requires doctors to prepare the substance and be present during ingestion. Doctors may assist patients with positioning but cannot administer the drugs directly.

England's Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty has cautioned against creating bureaucratic delays for terminally ill patients. International comparisons reveal different approaches: Oregon has a 15-day waiting period, while California reduced theirs to 48 hours to prevent patients dying pre-approval.

Government analysis estimates 1,042 to 4,559 assisted deaths annually within a decade - around 1% of England and Wales' total deaths. While euthanasia (direct medical administration) is legal in countries like Canada and the Netherlands, it's not included in UK proposals.

Other British regions are advancing similar legislation, with the Isle of Man approving an assisted dying bill and Scotland passing initial voting on their version that doesn't include a six-month prognosis requirement. Globally, assisted dying remains illegal in most countries, with supporters emphasizing patient autonomy and opponents warning of risks to vulnerable groups.

fields.title: Experts Call for Universal School Vision Screening to Detect Lazy Eye
fields.summary: Health professionals are urging universal vision screening in schools to detect lazy eye (amblyopia) early, warning that inconsistent checks across England mean thousands of children miss vital treatment windows before age seven. The condition affects 2-5% of children annually, with 11% of local authorities lacking school screening programs.
fields.content:
Children with lazy eye are increasingly missing out on treatment due to inconsistent vision screening availability in schools, health experts have warned. Budget and capacity limitations prevent some local councils from offering sight tests, according to the Local Government Association.

The British and Irish Orthoptic Society advocates for universal amblyopia screening in English schools, matching programs already established in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Lazy eye occurs when one eye is weaker than the other, with corrective patching proving most effective when treatment begins before age seven.

Ellen and Robert Hopkins discovered their son Harry had amblyopia during his first eye test at age six-and-a-half. Harry wears an eye patch daily, but progress slowed after his seventh birthday. Between two and five percent of children face similar diagnoses annually in the UK.

Despite national guidelines recommending vision checks for four-to-five-year-olds, approximately 11% of local authorities don't provide school screenings. This affects around 75,000 children living in areas including Derbyshire, Lincolnshire, and North Yorkshire.

Parents in these regions receive vision advice during early development checks or are directed to free NHS optician tests instead. Some schools use digital questionnaires to identify potential issues at enrollment.

Craig Murray of the Orthoptic Society describes the situation as a postcode lottery, stating: "Many older children now come forward when it's too late for effective treatment." Jenny Smedley, conducting screenings in Sheffield schools, reports 800 children required follow-up care this year alone.

Councillor David Fothergill of the Local Government Association has requested increased public health funding to expand screenings, claiming recent government spending reviews overlooked these needs. The government cites a £200 million funding boost earlier this year to support community health initiatives.

Vision specialists emphasize that both school screenings and regular optician visits remain essential. Daniel Hardiman-McCartney from the College of Optometrists notes parents often seek eye tests only after noticing problems, though children should receive checks every one to two years starting at age three.

Harry's parents urge others to prioritize early eye testing, even for non-readers. Though Harry's improvement plateaued after seven, his condition hasn't diminished his love of reading.

fields.title: Ancient Roman Frescoes Restored from 2,000-Year-Old Plaster Fragments
fields.summary: Archaeologists have reconstructed intricate 2,000-year-old Roman frescoes by painstakingly assembling thousands of fragmented wall plaster pieces discovered at a London construction site. The artworks reveal detailed paintings of instruments, botanical elements, and birds, offering new insights into London's affluent Roman-era suburbs.
fields.content:
Following a monumental reconstruction effort, researchers have revealed remarkably preserved Roman frescoes assembled from over 2,000 wall plaster fragments. Discovered during a 2021 excavation in central London, these artworks decorated a lavish villa and have been described by archaeologists as some of the most significant Roman wall paintings ever found in the city.

The fragments form at least 20 wall panels, with the largest fresco measuring about 5 meters by 3 meters. The artwork features rich yellow panels divided by decorative columns, pale pink lower sections resembling marble, and intricate depictions of lyres (stringed instruments), white cranes, daisies, and fruit. Archaeobotanists identified unexpected local flora like mistletoe berries integrated into classical motifs.

A particularly intriguing fragment bears the Latin inscription "Fecit" (meaning "has made this"), suggesting the artist signed their work. Though the name section remains missing, researchers continue sifting through fragments in hopes of identifying the creator. Lead archaeologist Han Li described the reconstruction as "the world's most difficult jigsaw puzzle" due to both the volume of fragments and their fragile condition.

The villa dates to the first or second century, shortly after Romans founded London in AD 43. Excavated in Southwark south of the Thames, the site contained additional significant finds including a mosaic and Roman cemetery. Researchers believe this area functioned as an affluent suburb—dubbed the "Beverly Hills of Roman London"—possibly housing wealthy families or serving as a hotel for elite travelers.

Evidence indicates highly skilled painters traveled across the Roman Empire to execute these works during London's building boom. Museum of London Archaeology experts suggest these discoveries show Romans viewed Londinium as a permanent settlement rather than a provincial outpost. Analysis continues to reveal insights about the settlement's expansion and daily life in ancient Roman London.

fields.title: BBC Issues Legal Threat to AI Firm Over Copyright Breach
fields.summary: The BBC has threatened legal action against AI company Perplexity, accusing it of illegally copying BBC news content verbatim without permission. The corporation demands the removal of its material and compensation for unauthorized use, marking its first legal confrontation with an artificial intelligence firm.
fields.content:
The BBC has formally threatened legal action against US-based AI company Perplexity, claiming its chatbot reproduces BBC news content word-for-word without authorization. In a letter to Perplexity CEO Aravind Srinivas, the broadcaster demanded an immediate halt to using its material, deletion of all existing BBC content, and financial compensation for past usage.

The corporation cited clear violations of UK copyright law and its terms of service, emphasizing this marks its first lawsuit against an AI developer. The BBC highlighted research showing significant inaccuracies in Perplexity's summarization of its news stories, noting such errors damage the broadcaster's reputation and violate its editorial standards for accurate, impartial journalism.

Perplexity responded to the allegations with a critical statement claiming the BBC aims "to preserve Google's illegal monopoly," without elaborating on its reference to Google or offering further comment.

Web scraping scrutiny

This dispute emerges amid growing global concerns about how AI companies source training data. While bots commonly scrape web content for AI development, UK publishers have urged stricter copyright enforcement. The Professional Publishers Association warned that illegal scraping threatens Britain's £4.4 billion publishing sector and 55,000 related jobs.

Though organizations often use "robots.txt" files to block unauthorized scraping, compliance remains voluntary. The BBC accused Perplexity of ignoring such directives after specifically prohibiting two of its web crawlers. Perplexity's CEO previously denied these allegations in interviews.

'Answer engine'

Perplexity markets its AI chatbot as an "answer engine" that scours the web for trusted sources to synthesize responses while advising users to verify potentially inaccurate information. This legal challenge follows a January incident where Apple disabled an AI feature that generated false BBC headline summaries.

fields.title: Chris Brown Pleads Not Guilty to London Nightclub Assault Charges
fields.summary: R&B singer Chris Brown has denied charges of attempted grievous bodily harm following an alleged bottle attack at a London nightclub in 2023, with his trial scheduled for October 2026 while he continues his European tour under strict bail conditions.
fields.content:
American singer Chris Brown has officially pleaded not guilty to assault charges stemming from an alleged bottle attack at a London nightclub two years ago. The 36-year-old artist faces accusations of attempting to cause grievous bodily harm to music producer Abraham Diaw during what prosecutors describe as an unprovoked incident.

Additional charges for assault occasioning actual bodily harm and possessing an offensive weapon—a tequila bottle—were added to his indictment prior to Friday's hearing at Southwark Crown Court. Brown will be arraigned on these counts on July 11.

The Grammy-winning performer appeared in court just hours after performing for thousands in Cardiff. Dressed in a blue suit and black-rimmed glasses, Brown remained silent amid photographers while supporters gathered outside. Inside the courtroom, he smiled and winked at an attendee before pleading "Not guilty, ma'am" to the GBH charge.

Co-defendant Omololu Akinlolu, a 39-year-old American performer known as HoodyBaby, also pleaded not guilty to the same GBH charge. Akinlolu's departure from court was documented following the hearing.

Brown was arrested last month at Manchester's Lowry Hotel while preparing for European tour dates. He spent nearly a week in custody before posting a £5 million ($6.3 million) security fee—a financial guarantee ensuring court appearances. His bail terms require UK residency during the trial period and passport surrender, though arrangements allow temporary passport release for tour commitments.

Tour dates resumed with Amsterdam on June 8, followed by UK shows. Brown humorously acknowledged supporters at his Manchester concert, thanking fans and ironically remarking, "Thank you to the jail. It was really nice." His Breezy Bowl XX tour celebrates two decades since his debut album.

Prosecutors allege Brown initiated an unprovoked attack on Diaw at Tape nightclub in Soho on February 19, 2023, striking him repeatedly with a bottle before pursuing him for further assault in another club area. Brown maintains his innocence and will perform at London's Tottenham Hotspur Stadium before his GBH trial begins on October 26, 2026.

fields.title: Assisted Dying Bill Clears Commons, Faces Lords Scrutiny
fields.summary: The proposed law to permit assisted dying for terminally ill adults in England and Wales has passed the House of Commons but faces further scrutiny in the Lords, where potential delays, opposition, and time constraints could impact its path to becoming law.
fields.content:
Legislation to legalize assisted dying in specific circumstances for England and Wales has completed its initial stages in the House of Commons. Members of Parliament voted 314 to 291 in favor of the Terminally Ill Adults (End of Life) Bill, securing a 23-vote majority. This follows an earlier vote in November where MPs supported the bill by 55 votes.

Despite this progress, the bill must still undergo full scrutiny in the House of Lords before potentially becoming law. Peers will examine the legislation in detail and propose amendments, after which MPs will review any changes. Final approval could be delayed or blocked if disagreements arise or parliamentary time runs out.

Debate and Voting in the Lords

Peers will have a conscience vote on the bill without party directives. While supporters believe there's majority backing in the Lords, the outcome remains uncertain. The chamber includes doctors, lawyers, disability rights advocates, and religious figures who will actively participate in discussions.

Potential Blocks and Opposition

As a private member’s bill sponsored by Labour MP Kim Leadbeater, it lacks official government status despite government-facilitated debate time. Opponents like Baroness Finlay, a palliative care specialist, argue the Lords shouldn't automatically endorse Commons decisions. Peers opposing the bill may feel emboldened by the reduced majority and could intensify scrutiny.

Parliamentary Time Constraints

A significant concern is whether the bill can complete Lords scrutiny before the current parliamentary session ends. Private members' bills cannot carry over between sessions. The process took seven months in the Commons, and supporters anticipate several months in the Lords. If the session ends prematurely, the legislation would collapse unless more time is allocated.

Amendments and Procedural Hurdles

Opponents could prolong debates through numerous amendments. Unlike the Commons, the Lords lacks mechanisms to force quick votes on bills. If disagreements persist between both houses, the bill could face indefinite delays through parliamentary ping-pong. Currently, only two Fridays remain scheduled for private members' bill debates.

Implementation Timeline

If passed, full implementation may take up to four years, pushing potential legal assisted deaths to late 2029. This extended timeframe results from modifications replacing high court judges with expert panels in approval processes. Bill sponsor Kim Leadbeater described the four-year deadline as a worst-case scenario rather than a target.

fields.title: Over 30 Soldiers Killed in Niger Army Base Attack by Motorbike Militants
fields.summary: Militants on over 200 motorbikes launched a deadly assault on a Nigerien military base near the Mali border, killing at least 34 soldiers and injuring 14 others. The attack intensifies security challenges in the Sahel region where jihadist violence persists despite international interventions.
fields.content:
More than 200 gunmen riding motorbikes stormed an army base in western Niger, killing at least 34 soldiers and wounding 14 others, according to the nation's defense ministry. The assault occurred on Thursday in the border town of Banibangou near Mali.

Niger's military labeled the attackers as "mercenaries," claiming their forces retaliated by killing 'dozens of terrorists' during the firefight. The defense ministry condemned the coordinated raid as a "cowardly and barbaric attack" involving several hundred assailants using eight vehicles alongside the motorbike fleet.

This violence occurs amid ongoing pressure on Niger's military over security failures, which had been cited as justification for the 2023 coup that ousted democratically elected President Mohamed Bazoum. Troops are conducting search operations in Banibangou to track down the militants.

Banibangou's location near the tri-border zone linking Niger, Mali, and Burkina Faso makes it highly vulnerable to jihadist attacks from Islamist groups plaguing the Sahel region. Niger's ruling junta recently expelled French and US forces assisting counterterrorism efforts in the area.

Along with regional neighbors Burkina Faso and Mali, Niger has formed an alliance against jihadist groups, shifting security cooperation toward Russia and Turkey. Despite these measures, militant violence across the region shows no signs of abating.

fields.title: UK Retail Sales Plunge as Supermarkets See 'Dismal' Month
fields.summary: UK retail sales volumes fell 2.7% in May – the steepest monthly decline since December 2023 – as supermarkets had a 'dismal' performance with reduced purchases of alcohol and tobacco. Government borrowing also hit the second-highest May level on record at £17.7 billion amid rising benefits costs and fragile consumer spending.
fields.content:
Retail sales volumes in the UK dropped sharply by 2.7% in May, marking the largest monthly contraction since December 2023 according to the Office for National Statistics. Senior statistician Hannah Finselbach described it as a 'dismal month for food retailers, especially supermarkets', with households cutting back on alcohol and tobacco purchases.

Clothing and home goods stores also reported sluggish trading as warmer weather prompted earlier completion of DIY projects. While the three months to May still showed a 0.8% volume increase, economists warn this signals waning economic momentum after GDP contracted 0.3% in April.

Parallel data revealed government borrowing climbed to £17.7 billion in May – the second-highest figure for the month since records began in 1993. This increase occurred despite rising tax revenue, as inflation-linked benefit expenses drove spending higher. Public borrowing totaled £37.7 billion for April-May, slightly below official forecasts but still highlighting fiscal pressures.

Inflation held steady at 3.4% in May, with food prices rising for the third consecutive month. The Bank of England maintained interest rates at 4.25% but noted 'weak' underlying growth. Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces calls to raise taxes after summer to meet fiscal rules as households cite food costs as their primary financial strain.

fields.title: Leeds Maternity Services Downgraded to 'Inadequate' Over Safety Risks
fields.summary: Maternity services at two Leeds hospitals have been downgraded from 'good' to 'inadequate' by the Care Quality Commission after inspections revealed systemic failures posing 'significant risks' to mothers and babies. Staff shortages, equipment issues, and management deficiencies were cited as critical problems affecting patient safety.
fields.content:
Maternity units at Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust have been rated "inadequate" by healthcare regulators after unannounced inspections uncovered serious safety risks. The Care Quality Commission (CQC) confirmed concerns raised by staff and patients regarding care quality and understaffing at both Leeds General Infirmary and St James' University Hospital.

Neonatal services were simultaneously downgraded from "good" to "requires improvement." Regulators issued an urgent warning notice demanding immediate changes. Recent revelations show that 67 families have reported inadequate care at the trust in the past six months, including cases involving preventable infant injuries and deaths.

'At risk of avoidable harm'

Inspectors in December 2024 and January 2025 identified regulatory breaches across multiple areas: risk management, environmental safety, incident learning protocols, infection control, medicine handling, and staffing. Critical failures included insufficient staff to monitor mothers during childbirth properly, malfunctioning equipment, empty emergency oxygen tanks, and inadequate safety information sharing between units.

The trust reported 170 maternity "red flag incidents" due to staffing shortages between May and September 2024. Similar staffing gaps affected neonatal units, leaving babies with complex needs without sufficient specialized care. In response, the trust plans to deploy 35 newly qualified midwives this autumn and has created additional midwifery leadership positions.

Ann Ford, CQC Director for Northern England, confirmed ongoing monitoring: "We'll conduct further inspections to ensure patient safety during improvements. We thank those who bravely shared concerns to help focus our assessment."

Families demand accountability

Amarjit Kaur and Mandip Singh Matharoo, whose daughter Asees was stillborn in January 2024, believe proper care could have prevented her death. They stated: "The CQC report confirms how inadequate services caused harm to patients. This comes too late for us but must trigger systemic change."

Fiona-Winser Ramm, whose daughter Aliona died in 2020 following documented "gross failures," called the findings "horrific," adding: "Problems we've highlighted for five years are now validated, but the CQC ignored them since their 2023 inspection that wrongly rated services as good." The CQC defended its 2023 assessment, noting it focused specifically on leadership and safety, revealing both strengths and improvement needs.

Trust pledges urgent reforms

Trust Chief Executive Prof Phil Wood acknowledged deficiencies: "My priority is urgent action to deliver improvements. We are committed to safe, compassionate care." He noted over 8,500 annual births at the hospitals, adding, "While most experiences are positive, we recognize this isn't universal." The trust has initiated recruitment drives and cultural reforms.

All 67 affected families demand an independent inquiry into maternity services, requesting leadership by senior midwife Donna Ockenden. Some Leeds families joined other bereaved parents this week urging Health Secretary Wes Streeting to launch a national maternity safety investigation.

fields.title: Teacher shifts to part-time to balance parenthood and profession amid recruitment woes
fields.summary: Primary school teacher Alice Cole highlights the value of part-time work after becoming a parent to preserve family time, as England faces record-low teacher recruitment and retention challenges, with flexible arrangements proposed as a solution amid broader struggles in specialist subjects and disadvantaged schools.
fields.content:
Alice Cole dedicated eight years to full-time teaching, but the birth of her son Oliver in May last year dramatically reshaped her priorities. "I really loved my job, and I loved working full-time. I couldn't have seen that changing before I had a family," she recalled.

With Cole's partner on shift work, a full-time teaching schedule would have rendered family time "non-existent." Now working three days a week at Oasis Academy Warndon in a flexible arrangement, she cherishes moments like baby group sessions with Oliver: "Working flexibly has given me that precious time with my son which I wouldn't change for the world."

Cole argues that expanding flexible options, especially for new parents, is crucial for solving the teaching profession's recruitment and retention issues. She wants all such educators to "feel confident that taking that step forward in their personal life isn't going to lead to a step back in their professional life."

Record Low Recruitment and Retention Strains

New data underscores the crisis, revealing a drop of 400 teachers overall in England, with only 41,736 joining in 2024-25—the lowest number on record at 9.2% of all teachers. Recruitment targets for both primary and secondary schools were missed for the ninth time in ten years.

Pay and working conditions have fueled departures. Despite a slight improvement since 2023-24, 8.2% of teachers left the profession last year. Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson cited these challenges while announcing a 4% pay rise and plans to recruit 6,500 new teachers, urging schools to adopt flexible hours.

However, critics like shadow minister Neil O'Brien accuse the government of overlooking growing deficiencies: falling numbers in nurseries and primary schools drove the decline despite increases elsewhere.

The Intensive Reality of Teaching Careers

Sam Alner, a computer science teacher and vice principal at London's Bridge Academy, embodies the profession's pressures. He labels teaching "relentless," citing 5:00 am starts and late finishes during exam peaks that make work-life balance elusive.

Alner—overseeing pupils where over half receive free meals—has no current plans to leave but has seen colleagues quit for higher wages or better balance: "There's always more you can do...When you're having to make the choice between that, people look at teaching and go: 'I can't sustain or justify this.'"

Subject Gaps in Disadvantaged Areas

Specialist subjects like computing reveal deep inequities. Recruitment hit only 37% of the national target for 2024-25, leaving 15% of poor-area schools unable to offer computer science GCSE—versus 4% in wealthier districts—states Teach First data.

Dan Botting of Portsmouth Academy describes filling computing roles as "really challenging" due to regional retention issues. His solution involved retraining a senior staffer to cover classes after failing to hire, but this forced them to cap GCSE spots despite high demand. "It's a shame," Botting said, noting pupil enthusiasm warrants tripling current capacity.

Emphasizing long-term retention, Botting added schools must secure staff "with the right skills and expertise to deliver for pupils who need it most."

Additional reporting by William Dahlgreen

fields.title: Player Demand Leads to Optional Combat Radar in Borderlands 4
fields.summary: After player feedback highlighted concerns over navigation, Gearbox Entertainment has added an optional combat radar to Borderlands 4, allowing players to better track enemies without a minimap. The feature, set for the game's release on September 12, was developed due to community input during preview events.
fields.content:
The debate around minimaps in video games is widely intense, as constant on-screen maps can distract players from immersive worlds, but their absence may lead to confusion during navigation or combat. In Borderlands 4's case, early footage revealed a lack of minimap, prompting player distress over lost enemy tracking in dynamic battles.

Gearbox founder Randy Pitchford addressed this response on social media, explaining that the initial omission was intentional due to the game's vast, seamless world. He stated, 'Borderlands 4 is much larger than ever before, and seamless. There are main missions and side quests that often have objectives beyond a useful mini-map's scope. So we invest more into the main map – making it faster and better.'

Instead, the team focused on enhancing tools like a compass for direction and an EchoBot AI drone, which can paint paths similar to spells in other RPGs. These features offer clear objective markers and height indications, addressing issues minimaps typically falter in.

However, during preview events like the Borderlands world tour, players emphasized the combat utility of a minimap for situational awareness. Pitchford noted, 'The people who stuck with their feelings about a combat radar had a point. Combat is all feel. Should we require everyone to learn the compass?' This led to the rapid development of an optional combat radar.

The radar, which defaults to off, will be available at the game's launch on September 12 for PC via Steam and the Epic Game Store. This addition showcases Gearbox's responsiveness to community-driven improvements based on feedback.

fields.title: Shotgun Cop Man Free DLC Adds Bullet Time and Banana Mayhem
fields.summary: Action game Shotgun Cop Man has received a significant free DLC update introducing bullet time mechanics, skateboards, and features from developer DeadToast Entertainment's previous hit My Friend Pedro, including 51 new levels and boss battles.
fields.content:
Shotgun Cop Man, the chaotic action-platformer from developer DeadToast Entertainment, has received a major free expansion inspired by the studio's earlier hit My Friend Pedro. This DLC introduces slow-motion gunplay, acrobatic skateboard mechanics, and Pedro the talking banana – all signature elements from DeadToast's 2019 cult favorite where players ricocheted bullets off frying pans while guided by a sentient fruit.

The base game originally featured players battling demons in hell using its signature ground-blast propulsion system that transforms shotgun recoil into makeshift double-jumps. While praised for its kinetic combat, it lacked the slow-motion flourishes of My Friend Pedro. The new update bridges that gap with a substantial content drop featuring 17 levels across three entirely new worlds themed around Pedro's universe.

Beyond the iconic bullet time and skateboards, the free expansion incorporates breakable glass, frying pans for projectile deflection, ziplines, swing ropes, and naturally, Pedro himself. Three formidable new boss fights challenge players, including a climactic battle against a helicopter. The 51 combined levels significantly expand the game's content without added cost to owners.

Coinciding with the DLC launch, both games are discounted on Steam: Shotgun Cop Man sees a 20% price reduction while My Friend Pedro receives an 80% discount. For action enthusiasts missing chaotic slow-motion shootouts, these deals offer avenue into DeadToast's explosively creative catalog – though bullet time skeptics might take issue with Pedro's persuasive philosophies.

fields.title: Hypnospace Outlaw sequel Dreamsettler cancelled due to overscoping
fields.summary: Dreamsettler, the planned sequel to critically acclaimed game Hypnospace Outlaw, has been cancelled after development challenges. Lead developer Jay Tholen cited overscoping issues and the removal of a key feature as primary reasons for halting production, though some created content will still emerge.
fields.content:
The highly anticipated sequel to 2019's Hypnospace Outlaw has been permanently shelved due to development challenges. Titled Dreamsettler, the project was announced in 2022 alongside spinoff Slayers X: Terminal Aftermath: Vengeance of the Slayer, which released successfully in 2023.

Lead developer Jay Tholen confirmed the cancellation in a video statement, emphasizing that publisher No More Robots wasn't responsible. 'They didn't pull support or anything and they did what they could to keep it going, but it's just time to stop it,' Tholen clarified.

Development challenges and feature cuts

Dreamsettler's central downfall was overscoping, particularly regarding a key feature called 'Oomph' - intended as a fictional Flash-like tool for creating music-synced animations. When budget constraints forced Oomph's removal, Tholen's motivation significantly diminished. 'We just way overscoped. Things were so complicated and fancy,' he admitted.

This setback highlighted a fundamental clash between Tholen's creative process and structured development. The developer described his approach as instinctive: 'I have to improvise... Things bloom from other things and become this big holistic thing.' He contrasted this with Dreamsettler's requirement for formal design documents, which stifled his workflow.

Legacy of the cancelled project

Some creative elements from Dreamsettler will survive despite the cancellation. Tholen's team has begun sharing 'Czechimation' concepts online - imagining Czech animation gaining western popularity akin to anime. This includes artwork and snippets for fictional shows like 'Golem Master' and 'Little Babi' through their BlueSky account.
