9. Best earbuds: Steelseries Arctis GameBuds

Delivering discreet low-latency sound with effective noise isolation, these earbuds provide solid in-game audio performance and extended battery life in a highly portable form factor ideal for mobile gamers.

fields.title: Acer Predator X32X QD-OLED Review: Curved 4K Gaming Excellence
fields.summary: The Acer Predator X32X QD-OLED combines a distinctive 1700R curve with 4K resolution, 240Hz refresh rate, and OLED technology for exceptional gaming immersion. While the curved design may polarize users, its performance excels in fast-paced titles.
fields.content:
The Acer Predator X32X QD-OLED enters the competitive gaming monitor market with a distinctive curved screen that sets it apart from other 4K OLED displays. While curved designs often polarize opinions, the 1700R curvature on this 32-inch monitor genuinely enhances immersion in first-person games when combined with exceptional OLED brightness and sharpness.

Initial setup revealed some unexpected quirks. Out of the box, the display appeared overly subdued and required adjustment through both the monitor's OSD settings and Windows 11 configuration. Activating HDR in both systems followed by selecting 'Max Brightness' mode unleashed the panel's full potential, delivering the vibrant visuals expected from QD-OLED technology. Precision testing confirmed coverage of 98% of the DCI-P3 color gamut.

The monitor features a 32-inch QD-OLED panel with 3840x2160 resolution and a blazing 240Hz refresh rate. Connectivity includes USB-C, dual HDMI 2.1 ports, two DisplayPort 1.4 connections, USB KVM capability, and HDR400 certification. Physical adjustments provide +25° to -5° tilt, 90° pivot, ±20° swivel, and 150mm height adjustment. The unit weighs 7kg with its stand and measures 818x30.5x579mm.

Gaming performance impresses with near-zero ghosting and excellent motion clarity at the 240Hz refresh rate. The panel maintains good viewing angles despite a slight yellowish tint common to QD-OLED screens, which can be adjusted via color temperature settings. Build quality remains premium with Acer's signature Predator design, though the casing attracts dust and requires an external power brick.

Connectivity stands out as a major strength with abundant ports for multi-device setups. The inclusion of two DisplayPort and two HDMI inputs alongside USB-C (with 65W charging) makes it versatile for PCs and consoles. The USB hub facilitates peripheral sharing between systems, complemented by a headphone hook on the stand. Priced at $900 (US) and £869 (UK), it compares favorably with similarly specced flat OLED alternatives.

While curved 32-inch monitors remain less common, the X32X offers a compelling option for gamers seeking enhanced immersion. Its curvature elevates the experience in compatible titles without sacrificing the outstanding visual performance expected from cutting-edge OLED displays in its class.

fields.title: Mastering Jasmium Crystal Farming in Dune: Awakening
fields.summary: This guide reveals optimal strategies for locating and harvesting Jasmium Crystal in Dune: Awakening's dangerous Sheol region, including radiation management tips and efficient farming techniques for crafting vital late-game equipment.
fields.content:
Acquiring Jasmium Crystal presents one of Dune: Awakening's toughest endgame challenges. This rare mineral is required alongside Aluminum Ingots to create Duraluminum in a Medium Ore Refinery. These resources are essential for crafting advanced gear like the Spice Refinery and Cutteray Mk5. Before attempting to gather Jasmium, players must prepare for significant environmental hazards in the mining region.

Jasmium Crystal locations in Sheol

Jasmium Crystals are exclusively found in Sheol's southern mid-section. Mining requires an Industrial Cutteray Mk4 or better, plus radiation protection. It's advisable to approach from the southwest (7-8 o'clock position) using an Ornithopter to avoid ground radiation. Look for large yellowish crystals growing in glowing puddles – avoid stepping in the toxic liquid which causes level 3 radiation immediately.

Due to the crystals' heavy weight, a single mining trip yields limited quantities. Prepare radiation countermeasures before farming, as lingering in contaminated zones severely impacts survival. The Hagga Basin serves as the primary access point to Sheol resources.

Essential radiation protection strategies

Success requires careful radiation management. Always bring multiple Radiation Detoxification packages, ideally the Improved variant requiring 4 Sand Dragon Scales and 2 Mythrite Dusts. Equip Advanced Radiation Gear crafted from Mythril Plates and Refined Corundum. Iodine Pills offer additional protection but require Duraluminum to create – inaccessible before establishing Jasmium farming. The Ornithopter remains the safest transport for quick entry and exit from contaminated zones.

Advanced farming techniques

Optimize yield by scouting high-elevation spots in southwest Sheol before mining. Spot potential clusters using Survey Probes to identify crystal groupings from a safe distance. Position mountain ridges and rock formations between yourself and hostile players while harvesting. Due to crystal weight, transport limitations are inevitable, so prioritize key crafting objectives when planning farming runs.

fields.title: Hearthstone's $158 Pet Sparks Outrage Over Gacha Mechanics
fields.summary: Blizzard introduced the first interactive pet in Hearthstone, King Krush, through a controversial gacha system where players may pay up to $158 to obtain it, sparking widespread criticism over the pricing model.
fields.content:
The debut of Hearthstone's first in-game interactive pet has triggered backlash due to its acquisition method. King Krush, a charming dinosaur companion that reacts to gameplay, became available through the Darkmoon Faire Treasures stall—a digital gacha mechanism where players pay escalating fees for randomized rewards.

This mechanic offers one free initial pull, after which the cost increases with each subsequent attempt to obtain rewards. The pet is among ten possible items in the prize pool, with the odds strongly weighted against players—starting at just 0.1% for King Krush on the first attempt.

The Cost of Collection

To guarantee obtaining all ten rewards including the pet, players must make ten pulls at cumulative costs peaking near $158. Blizzard published odds showing how probabilities shift marginally as items are removed. For instance, after four pulls, the chance of getting King Krush rises only to 0.3922%.

The pricing structure follows lucrative currency bundles. Even with the largest offered pack of 8,000 runestones at $79.99, meeting all ten pulls requires duplicating that expense—at least $160 total. Fans quickly created a simulator replicating this system, often yielding average outcomes matching Blizzard's projected cost.

Community Reactions

Fans immediately condemned the pricing. Content creator Zeddy expressed disappointment, stating: 'King Krush deserved better than being paywalled for $158.' Others highlighted alternatives—a Nintendo Switch Lite, 160 taquitos, or 50 gallons of gas equal this pet’s cost.

Some argued that high cosmetic prices fund game longevity, but critiques labeled it a 'cash grab' disguised behind carnival-style promos insisting 'everyone's a winner.' Blizzard externally discloses odds and escalating pull costs but avoids upfront clarity about the total expense. Despite predictions of price adjustments, past expensive cosmetics suggest them unlikely soon.

fields.title: University Course Cuts Spark Fear of Regional 'Cold Spots'
fields.summary: A Universities UK report warns that course reductions across UK universities could create subject 'cold spots' where students can't access certain degrees locally. The study calls for regulatory flexibility to allow collaboration between institutions amid financial pressures.
fields.content:
University students across the UK may soon face regional education 'cold spots' lacking specific courses due to widespread program cuts, a new study reveals. Universities UK (UUK), representing 141 institutions, identified reluctance among universities to collaborate on course delivery due to competition law concerns. The Competition and Markets Authority acknowledged the sector's financial strain and expressed willingness to support partnerships where feasible.

Case Study in Collaborative Learning

Current collaborative programs already benefit students like Joe Vincent, 33, who studies pharmacy remotely. Living in Devon with his family, the University of Bath masters student attends courses 130 miles away through Plymouth facilities. "It's everything for me," Vincent states, noting local access makes the difference between pursuing his career or not. After training as a pharmacy technician in 2018 due to absent local pharmacist programs, this partnership tackles the South West's healthcare shortage.

Competition Law Barriers

UUK review leader Sir Nigel Carrington warns neighboring universities must strategically manage course offerings without risking illegal collusion. "Cold spots will emerge where students can't study desired subjects in their home regions," he told the BBC. Cardiff University vice-chancellor Wendy Larner confirmed this challenge, expressing frustration at legal barriers preventing consultation with peers on course closures. While sharing administrative functions between institutions remains permissible under competition rules, direct course coordination requires regulatory change.

Sector Financial Pressures

University finances face multiple pressures: a 16% drop in international students after January's visa rule changes squeezes income, while domestic tuition fees have remained capped at £9,250 until autumn's increase to £9,535. The Office for Students warns 40% of UK universities face deficits this year, prompting course cuts at institutions including Sheffield, Durham, and Bournemouth. These circumstances create a patchwork of isolated decisions driven by market forces instead of regional educational planning.

A government spokesperson confirmed ongoing reforms would make universities "engines of opportunity," with long-term higher education funding proposals for England expected this summer. Skills Minister Jacqui Smith welcomed UUK's focus on collaboration amid financial restructuring.

fields.title: Social Media Fuels Misogyny Epidemic, Warns Murder Victim's Daughter
fields.summary: Amy Hunt, who lost her mother and two sisters in a violent attack by her sibling's ex-boyfriend, warns society about the alarming link between misogynistic social media content and real-world violence against women, calling for urgent collective action to address this 'epidemic'.
fields.content:
Amy Hunt has described misogyny as society's 'acceptable form of extremism' following the brutal murders of her mother Carol, 61, and sisters Hannah, 28, and Louise, 25. The attack occurred last July at their Bushey, Hertfordshire home by Louise's former partner, Kyle Clifford.

'There's an epidemic we face that has the most horrific, devastating consequences,' Amy stated in an interview alongside her father John Hunt, a racing commentator. The family stresses that Clifford's actions reflected deep-seated hatred and insecurity, with Amy observing: 'He doesn't hate women as much as he hates himself.'

The Social Media Connection

Court evidence revealed Clifford consumed content from controversial influencer Andrew Tate before the murders, searching Tate's podcast just one day prior. Amy emphasized this was 'not coincidence but undeniable linkage,' though she rejected notions that Clifford only became dangerous after exposure. 'It's not just Andrew Tate,' she cautioned, 'many subsets spout the same hate across platforms.'

The tragedy underscores what the Hunts describe as society's failure to curb misogyny. John Hunt stressed: 'Schools must teach boys to respect women much earlier. Once they start viewing toxic content, they're already on the path to doom.'

At sentencing, Judge Bennathan condemned Clifford as 'soaked in self-pity' and holding 'women in utter contempt' after he murdered Carol with a knife, then waited to rape Louise and shoot both sisters with a crossbow. Clifford received three whole-life sentences in March.

The Hunts dispute claims that prior abuse warnings existed, yet Amy holds society accountable: 'We allow misogyny to fester until it forces itself into lives like ours.' She noted her loved ones became statistics instantly, stressing: 'This is fundamentally a male issue requiring behavioral change.' The BBC provides support resources through its Action Line.

fields.title: Iran's leader rejects US claims on nuclear site strikes as ineffective
fields.summary: Ayatollah Khamenei has dismissed US claims about the effectiveness of strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities, asserting Washington 'gained no achievements' just days after a ceasefire halted hostilities between Iran and Israel.
fields.content:
Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has declared US strikes against nuclear sites achieved no meaningful results. In his first public appearance since Tuesday's ceasefire, Khamenei stated the attacks failed to significantly disrupt Iran's nuclear program. He characterized Iranian missile strikes on a US base in Qatar as having delivered a "heavy blow" to American forces.

Contrasting assessments

US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth countered Khamenei's claims, asserting intelligence indicated the operation "significantly damaged the nuclear programme" and rendered enrichment facilities "inoperable". The Secretary described the mission as a "historic success" that set back Iran's atomic ambitions by years during a Pentagon briefing alongside General Dan Caine. President Donald Trump previously claimed the attacks "totally obliterated" three facilities and refuted reports suggesting limited damage.

Hegseth addressed speculation about enriched uranium relocation, stating the US possesses "no intelligence" indicating materials were moved from Fordo's underground complex before bunker-buster bombs struck. Khamenei's televised address followed limited public appearances since hostilities erupted on June 13, during which authorities confirmed he sheltered in secure locations amid the conflict. The leader warned of future attacks on US bases should Iran face further aggression, calling previous strikes against the Qatar installation "repeatable". These attacks caused no fatalities according to US officials.

Conflict background

The crisis escalated when Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asserted Iran could rapidly develop nuclear weapons, prompting direct confrontation. This followed the International Atomic Energy Agency ruling that Iran breached non-proliferation obligations for the first time in 20 years. Tehran maintains its nuclear activities exclusively serve civilian purposes.

Iran's parliament escalated tensions by approving legislation halting cooperation with the IAEA, terminating nuclear inspections. Iranian health officials reported 610 deaths during 12 days of fighting, while Israel confirmed 28 fatalities. US forces directly entered the conflict last weekend with strikes on Fordo, Natanz, and Isfahan facilities before brokering a ceasefire.

IAEA chief Rafael Grossi suggested Iran potentially relocated highly enriched uranium during attacks. The ceasefire agreement initially showed instability with continued hostilities before implementation.

fields.title: Pound Hits Four-Year High Amid Trump Fed Appointment Speculation
fields.summary: The British pound climbed to its strongest level against the US dollar in nearly four years as markets reacted to reports that President Trump may accelerate appointing a new Federal Reserve chair, raising concerns about central bank independence and economic stability.
fields.content:
The British pound reached its highest value against the US dollar in nearly four years after markets reacted to reports that President Donald Trump might name a new Federal Reserve chair ahead of schedule. Sterling briefly surpassed $1.37, a level not seen since October 2021.

This surge followed a Wall Street Journal report indicating Trump could replace current Fed Chair Jerome Powell as early as September or October. The dollar weakened significantly on these concerns about political interference in the central bank's operations.

Trump has repeatedly criticized Powell this year, calling him 'terrible' and confirming he's examining 'three or four people' for the position. Powell's official term runs through May 2026. Market fears center on potential replacement candidates who might align more closely with Trump's policy priorities.

The Federal Reserve maintains independence from the White House in setting interest rates, which have remained unchanged despite Trump's repeated complaints. Powell recently told Congress the Fed would monitor economic impacts if Trump's proposed retaliatory tariffs take effect after their current July 9 pause.

Economists worry these import levies, paid by US companies, could worsen inflation. This concern comes as new data shows the US economy shrank in Q1 2024—its first contraction in three years—partly driven by companies rushing imports ahead of potential tariffs.

JP Morgan reduced its 2024 US recession forecast but still pegs the probability at 40%. Financial experts note eroding institutional confidence may weaken the dollar further. 'Traders are betting against the dollar amid institutional erosion,' observed Kaspar Hense of RBC BlueBay Asset Management.

Former Federal Reserve governor Kevin Warsh has emerged as a potential replacement, with Trump calling him 'very highly thought of.' US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent could also be considered, having recently stated he's 'happy to do what President Trump wants.'

Ironically, Trump originally appointed Powell to succeed Janet Yellen in 2018 after criticizing her rate policies. Yellen later questioned Trump's macroeconomic knowledge after becoming Treasury Secretary under President Biden.

fields.title: UK PM Offers Welfare Concessions Amid Labour Rebellion
fields.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer is offering to soften proposed welfare cuts in negotiations with rebellious Labour MPs ahead of a key vote. Over 120 Labour backbenchers have joined an amendment to block the legislation.
fields.content:
Prime Minister Keir Starmer is considering scaling back proposed welfare cuts to prevent a significant rebellion within his own Labour Party. The government confirmed ongoing talks to amend controversial legislation ahead of a scheduled parliamentary vote next Tuesday.

Over 126 Labour MPs not holding government positions have now backed an amendment to stop the welfare bill's progress. This represents approximately half of Labour's backbenchers. Sir Keir has personally contacted dissenting MPs to seek compromise.

Discussing the welfare reforms in parliament, the Prime Minister acknowledged widespread recognition that the system requires repair. He stated, "We want to see reform implemented with Labour values and fairness," emphasizing continued dialogue before Tuesday's vote.

Welfare Reform Details

The Universal Credit and Personal Independence Payment Bill proposes stricter eligibility criteria for disability benefits. It would reduce health-related universal credit amounts while increasing standard allowances, aiming to save £5 billion annually by 2030.

Government statistics indicate working-age health benefit expenditures surged from £36 billion to £52 billion between 2019 and 2024. The Institute for Fiscal Studies projects this could reach £66 billion by 2029 without reforms. Critics oppose requirements like compelling claimants to demonstrate extensive assistance needs with daily tasks.

Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch declared welfare spending "out of control" during a recent business address. She highlighted stagnating productivity and argued benefits shouldn't cover conditions like anxiety. Badenoch cited a Centre for Social Justice report suggesting £7.4 billion could be saved annually by restricting mental health benefits to severe cases, funding 1.5 million therapy sessions.

Winter Fuel Reversal Impact

A key architect of the Labour rebellion revealed the government's U-turn on winter fuel payment cuts strengthened rebel resolve. The anonymous organizer noted MPs faced constituency backlash over the abandoned plans, questioning why they should endure similar criticism again.

Work and Pensions Secretary Liz Kendall previously extended transition support from four to 13 weeks for those losing benefits. Commons Leader Lucy Powell confirmed the bill's first vote remains scheduled for next Tuesday, with subsequent stages the following Wednesday.

Resolution Foundation economist Louise Murphy described the extended transition as sensible but noted proposed employment support funding won't be fully operational until 2029.

fields.title: UK Study Probes Weight Loss Drug Links to Pancreatic Complications
fields.summary: UK regulators have initiated a genetic research project investigating potential connections between popular weight loss injections and pancreatic disorders, following hundreds of reported adverse reactions among users of medications like Ozempic and Wegovy.
fields.content:
British health authorities are investigating whether weight loss medications could trigger serious pancreatic complications, based on numerous patient reports. The Medicines and Healthcare Regulatory Agency and Genomics England are seeking participants who experienced pancreatitis after using drugs such as Ozempic, Wegovy, and Mounjaro - medications also prescribed for type 2 diabetes.

Researchers are examining whether genetic factors increase vulnerability to pancreas inflammation among individuals using these treatments. Dr. Alison Cave, MHRA's chief safety officer, emphasized the study aims to "better predict those most at risk of adverse reactions" through scrutiny of genetic influences.

Patients aged 18 and older who suffered severe reactions requiring hospitalization can report their cases through the Yellow Card surveillance program. Selected participants will provide detailed information and DNA samples to identify potential hereditary risk factors. The initiative hopes to prevent future complications by personalizing treatment approaches.

Official records show up to 13 May included 10 fatal pancreatitis cases among weight loss medication users, though authorities caution multiple factors might have contributed. The data remains inconclusive about whether the drugs directly caused the complications.

Regulators note usage figures are unclear as many acquire these medications through unregulated online sources outside conventional medical supervision. While health officials acknowledge these injections could help combat obesity, they stress they aren't cure-alls. Known side effects include nausea, constipation, and diarrhoea.

Additional warnings state Mounjaro might reduce oral contraceptive effectiveness in some users. Dr. Cave highlighted that genetic testing could prevent almost one-third of adverse drug responses, potentially saving Britain's health system over £2.2 billion annually on hospitalization costs alone.

Professor Matt Brown, Genomics England's scientific chief, explained: "GLP-1 medicines have been making headlines, but like all medicines there can be a risk of serious side effects. We believe there is real potential to minimise these, with many adverse reactions having a genetic cause."

fields.title: Delays Plague Special Education Support Plans For Thousands of Children
fields.summary: Government data reveals that fewer than half of education, health and care plans for children with special educational needs were completed within mandatory timeframes last year. Rising demand and systemic pressures have created extensive delays, leaving thousands of families in limbo as authorities prepare controversial reforms.
fields.content:
Children with special educational needs face increasingly long waits for essential support, with only 46% of required education, health and care plans (EHCPs) issued within the mandatory 20-week deadline in 2024. The Department for Education acknowledges local authorities are "overwhelmed" and has promised "wide-ranging reform" this autumn.

These delays unfold as parents and charities express growing concerns that proposed government changes may eliminate EHCPs entirely. Sue from Wirral, whose family waited 72 weeks for her daughter's EHCP after months of challenges, describes the constant stress experienced by caregivers: "I now fully appreciate that parents of children with SEND are stuck in fight or flight mode. I've been fighting so long."

Sue's 11-year-old daughter Matilda has suspected autism and ADHD, requiring a carefully managed transition as she finishes primary school. The delay meant missing critical planning opportunities before secondary education begins. Sue explains, "She really struggles with change," highlighting how overdue support impacts children's daily lives.

Wirral Council reports processing more than double the pre-pandemic volume of EHCP assessment requests despite injecting an extra £2.8 million annually and doubling staff. However, Sue fears the government's upcoming reforms might abolish EHCPs altogether, which could prove "devastating" for dependent children like Matilda.

Current data shows 638,745 children in England have EHCPs—an 11% annual increase and the highest figure since the plans launched ten years ago. These legally binding documents mandate individualized educational, health, and social support, such as specialist equipment or one-to-one assistance.

Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson aims to place more students in mainstream schools, supported by £740 million in adaptation funding. Yet 43% of children with EHCPs already navigate mainstream settings, while 1.3 million others without formal plans receive special needs help, raising concerns about legal protections.

Katie Gauche from the Disabled Children's Partnership warns that plans to replace EHCPs will "terrify families," stressing that legal documentation remains vital for access to education. "An EHCP is the only way many children get an education," she emphasized, urging reforms that strengthen rights without bureaucratic hurdles.

A recent National Audit Office report declared England's special educational needs system financially unsustainable despite funding growth. Though local authorities secured an extension until 2028 for £3 billion in deficits, County Councils Network chair Tim Oliver stressed the urgency for "comprehensive reform" and "clearly defined support," warning the government cannot "afford to get it wrong."

Phillipson acknowledged systemic failures lead to delayed interventions that overwhelm services: "Too many children don't have needs identified early, creating a vicious cycle where support escalates to crisis point." Her proposed changes include boosting specialist staff and autumn legislation to revamp the entire support framework.

fields.title: Synthetic Human Genome Project Launches to Build DNA from Scratch
fields.summary: A new scientific initiative funded by the Wellcome Trust aims to create artificial human DNA from scratch, promising revolutionary medical treatments but sparking ethical concerns over potential misuse.
fields.content:
Groundbreaking work has commenced on synthesizing artificial human DNA, a project considered the first of its kind in the world, despite its controversial nature due to fears it might enable the creation of designer babies or unforeseen genetic alterations for future generations.

The Wellcome Trust, the world's largest medical charity, has allocated an initial £10 million for this research, supported by scientists like Dr. Julian Sale from the MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology in Cambridge, who described it as a monumental leap in biology.

"The sky is the limit. We are looking at therapies that will improve people's lives as they age, leading to healthier individuals with fewer diseases later in life," said Sale, adding that the technology could generate disease-resistant cells for organ repair in the liver, heart, or immune system.

Scientific Goals and Potential Benefits

Every human cell contains DNA, composed of repeating molecules A, G, C, and T that define genetic identity. While the Human Genome Project successfully mapped these elements exactly 25 years ago, the Synthetic Human Genome Project aims to construct human DNA piece by piece, potentially leading to artificial chromosomes that regulate bodily functions.

Prof Matthew Hurles of the Wellcome Sanger Institute explained that building DNA from scratch allows unprecedented testing of genetic theories, which could advance treatments for diseases caused by faulty genes, moving beyond current methods of altering existing DNA.

Initial experiments will synthesize DNA segments in test tubes, avoiding the creation of synthetic life forms while enabling researchers to manipulate genetic information for medical purposes, such as developing therapies for currently incurable conditions.

Ethical Risks and Criticisms

Critics warn that this technology could be exploited for harmful purposes, including the development of biological weapons, enhanced humans, or hybrid organisms. Dr. Pat Thomas of Beyond GM cautioned, "We like to think scientists are there to do good, but the science can be repurposed for harm and warfare."

Edinburgh University's Prof Bill Earnshaw called it "the genie out of the bottle," noting restrictions might not prevent unscrupulous groups from synthesizing hazardous genetic materials. Additional concerns focus on commercialization, with Thomas questioning ownership rights over synthetic body parts or entities.

Dr. Tom Collins, instrumental in securing Wellcome's funding, defended the decision by emphasizing the inevitability of such technology, stating that acting now allows for proactive ethical confrontation. A parallel social science effort, led by Prof Joy Zhang of the University of Kent, will gather public input to ensure responsible development and address societal implications.

fields.title: Trump Phone 'Made in USA' Claim Vanishes From Website
fields.summary: References to 'Made in the USA' have been removed from the Trump T1 phone's promotional materials days after its announcement, though organizers insist it will still be American-made. Industry experts express skepticism about producing smartphones entirely in the United States.
fields.content:
Days after the Trump Organization unveiled plans for a US-made smartphone, all references to "Made in the USA" have disappeared from the product's website. When the gold Trump T1 phone launched on June 16th, promotional materials proudly featured the American manufacturing claim, but by Wednesday all such mentions had vanished.

A Trump Mobile spokesperson confirmed to BBC that the phone will still be manufactured in America, stating "speculation to the contrary is simply inaccurate." The organization encouraged customers to switch mobile providers using existing phones while awaiting the Trump T1's release later this year.

Website descriptions were altered to highlight an "American-Proud Design" and emphasize that the device is "brought to life right here in the USA" with "American hands behind every device." The pre-order banner changed from promoting "our MADE IN THE USA T1 Phone" to simply "the new T1 phone"—changes first spotted by The Verge.

Experts immediately questioned the manufacturing claims when Donald Trump's family members announced the phone. Professor Tinglong Dai of Johns Hopkins University stated they lack even a working prototype, calling September production timelines miraculous. CCS Insight's Leo Gebbie noted America lacks smartphone supply chains, suggesting assembly from imported parts might be the only feasible path.

Similar doubts surround Trump's push for Apple to shift iPhone production stateside. The former president threatened 25% tariffs in May if Apple didn't manufacture US-sold iPhones domestically, a demand tech analyst Dan Ives called a "fairy tale that is not feasible." Eric Trump nevertheless maintains that "eventually all phones can be built in the United States."

fields.title: Denis Villeneuve Announced as Director for Next James Bond Film
fields.summary: Acclaimed filmmaker Denis Villeneuve, known for the Dune series and Arrival, has been officially named director of the next James Bond film. The French-Canadian director expressed plans to honor the franchise's legacy while bringing his distinctive cinematic vision to the iconic spy series.
fields.content:
Amazon MGM Studios confirmed that Oscar-nominated filmmaker Denis Villeneuve will helm the next installment of the James Bond franchise. The Dune director described himself as a lifelong 007 enthusiast in an official statement released by the studio.

Villeneuve committed to honoring the spy series' heritage while crafting the future path for the character. This announcement comes after longtime Bond producers Barbara Broccoli and Michael G. Wilson handed control of the franchise to Amazon earlier this year.

What will Villeneuve bring to Bond?

Villeneuve acknowledged the significance of taking charge of cinema's most enduring spy franchise, recalling childhood viewings of Sean Connery's films with his father. The director stated: "I intend to honour the tradition and open the path for many new missions to come."

Amazon MGM Studios chief Mike Hopkins praised Villeneuve's capacity for "immersive storytelling" that resonates globally. Known for blending grand visuals with character-driven narratives, Villeneuve employs tension-building techniques leading to impactful action sequences.

This suggests his Bond interpretation may align with the grittier tone of Daniel Craig's Casino Royale over Roger Moore's lighter approach. James Bond International Fan Club spokesperson Ajay Chowdhury hailed the appointment as the franchise's "most artistically significant development."

A long wait?

Production timing remains uncertain since Villeneuve will soon begin shooting Dune Messiah, anticipated for 2026 release. The director is attached to multiple projects including Nuclear War: A Scenario, Cleopatra, and Rendezvous with Rama—prompting him to admit, "I have too many things right now."

Villeneuve gained recognition through critically praised films like Sicario, Prisoners and Incendies before earning his first directing Oscar nomination for the sci-fi drama Arrival. His recent Dune films collectively grossed over $1 billion globally and received Best Picture Oscar nominations.

Who might play Bond?

As Daniel Craig's tenure ends, speculation intensifies regarding his successor. Chowdhury suggests casting requires a "Goldilocks amount of fame"—neither too established nor unknown. Potential candidates reportedly include British actors Aaron Taylor-Johnson and James Norton, plus Irish star Paul Mescal.

Chowdhury proposed other contenders meeting the criteria like Callum Turner, Joe Alwyn, and Jack Lowden, noting the next Bond must be young enough for long-term commitments while handling franchise activities including games and potential spin-offs. "Taking over from Daniel Craig will be no easy feat," he added.

fields.title: Space Marine 2 Adds Horde Mode and Thunder Hammer Simply Because It's 'Very Cool'
fields.summary: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2's latest free update introduces Siege Mode—a co-op horde survival experience against Tyranids and Chaos Marines—alongside a thunder hammer for the Bulwark class after developers decided adding it would be 'very cool.'
fields.content:
The newest content patch for Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 delivers Siege Mode, an endless wave-based combat challenge where three players fight together as Space Marines. Squad members navigate three sectors, complete side objectives between waves, upgrade equipment, and summon reinforcements including Imperial Guards or even the massive Dreadnought walker.

Every fifth wave triggers a boss battle against elite enemies, while surviving 15 waves unlocks the intense Endless Mode featuring heightened difficulty, scarcer resources, and faster-paced combat. As stated in the game lore, Ultramarines Primarch Roboute Guilliman acknowledges that "ultimate victory here is unlikely—but your bravery will echo through the halls of eternity."

Developer Saber Interactive improved Siege Mode's pacing following feedback, implementing session-wide timers that increase when clearing waves instead of imposing tight per-wave limits. In Endless Mode, enemy strength escalates faster to ensure players "die in fair combat rather than due to the timer," with plans to potentially eliminate timers entirely later.

While Siege Mode and its associated cosmetics are free for all players, the patch also offers premium cosmetic packs for chapters like White Scars and Blood Angels. A larger customization update allowing armor swapping between classes is in development though not included here.

The Bulwark class specifically receives a thunder hammer purely because "we think it will be very cool," according to the developers. Technical upgrades include Ray Traced Ambient Occlusion and DLSS4 support for NVIDIA's 50-series cards, alongside wide-ranging gameplay adjustments across all modes.

Space Marine 2 has surpassed seven million sales since launch, with publisher Games Workshop confirming plans for inevitable sequels. Ongoing content expansions will continue, including hidden content: "There are surprises even dataminers haven’t found out about."

fields.title: Starmer shifts tone to appease Labour MPs over welfare reforms
fields.summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer has altered his approach to win over Labour MPs rebelling against controversial welfare reforms, signaling a conciliatory tone amid party tensions. With key votes approaching, negotiations center on adjustments to disability and universal credit payments.
fields.content:
Prime Minister Keir Starmer faced intensified backlash after pledging on Wednesday to pursue contentious welfare reforms, further alienating Labour MPs. His immediate focus became repairing relations within his party.

A noticeable shift surfaced when Starmer acknowledged in Parliament that legislators across parties remain "eager" to overhaul Britain's "broken" benefits framework. He emphasized: "We want to see reform implemented with Labour values and fairness."

Talks with dissenting Labour MPs will advance before next week's critical vote on welfare legislation. The proposed bill would tighten eligibility for Personal Independence Payments (PIPs), halve Universal Credit's health component, and raise its standard allowance, targeting £5bn in annual savings by 2030.

Central to negotiations are PIPs criteria and reductions to health-related Universal Credit elements. Despite their sensitivity, the government prioritizes securing approval in Tuesday's vote.

This turmoil starkly contrasts with Labour's landslide election victory under a year ago. Recent dialogues reveal extraordinary acrimony among lawmakers, with accusations proliferating widely.

The rebellion reflects broad Labour discontent—spanning factions—over shrinking welfare protections. For many MPs, safeguarding this social safety net represents a sacred commitment.

Frustrations with No 10

Beyond policy disagreements, simmering frustrations about Downing Street's operations have amplified tensions. Many MPs feel their voices go unheard within Starmer's administration.

Criticism increasingly targets Chief of Staff Morgan McSweeney and Political Secretary Claire Reynolds for their handling of the welfare dispute. McSweeney, Starmer's second appointee to the role, succeeded Sue Gray after her brief three-month tenure.

The position itself originated with Jonathan Powell under Tony Blair. Powell now serves as Starmer's security advisor. However, one party insider dismissed criticisms of Starmer's team as misguided, stating: "He could hire Jonathan Powell as chief of staff, and it wouldn't compensate for the prime minister's deficient political judgment."

This episode highlights volatility in contemporary UK politics. Boris Johnson secured an 80-seat majority in 2019 yet confronted persistent challenges. Starmer achieved double that margin in 2024 but still faces profound crisis.

When questioned about this swift deterioration, a government minister responded: "This is the new reality of our volatile politics."

fields.title: Trump Urges Israel to End Netanyahu Corruption Case
fields.summary: Former U.S. President Donald Trump has publicly called for Israel to either pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu or dismiss his ongoing corruption trial, labeling the proceedings a 'witch hunt'. Netanyahu thanked Trump for his support, while Israeli opposition figures condemned the intervention in their judicial system.
fields.content:
Former U.S. President Donald Trump has urged Israel to grant Benjamin Netanyahu a pardon or terminate the corruption case against the Israeli leader, declaring the trial should be 'cancelled immediately'. In a social media post, Trump asserted that the U.S. had previously 'saved' Israel - referencing its role during Israel's conflict with Iran - and would now similarly 'save' Netanyahu from prosecution.

Netanyahu, who has denied all charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust since his trial began in 2020, responded with gratitude for what he called Trump's 'moving support' for both him and Israel. However, Israel's primary opposition leader, Yair Lapid, criticized Trump's remarks as inappropriate interference in an independent nation's legal processes.

Trump's statement comes shortly after he publicly admonished Israel for launching attacks against Iran following a U.S.-brokered ceasefire between the two nations after 12 days of missile exchanges. Netanyahu had earlier praised Trump for 'boldly' ordering strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities days before.

On his Truth Social platform, Trump described his longtime ally as a 'great hero' and 'warrior' who contributed significantly to Israel. He criticized Netanyahu's pending court appearance on Monday as part of a 'travesty of justice', comparing the situation to investigations into his own conduct in the U.S. Trump emphasized that he knew 'no one' who collaborated as harmoniously with him as Netanyahu.

Netanyahu pledged continued cooperation with Trump to 'defeat common enemies, free hostages, and expand peace'. Meanwhile, Lapid suggested Trump's intervention might be calculated to pressure Netanyahu regarding Gaza and hostage negotiations, telling Israeli media: 'I hope and suppose this is a reward he's giving Netanyahu because he's planning to pressure him into a hostage deal.'

The prime minister's corruption trial has faced multiple delays since the October 2023 Hamas attacks, with critics alleging Netanyahu seeks to prolong the Gaza conflict to avoid both elections and legal accountability.

fields.title: Met Police Officers Dismissed Over Child Q Strip-Search Scandal
fields.summary: Two Metropolitan Police officers were dismissed after an unjustified strip-search of a 15-year-old black schoolgirl known as Child Q at her Hackney school in 2020, which a disciplinary panel ruled amounted to gross misconduct. A third officer received a written warning as the incident sparked widespread outrage and exposed organizational failings in police procedures.
fields.content:
Two Metropolitan Police officers have been dismissed from duty after a disciplinary panel found them guilty of gross misconduct for conducting an unjustified strip-search of a 15-year-old girl. The incident occurred in December 2020 at the teenager's school in Hackney, east London, where the black pupil—identified only as Child Q—was forcibly searched without an appropriate adult present while menstruating.

Detective Constable Kristina Linge and PC Rafal Szmydynski were dismissed after the panel determined their actions were improper, disproportionate, and degrading. PC Victoria Wray received a final written warning for her involvement in the search, which stemmed from unfounded cannabis suspicions. The panel noted officers failed to obtain mandatory supervisor authorization and disregarded Child Q's vulnerability, age, and gender during the procedure.

Despite acknowledging that black schoolchildren are often perceived as older and less vulnerable than white peers, the panel rejected claims that racial bias directly influenced Child Q's treatment. Evidence revealed the teenager felt "demeaned" and "physically violated," with psychological trauma preventing her from testifying at the month-long hearing. A 2022 safeguarding review contradicted the panel by concluding racism was likely a factor.

'There's a level of fear'

The Independent Office for Police Conduct condemned the search as "completely disproportionate," especially given the negligible amount of suspected cannabis. Community members highlighted longstanding racial inequities, with activist Tanya Obeng stating, "There's a level of fear among black people regarding police that doesn't exist for white people." Protests erupted across London after the case details became public, including demonstrations featuring signs demanding justice outside BBC headquarters.

Local resident Sharon Adams expressed outrage over the violation, emphasizing the girl's powerlessness: "They already had that perception of her. She didn't have a voice." University of Greenwich professor Louise Owusu-Kwarteng described the automatic assumption of guilt as indicative of systemic racial biases affecting black students.

'Catalyst for change'

Met Commander Kevin Southworth issued a formal apology to Child Q and her family, acknowledging the incident exposed major organizational failures including insufficient officer training and lax oversight. "The experience should never have happened," he stated, confirming the case prompted nationwide reforms that have since reduced such searches. He described it as a "catalyst for change" while admitting these improvements should have been implemented earlier.

Children's Commissioner Rachel de Souza called the incident "shocking and profoundly disturbing," demanding that strip-searches only occur as an absolute last resort with robust safeguards. London's police force has revised policies following the scandal, with new rules enacted in May requiring automatic dismissal for gross misconduct.

fields.title: Ukrainian Army Halts Russian Offensive in Sumy Region, Says Military Chief
fields.summary: Ukraine's army commander General Oleksandr Syrskyi reports successful defense operations halting Russian advances in the northeastern Sumy region, though fortification gaps remain a critical vulnerability amid ongoing fighting.
fields.content:
Ukraine's military commander General Oleksandr Syrskyi announced his troops have stopped Russian offensive actions in the northeastern Sumy border region. During a Thursday frontline visit, he confirmed combat operations had been stabilized, describing Russia's summer advance as effectively choked off and prevented from making further gains.

However, Syrskyi cautioned that fortification inspections exposed urgent defensive needs in the region, acknowledging current barriers require significant improvement through stronger structures and anti-drone corridors. His assessment aligns with Ukrainian officials reporting reduced Russian pressure, though border guard spokesperson Andriy Demchenko characterized the situation as persistently volatile earlier this week.

Moscow heightened assaults following Ukrainian forces' 2023 incursion into Russia's Kursk region near Sumy, which President Vladimir Putin labeled an embarrassment. In April 2024, Putin ordered security buffer zones along Ukrainian border areas. Current intelligence indicates Russia amassed 50,000 troops at the Sumy frontier aiming to establish a 10km deep buffer zone according to President Volodymyr Zelensky.

Analysts from frontline monitoring group DeepState report Russian attacks targeting Sumy's unfortified sections, noting dangerously delayed constructions and inadequate defensive constructions. Ukrainian forces missed their optimal fortification period in autumn 2024 while holding positions in Kursk, leaving critical vulnerabilities now exploited by Russian troops who have launched deadly missile strikes killing dozens including 34 civilians in a single April attack.

Putin recently acknowledged substantial military presence in Sumy, claiming an 8-12km deep operational zone without explicitly ruling out capturing the region at a St. Petersburg summit. Russia's invasion continues into its fourth year amid escalating drone attacks overwhelming Ukrainian defenses.

International responses include NATO allies pledging €35 billion in military support, but Ukrainian leadership expresses concern over Donald Trump's potential weakening commitment to their cause. Though describing his meeting with Zelensky as pleasant, the US president stated Patriot missile system deliveries remain uncertain.

fields.title: Former Barclays CEO Loses Bid to Overturn Job Ban Over Epstein Links
fields.summary: Jes Staley, former Barclays chief executive, has failed to overturn a UK regulatory ban prohibiting him from holding top financial roles due to his relationship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The tribunal upheld the Financial Conduct Authority's decision while reducing his fine to £1.1 million.
fields.content:
Jes Staley has lost his legal challenge against a UK regulatory decision to bar him from senior financial positions after investigators found he misrepresented his connections with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The former Barclays CEO was removed from his role in November 2021 when the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) determined he inaccurately described his association with Epstein to both the bank's board and regulators in 2019.

Court Proceedings

Staley sought to overturn the FCA's 2023 ruling that banned him from the industry and imposed a £1.8 million fine, maintaining he "never attempted to conceal his relationship with Mr Epstein". London's Upper Tribunal rejected his appeal on Thursday but lowered the financial penalty to £1.1 million. During hearings, Staley testified that his association with Epstein was strictly professional rather than a personal friendship.

Epstein died by suicide in 2019 while imprisoned on sex trafficking charges, having previously served 13 months for soliciting sex from a minor in 2008. Staley asserted to the tribunal that he had no knowledge of Epstein's "monstrous activities". The former banker voiced disappointment in the verdict but welcomed the tribunal's acknowledgment that he wasn't found dishonest.

"I have worked tirelessly for my prior employers throughout my career," Staley stated. "I take pride in supporting numerous individuals during that time and in developing strategies that helped Barclays navigate significant challenges."

Nature of the Relationship

The case focused on a 2019 letter from Barclays chair Nigel Higgins to the FCA, which regulators claimed contained two false assertions: that Staley lacked a "close relationship" with Epstein and that their contact ended before he joined Barclays in 2015. The FCA argued Staley "recklessly" endorsed the letter despite not drafting it himself.

Staley countered that both statements were truthful, insisting his "close business relationship" with Epstein diminished after departing JPMorgan, where Epstein had been a client. Having spent three decades at the US bank — including leadership of its asset management division — Staley claimed his last in-person meeting with Epstein occurred in April 2015.

However, emails released by JPMorgan contradicted this account, revealing visits to Epstein's properties in New York and his private Caribbean island. Correspondence showed Staley describing Epstein as one of his "deepest" and "most cherished" friends. One notable exchange involved Staley writing, "That was fun, say 'Hi' to Snow White," with Epstein replying, "What character would you like next?" prompting Staley's response: "Beauty and the beast!". Additional emails confirmed contact between the two just days before Staley's Barclays CEO appointment was announced on October 28, 2015.

Staley has consistently denied awareness of Epstein's criminal conduct despite the documented communications.

fields.title: Warwickshire Council leader resigns, 18-year-old deputy takes temporary charge
fields.summary: Rob Howard, leader of Warwickshire County Council, has resigned after just 41 days citing health reasons, leaving his 18-year-old deputy George Finch as interim leader. The Reform UK politician stepped down as his party prepares to elect a successor to lead the minority administration.
fields.content:
The elected leader of Warwickshire County Council has resigned after only 41 days, handing temporary leadership to his 18-year-old deputy. Rob Howard of Reform UK announced his departure with "much regret," attributing it to health challenges preventing him from performing at his desired standard.

Howard had been elected in May when Reform UK achieved unprecedented local election success, becoming Warwickshire's largest party and forming a minority administration. His resignation places George Finch, Britain's youngest council deputy leader, as interim leader until a permanent successor is chosen.

Finch confirmed a leadership election would occur within a week, promising fair competition. Regarding his potential candidacy, he stated: "I haven't given it thought yet. It has been less than 24 hours and we have a lot to do. I am still doing the job as leader until we elect a new one."

'Mission remains unchanged'

The 18-year-old interim leader emphasized his priority is maintaining council operations: "We want to make sure the election process is fair. Let's see where we are in a week's time." He vowed to keep the council in "steady hands" while ensuring Reform UK's core mission "remained unchanged."

Rachel Taylor, Labour MP for North Warwickshire, expressed concern about the leadership change: "This is a real concern for constituents. We desperately need a functioning council to fill potholes, deliver care services and end the SEND education crisis."

Taylor questioned the administration's effectiveness, noting: "[These concerns] aren't helped by the council leader missing the first meeting for a Dominican Republic holiday or stating the council lacked specific policies." She urged Reform to elect a replacement swiftly to restore effective governance.

'Honoured and privileged'

Howard, who recently told media he felt "not intimidated" by managing the council's £1.5bn assets and £500m budget, will remain as a county councillor. He stated: "I am honoured and privileged to have held the role, even if briefly. I remain committed to working for Warwickshire residents."

Reform UK Warwickshire confirmed focus on policy implementation despite the resignation: "We're getting on with exploring our Pothole Renewal Plan to address 6,500 potholes, create apprenticeships, and improve SEND provisions."

Finch had previously spent three months as a Conservative before switching parties over immigration policy. His political stance centers on "Brexit, sovereignty and a strong family unit," according to his online profile.

fields.title: NHS England Launches Strict GP Prescriptions for Weight Loss Drug Mounjaro
fields.summary: Mounjaro weight loss injections become available through GP surgeries in England under stringent eligibility criteria, with NHS England implementing a phased rollout to prioritize high-risk patients while addressing capacity constraints and workload concerns.
fields.content:
Prescriptions for the weight loss injection Mounjaro are now available through GP surgeries in England, but only for patients meeting specific clinical criteria. NHS England emphasizes this staggered approach prioritizes those most in need while managing healthcare resources. The weekly drug induces feelings of fullness to reduce food intake, potentially helping users lose up to 20% of their body weight. Doctors warn of insufficient staffing to handle widespread demand, urging only eligible individuals to seek prescriptions.

The medication, also known as tirzepatide, was initially approved for type 2 diabetes treatment before receiving authorization for obesity management. Its rollout represents a significant development in addressing weight-related health concerns through pharmaceutical intervention.

Who qualifies initially?

Eligibility focuses on high-risk patients, though precise criteria remain strict. Qualified recipients will receive combined support including regular health monitoring, exercise guidance, and nutritional counseling. Not all general practices will directly administer prescriptions, with some relying on community clinics instead. Dr. Claire Fuller, NHS England's co-national medical director for primary care, stated: "This will make a significant difference to lives of people living with obesity and severe ill health."

However, many GP surgeries indicate few patients currently qualify, requesting patience during service setup. Professor Kamila Hawthorne of the Royal College of General Practitioners cautioned: "We are over-burdened already and lack sufficient workforce." She advised against unsolicited GP requests, stressing safety over unregulated online purchases.

Implementation barriers

Industry experts anticipate supply limitations despite demand. Malcolm Harrison of the Company Chemists' Association noted: "GP provision alone is unlikely to meet patient demand," despite the drug's transformative potential. Additional complexities include mandatory staff training, monthly patient check-ups during initial treatment, and current exclusions for pregnant/breastfeeding individuals or those with pancreatitis or specific thyroid tumor histories. Potential side effects require professional consultation before prescription.

Alternative access points

Specialist NHS weight-loss clinics have provided Mounjaro since March. Wegovy (semaglutide), another similar injection, remains accessible through these centers. Both medications can also be obtained privately. Dr. Fuller reiterated that not everyone qualifies: "Discuss NHS support options with healthcare professionals if concerned about weight-related health impacts."

Future eligibility expansion

NHS England projects approximately 220,000 individuals will access Mounjaro over three years through gradual rollout phases. A future evaluation by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) will determine broader availability, potentially extending eligibility to around 3.4 million people within 12 years.

UK-wide disparities

Access varies significantly across the UK. Wales currently offers Mounjaro through specialist services while considering primary care integration. Northern Ireland plans to introduce regional obesity management with medications available over coming years. In Scotland, health authorities report minimal current prescriptions, with decisions delegated to local health boards.

fields.title: Apprenticeships in the UK: Pay, Pathways and Policy Changes
fields.summary: New funding restrictions for older apprentices in England and minimum wage increases reshape opportunities. This guide explains apprenticeship structures, payment rates across UK nations, application processes, and challenges including 50% dropout rates.
fields.content:
The UK government will stop funding postgraduate apprenticeships for people aged over 22 in England from next year. Officials say the funds will instead support lower-level training programs. The changes come alongside increased apprentice minimum wages implemented since April.

With apprenticeship dropout rates hovering near 50% and ongoing concerns about low pay levels, prospective candidates face important considerations when evaluating this career pathway.

Understanding apprenticeships

Apprentices typically work four days weekly while dedicating one day to studying for a qualification through their workplace, college, university or online platforms. Participants receive a salary, and the government along with employers cover all qualification costs.

Since April 2023, small businesses receive full government funding when hiring apprentices aged 21 or younger. All UK employers must ensure apprentices work alongside experienced staff and receive adequate study time. Apprenticeships operate at different levels:

Beginning in January, only those aged 16-21 and existing apprentices will qualify for Level 7 (postgraduate equivalent) funding in England.

Apprenticeship salaries

Apprentices under age 19, or those in their first year regardless of age, currently receive £7.55 per hour. Other apprentices must earn at least the national minimum wage applicable to their age group.

Participation trends

Individuals often pursue apprenticeships when targeting specific careers or seeking advancement in their current field.

England recorded 736,500 apprenticeships last year, with advanced apprenticeships being most popular. Higher-level apprenticeships show rising enrollment, while 23% of new apprentices in 2023-2024 were under 19.

Securing an apprenticeship

Prospective applicants can approach employers directly or search official portals including England's centralized application system. UCAS also lists vacancies and plans to enable direct applications.

Candidates undergo interviews before starting and must pass final assessments. Health/public services and business sectors saw the highest apprentice intake in 2022-2023. Major employers include the British military, civil service, and Mitchells & Butlers hospitality group.

Apprenticeship challenges

Only 60.5% of apprentices completed their programs successfully in England during 2023-2024, falling short of the government's 67% target.

A 2022 Department for Education report revealed 40% of non-completions resulted from personal situations like career changes or health issues, while another 40% cited inadequate training time or poor program management.

Factors like low pay, travel costs, and required numeracy qualifications also hindered participation. Recent policy changes now give businesses discretion over math and English requirements for over-19s and will shorten minimum apprenticeship durations from 12 to 8 months starting August 2025.

Evaluating suitability

Prospects should consider the apprenticeship's career relevance, location, salary, duration, and progression opportunities. Researching employer training programs and reading apprentice reviews on platforms like RateMyApprenticeship.co.uk provides crucial insights before committing.

fields.title: World's oldest boomerang discovered in Poland wasn't designed to return
fields.summary: A 40,000-year-old boomerang carved from mammoth ivory, discovered in a Polish cave, represents the world's oldest known throwing implement of its type. Researchers confirm this prehistoric tool wouldn't return to its thrower and was likely used for hunting.
fields.content:
The world's oldest boomerang, found in southern Poland, is significantly older than previously thought, revealing advanced ancient skills. This unique artifact dates between 39,000 and 42,000 years old.

Excavated in 1985 at Oblazowa Cave, the tool was originally estimated at 30,000 years old. More precise radiocarbon dating of nearby bones has now established its true age as approximately 40,000 years old.

Crafted from mammoth tusk with extraordinary precision, archaeological analysis shows the boomerang would fly effectively when thrown but was not designed to circle back to the user. University of Bologna researcher Dr. Sahra Talamo notes: "It's the oldest boomerang in the world" and offers "remarkable insight" into early human behavior. Remarkable preservation reveals polish marks indicating right-handed craftsmanship.

Contrary to common associations with Australian Aboriginal culture, the artifact emphasizes boomerangs' broader historical use. Comparable discoveries include a 10,500-year-old wooden boomerang from Australia and a 7,000-year-old find in Denmark's Jutland region. A returning oak boomerang dating back 2,000 years has previously been uncovered in the Netherlands.

This research, published in PLOS One by a European team, represents the only known boomerang of this shape and size from Poland. Archaeologists suggest it likely served hunting purposes, though ritualistic use remains possible.

fields.title: Meta acknowledges wrongful Facebook Group suspensions but denies widespread issue
fields.summary: Meta confirms a technical error caused some Facebook Groups to be incorrectly suspended due to faulty AI enforcement, but denies systemic problems. Thousands of users have signed petitions alleging unwarranted account bans across Facebook and Instagram.
fields.content:
Meta says it is correcting a technical malfunction that led to the erroneous suspension of Facebook Groups while denying broader platform-wide issues. Group administrators reported receiving automated messages falsely claiming policy violations had occurred, triggering deletions of their communities.

Similar complaints emerged from Instagram users who blamed flaws in Meta's artificial intelligence systems. One prominent meme-sharing group about software bugs with over 680,000 members was wrongly accused of promoting "dangerous organizations or individuals" before being reinstated.

An administrator of an AI-focused group with 3.5 million members described temporary suspensions of both the community and personal account, with Meta later admitting: "Our technology made a mistake."

Thousands of signatures

Nearly 22,000 people signed a petition titled "Meta wrongfully disabling accounts with no human customer support" protesting abrupt bans. Reddit threads feature numerous reports of suspended accounts, including those containing irreplaceable personal memories and business-critical pages.

Some users claimed suspensions resulted from mistaken child exploitation policy violations, attributing errors to AI moderation. Meta stated: "We take action on accounts that violate our policies, and people can appeal if they think we've made a mistake," maintaining no significant spike in wrongful enforcement exists.

Instagram's policy notes AI is "central to our content review process," automatically removing violating content with human review in select cases. Accounts face immediate disablement for severe breaches like child exploitation material.

Meta's latest transparency report recorded 4.6 million actions against child sexual exploitation from January to March 2024, the lowest since early 2021. Policies cover both real children and AI-generated or fictional depictions. The company also uses AI to flag suspicious behavior, such as adults receiving teen complaints or searching harmful terms, potentially restricting contact with minors or deleting accounts.

fields.title: Defense Secretary Hegseth defends US strikes on Iran during pivotal briefing
fields.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth presented intelligence evidence to defend the effectiveness of US airstrikes against Iranian nuclear facilities while harshly criticizing American media coverage, aiming to sway public opinion amid political pressure from the White House.
fields.content:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth approached the Pentagon podium with dual objectives on Thursday: counteracting preliminary reports suggesting limited success in US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities, while launching a pointed critique against media outlets he deemed unpatriotic. His briefing targeted shifting divided public opinion and addressing strong White House concerns about news coverage.

Presenting evidence of impact

Hegseth provided intelligence assessments challenging the defensive evaluation, reading a CIA letter from Director John Ratcliffe stating a credible source confirmed multiple Iranian nuclear facilities were destroyed and required years-long reconstruction. Supplementary evidence included recent Israeli intelligence findings, Iranian leadership statements, and initial International Atomic Energy Agency reports indicating extensive damage.

Joint Chiefs Chair General Dan Caine elaborated on weapon capabilities, detailing how precisely targeted bunker-buster bombs repeatedly struck ventilation systems at Iran's Fordo facility. Hegseth implored Americans to assess outcomes objectively: "Anyone with two eyes, ears and a brain can recognize... devastating effect." He asserted: "This was a historically successful attack."

Targeting media coverage

The defense secretary pivoted to condemn US media coverage, characterizing reports as rooted in bias against the administration. "It's in your DNA," he contended, suggesting journalists prioritized political opposition over national interests. His remarks immediately drew presidential approval, with former President Donald Trump celebrating on Truth Social: "One of the greatest, most professional News Conferences I have ever seen!"

Political stakes and public opinion

The aggressive public stance addressed urgent political concerns, as final battle assessments require extended intelligence review while public perception solidifies rapidly. Current polling indicates dwindling support for Trump along with pre-strike skepticism about US involvement in Iran-Israel conflicts. Post-attack surveys reveal partisan divides, with strong Republican endorsement contrasted by most Democrats and independents believing the operation reduced US security.

Administration officials recognize a verifiable success could provide Trump with a critical political boost and foreign policy achievement. This understanding drove immediate declarations that Iran's nuclear program was "obliterated" before full assessments materialized. Critics weaponized the preliminary damage report against these claims, highlighting the administration's race against time to define the narrative.

fields.title: The Magical Thursday Opening of Glastonbury Festival
fields.summary: Glastonbury co-organiser Emily Eavis shares insights about the festival's unique Thursday atmosphere, describing the palpable excitement as crowds arrive to create communal magic before the main music begins.
fields.content:
The Thursday Energy

When DJing at Glastonbury last year, one striking observation emerged: the unique charged atmosphere on Thursday as crowds poured in. This wasn't just anticipation but an almost tangible release of tension — a shared moment when festival-goers finally arrived after months of waiting.

Emily Eavis, who helps run the festival started by her parents, describes this sensation as central to the Glastonbury experience. She personally oversees the Wednesday gate opening: "It's like letting people into Christmas in a way... musical Christmas." By Thursday afternoon, when the site reaches full capacity, she notes: "There's a palpable feeling of excitement, anticipation... a feeling of community and big gangs of friends reuniting."

Roots of the Festival

The iconic event began in 1970 as the Pilton Pop, Folk and Blues Festival in Michael Eavis' fields. With performers like Marc Bolan playing alongside dairy cows, Michael initially joked it was "the quickest way of clearing my overdraft". While the scale transformed dramatically, Emily notes the enduring spirit: "The look in their eyes remains cheer, determination, joy, excitement, and kind of magic. They're trying to make these five days the best of their life."

Capturing the Moment

Returning this year as both attendee and Thursday DJ, the writer is recreating that opening energy through music. Collaborating with BBC Radio 1's Greg James, listeners' voice messages about their Glastonbury arrival feelings were collected. DJ Crissy Criss then transformed these emotions into a track sampling both listener clips and Emily Eavis' interview.

This musical tribute aims to embody the collective spirit described by one participant: "You set yourself up, you've got your drink. Life is good. You are where you're meant to be" — echoing Emily's vision of attendees creating "the best five days of their life."

fields.title: Hitman 3 Cost 80% Less Than Predecessor by Reusing Assets, Reveals IO Interactive CEO
fields.summary: IO Interactive CEO Hakan Abrak explains how strategic asset reuse - including stopping the practice of creating new toilet models for every game - enabled Hitman 3 to be developed at just 20% of Hitman 2016's budget while achieving higher review scores, cementing the studio's sustainable development philosophy.
fields.content:
After securing independence from Square Enix in 2017, Hitman developer IO Interactive has thrived in the competitive AAA games industry through disciplined development strategies. CEO Hakan Abrak revealed that pivotal 'toilet discipline' - eliminating wasteful asset creation - helped slash budgets across the World of Assassination trilogy.

Reflecting on inefficient practices during Hitman: Absolution's 2012 development, Abrak stated: 'I swore never to do more new toilets. We were just doing new everything as throwaway content.' This realization led to the creation of IO's foundational 'brick system' for Hitman 2016, enabling asset repurposing across sequels.

Trilogy Budgets and Critical Success

Abrak disclosed the dramatic budget reductions: 'If Hitman 2016 was $100 million, Hitman 2 was maybe $60 million. Hitman 3 was $20 million.' Remarkably, this efficiency correlated with improved reviews, with the final entry scoring 87 on Metacritic - the highest in the trilogy - proving that resourcefulness didn't compromise quality.

The studio will apply these principles to its upcoming James Bond project, 007: First Light. Abrak acknowledged this 'more ambitious product' represents a larger investment but will maintain focus on asset longevity, enabling potential sequels without redundant development.

Sustainable Growth Philosophy

IO's fiscal restraint proved crucial during industry turbulence, with Abrak noting they deliberately avoided overexpansion during the COVID-era 'gold rush' that caused widespread layoffs. 'We could have grown more or taken on extra projects, but chose to align growth with our established culture and expertise,' he explained.

This emphasis on sustainable practices allows the 200-person studio to maintain creative independence while delivering acclaimed titles without corporate backing, setting a benchmark for efficient AAA development.

fields.title: UK Bioethanol Plant Faces Closure After U.S. Tariff Deal
fields.summary: Associated British Foods has threatened to close its Vivergo bioethanol facility in Hull unless the government provides financial support, following a new trade agreement that removes tariffs on U.S. ethanol imports. The move risks 150 jobs at the UK's largest bioethanol plant and jeopardizes the nation's sustainable fuel targets.
fields.content:
Associated British Foods has announced potential closure plans for its Vivergo bioethanol facility in Hull, citing insufficient government support after a new U.S.-UK trade deal. The company will begin consultations with its 150 staff members about an orderly shutdown of operations.

The threat comes after the UK removed a 19% import tariff on American ethanol under the bilateral agreement, replacing it with a tax-free quota allowing up to 1.4 billion liters of imports. This volume represents the entirety of the UK's ethanol market, undermining domestic producers like Vivergo.

Industry Reactions

Business officials expressed disappointment at AB Foods' decision despite ongoing government negotiations about financial support that began on June 25. Ensus, the UK's only other bioethanol producer located in Teesside, also warned its German-owned facility faces potential shutdown due to this trade agreement's market impact.

For months, AB Foods has lobbied the government about competing against subsidized U.S. ethanol, which receives tax credits and agricultural support. The tariff elimination particularly benefits farmers in key U.S. states like Iowa and Nebraska, crucial support bases for President Donald Trump.

Economic Consequences

The company issued an ultimatum requiring short-term funding to cover losses and lasting solutions to prevent manufacturing cessation by September 13. This announcement coincided with the government unveiling new trade measures designed to protect UK industries from cheap imports.

Labour MP Karl Turner warned that losing domestic ethanol capacity would severely hinder the UK's net zero ambitions while devastating Hull communities. The bioethanol sector supports approximately 4,000 jobs nationwide including wheat farmers, with Vivergo halting crop purchases since June 11.

As the Department of Business recruits external consultants to evaluate potential support measures, a spokesperson pledged commitment to protecting supply chains and jobs. The government aims for 10% sustainable aviation fuels by 2030, but plant closures could make Britain entirely dependent on overseas ethanol suppliers.

fields.title: Reform UK Proposes Public Petitions to Challenge Prison Sentences
fields.summary: Reform UK's Richard Tice introduces legislation allowing public petitions to dispute criminal sentences through the Criminal Cases Review Commission, aiming to boost confidence in justice, despite government dismissal of the plan.
fields.content:
Reform UK deputy leader Richard Tice has proposed new legislation enabling public intervention in criminal sentencing decisions. Under the plan, 500 petition signatures could trigger a Criminal Cases Review Commission (CCRC) assessment of sentences perceived as unjustly harsh or lenient.

Tice argued this mechanism would create a "treble check safeguard" within the justice system. "Even noble, experienced, wise judges can get things wrong," he told MPs, suggesting public participation would increase confidence in judicial fairness without undermining original verdicts.

The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) stated it is not formally considering the proposal. An MoJ spokesperson highlighted existing appeal options: defendants can challenge sentences through the Court of Appeal, while any citizen can refer potentially lenient sentences to the attorney general.

The Lucy Connolly Case

Tice specifically referenced Lucy Connolly's case in his parliamentary speech. Connolly received a 31-month prison sentence in October after pleading guilty to inciting racial hatred through social media posts calling for 'mass deportation' and suggesting asylum seeker accommodations be set ablaze.

Her post was reposted 940 times and viewed 310,000 times before deletion after 3.5 hours. Connolly lost an appeal against her sentence in May, which Tice characterized as disproportionate compared to punishments for physical crimes like shoplifting or robbery.

CCRC Performance Concerns

The proposal relies on the CCRC, an independent body currently under scrutiny for operational shortcomings. Interim chair Dame Vera Baird recently stated the commission remains "incapable of learning from mistakes" and pledged cultural reforms.
