Jewish attendees reported feeling unsafe enough to hide their identities at the event. One described the environment as unwelcoming despite the festival's inclusive ethos, noting 'there's a difference if you're a Jew'. This tension highlighted contrary perspectives among the audience itself.

Criticism focused on whether the network adequately prepared for potential incidents despite thorough due diligence. Organizational focus on Kneecap may have diverted attention from risks posed by Vylan, revealing how intense scrutiny of one potential controversy can obscure emerging issues nearby.

PA Media Bob Vylan crowd surfs during his performance.

The broadcaster acknowledged reacting too slowly during Vylan's set and expressed regret. Though the contentious remarks came late, the stream continued until removal from on-demand services. New guidance is now being developed for internal teams regarding acceptable broadcast decisions during live events.

Despite complicating factors like artistic expression rights and widespread pro-Palestinian sentiment among attendees, incitement to violence remains separate from protected political speech. This episode amplifies existing challenges regarding the broadcaster's previous editorial choices about Gaza coverage.

While the performers initiated the controversial comments, responsibility lies with both the festival allowing the sets and the publicly-funded network distributing them. This incident mirrors national tensions about Middle East conflicts while sparking wider debates about free speech limitations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Colin Allred Launches 2026 Senate Bid After Texas Loss to Cruz
fields.summary: Democratic former Representative Colin Allred announced his 2026 Senate campaign targeting Texas Republicans John Cornyn and Ken Paxton, just eight months after losing to Ted Cruz in a $130 million race. The NFL-turned-politician vowed to fight corruption while highlighting his personal story.
fields.content:
Texas Democrat Colin Allred announced his entry into the 2026 Senate race Tuesday, launching another campaign just months after his costly defeat against Republican incumbent Ted Cruz. Democrats invested over $130 million in Allred's unsuccessful 2024 challenge, which concluded eight months ago. In his campaign video, Allred criticized Senator John Cornyn—whose seat opens in 2026—and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, describing them as "too corrupt to care about us and too weak to fight for us."

A former NFL linebacker and attorney, Allred shared personal experiences about overcoming rejection as an undrafted player before eventually earning a professional contract. "I worked harder than anybody and finally made it to the pros—and bought my mom a house," Allred recounted while contrasting his path with economic barriers facing ordinary citizens.

Colin Allred

"The truth is you shouldn't have to have a son in the NFL to own a home," he emphasized. "Everything is backwards. Folks who play by the rules and keep the faith just can’t seem to get ahead. But the folks who cut corners and cut deals—well, they’re doing just fine." Allred pledged to center his campaign on an anti-corruption platform, recalling his congressional record: "I know Washington is broken. The system is rigged. In six years in Congress, I never took a dime of corporate PAC money, never traded a single stock."

Ted Cruz shows his gratitude as he crosses his hands over his heart as he speaks at a watch party during the 2024 election

Former NASA astronaut Terry Virts has also joined the 2026 Texas Senate contest as a Democratic candidate, setting up a competitive primary for the open seat.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Expert Advice: Choosing the Healthiest Breads to Avoid Inflammation and Sugar Spikes
fields.summary: Nutrition specialists analyze various bread types' health impacts, explaining why ultraprocessed options cause issues while recommending whole-grain and sourdough alternatives to reduce inflammation and stabilize blood sugar.
fields.content:
Joe Rogan on Avoiding Bread and the Exception

Popular podcaster Joe Rogan attributes dietary inflammation to problematic bread consumption, stating: "Our bread is f----d — if you go overseas and eat bread in Italy, you won’t feel bad at all." Rogan shared content from holistic health influencer Dennis Echelbarger suggesting bread often causes bloating, brain fog, and fatigue. Echelbarger contends gluten is "just the scapegoat," blaming instead "ultraprocessed, chemically altered, bleached, bromated, fake vitamin-filled wheat soaked in glyphosate." Rogan confirmed eliminating such bread yielded significant benefits but made an exception for sourdough, calling it "great for you," and recommended sourcing "heirloom wheat" – unmodified heritage varieties with higher nutritional value.

The Ideal Ingredient List

Dietitian Erin Palinski-Wade notes bread's health impacts vary dramatically: "There’s a wide range of breads — from those that negatively impact health to options offering potential benefits." She advises choosing whole-grain, high-fiber breads for slower digestion and better blood sugar management. When evaluating products, she emphasizes: "The first ingredient should be a whole grain... The shorter the ingredient list, the better." Ideal formulations include whole grains, yeast, minimal salt, limited sugars, and few preservatives. Palinski-Wade endorses Ezekiel bread (sprouted grains and legumes) and Dave’s Killer Bread (organic whole grains) as top store-bought choices with minimal processing. Julie Stefanski, RDN spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition & Dietetics, cautions against universally condemning bread but recommends whole-grain versions for frequent consumers, noting simpler-ingredient loaves may require freezing to prevent spoilage.

Man slicing bread

Woman shopping for bread

Is Sourdough Really Better?

Stefanski explains sourdough's benefits: "A lower glycemic index means the bread digests and turns into blood sugar slightly slower than typical white bread." The fermentation process partially breaks down wheat carbohydrates, potentially reducing bloating and digestive issues for sensitive individuals. While Palinski-Wade agrees sourdough is a good option, she asserts it’s "not superior" and recognizes homemade versions may be impractical for busy lifestyles. Stefanski elaborates that the natural bacteria and yeast in sourdough starters alter carbohydrate structures, decreasing the post-consumption glycemic response compared to conventional breads.

Sourdough bread

Avoiding the Sugar Spike

Dr. Jason Fung attributes rapid glucose conversion in commercial white bread to its texture: "The flour is very refined... and is very finely machine ground. This fine grind creates white flour dust quickly absorbed by intestinal cells." Texturizers and emulsifiers expedite digestion further, contributing to white bread’s high glycemic index (GI) of 73 and whole wheat’s 70. Fung recommends alternatives like stone-ground whole wheat, sprouted grain, sourdough, or homemade bread alongside pairing techniques: "Eat bread with olive oil and vinegar." Palinski-Wade concurs, noting strategic pairings with fats, proteins, or fiber help minimize blood sugar spikes.

Breakfast close-up with hands, bread and butter

Glycemix index

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Mom's Clever Airplane Seat Hack Sparks Traveler Debate
fields.summary: A mother's tactical maneuver to secure an entire row of airplane seats by waiting until departure has ignited online discussion about travel etiquette on United Airlines flights.
fields.content:
A resourceful mother demonstrated an advanced travel tactic during a United Airlines flight that led to both admiration and criticism from fellow passengers. According to a Reddit eyewitness posting in the "r/unitedairlines" forum, the woman persistently monitored seat availability through the airline's app until claiming a vacant row.

The observer initially speculated the family was waiting for a Polaris class upgrade but noticed they were closely tracking empty seats. Row 9 appeared completely unoccupied several hours before departure. "They're watching the seating chart like hawks," the user wrote, recognizing the family intended to commandeer the row if it remained empty after boarding.

The strategy succeeded once the aircraft doors closed and boarding finalized. The family swiftly moved into the unclaimed row, exchanging celebratory high-fives. "Well played, mom," commented the Reddit poster who documented the incident with the title "Seat Shenanigans - advanced tactics."

Little girl playing games on cell phone while traveling by plane with her mother.

Online reactions revealed sharply divided opinions when the story spread across social media. One user insisted: "I really think people should sit in the seats they paid for." Others highlighted potential consequences, noting "Some FA’s will enforce the walk of shame" referring to flight attendants requiring passengers to return to original seats.

Several commenters supported the family's approach: "I don’t see the issue. They waited until doors closed and knew they might be moved. It’s fine." Another recounted witnessing flight attendants confronting opportunistic seat-changers: "They told him to pay for the exit row he invited himself to or go back." A third added: "You gotta admire their strategy. Not something I would do, but wow."

Interior of a crowded airplane with blue seats showing passengers sat, pictured from behind.

The Reddit poster provided historical context about such seat-swapping tactics, reminiscing: "You used to be able to take any open seat post-boarding. People would move forward for aisle seats or recline in empty back rows." This reflection highlights evolving airline policies that increasingly restrict spontaneous seat changes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Imane Khelif Shares Defiant Message As IOC Vows Fairness Review
fields.summary: Olympic boxing champion Imane Khelif posted an inspirational message after winning gold amid gender eligibility questions, while International Olympic Committee president Kirsty Coventry announced plans to review policies to protect fairness in women's sports.
fields.content:
Algerian boxer Imane Khelif shared a determined message following her controversial gold medal victory in the women's boxing event at the Paris Olympics. Amid ongoing debate about gender eligibility in sports, Khelif posted on her Instagram Stories: "Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts." This came after she won Olympic gold despite previously failing gender-eligibility tests in international competitions.

Imane Khelif looks on

IOC's Commitment to Fairness

International Olympic Committee President Kirsty Coventry pledged action to ensure competitive fairness following discussions about gender eligibility. "We understand that there'll be differences depending on the sport," Coventry stated, "but it was very clear from the members that we have to protect the female category, first and foremost to ensure fairness." She emphasized that changes would be guided by scientific research and collaboration with international sports federations.

Coventry noted "unanimous" IOC support for establishing new guidelines, possibly modeling policies after World Athletics' standards which restrict transgender women who underwent male puberty from competing in female categories. "It was very clear from the membership the discussion around this has to be done with medical and scientific research at the core," Coventry explained, acknowledging that policies may vary by sport.

Imane Khelif with a coach

The IOC president indicated that any policy changes would not affect past competition results. At the Paris Games, Khelif and another boxer won women's gold medals despite previous gender-eligibility test failures. Coventry stated the IOC would take a "leading role" in establishing consensus but confirmed that historical outcomes would remain unchanged.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Brain-Computer Interface Restores Speech and Song to Paralyzed Man
fields.summary: University of California researchers have developed an AI-powered brain-computer interface that restores real-time speech capabilities to individuals with paralysis. The system translates neural signals into spoken words and song while preserving the user's original voice, achieving unprecedented naturalness in communication.
fields.content:
Transforming Lives Through Neural Technology

Losing speech capacity due to neurological conditions like ALS profoundly impacts every aspect of existence, from social interactions to basic daily needs. A research team at the University of California, Davis, has created an innovative brain-computer interface (BCI) that enables real-time natural conversation for speech-impaired individuals. Unlike text-based systems, this technology interprets brain signals intended for speech muscles, allowing users to communicate verbally and even sing through a computer with near-instantaneous response times.

Decoding Speech in Real-Time

The system relies on four microelectrode arrays surgically implanted in the brain region responsible for speech production. These devices detect neural activity generated when a person attempts to speak and transmit signals to an AI decoder that converts them into audible speech within just ten milliseconds. Crucially, the technology recreates the individual's authentic voice using a cloning algorithm trained on pre-ALS recordings.

Beyond standard conversation, the BCI recognizes song attempts and adjusts vocal pitch to match melodies. It also captures nuanced communication elements like interrogative tones, verbal emphasis, and emotional interjections such as "aah" or "ooh." This level of expressiveness significantly surpasses previous assistive communication devices.

Artificial intelligence translates neural signals into vocal expressions instantly

Technology Behind Voice Recovery

During trials, participants attempted to speak sentences displayed on screens while electrodes recorded firing patterns from numerous neurons. AI algorithms mapped these neural signatures to corresponding sounds, reconstructing speech with precise control over rhythm, tone, and inflection. This allows natural conversational elements like interruptions or emphasized words.,

The study revealed that listeners understood almost sixty percent of synthesized words, compared to just four percent comprehension without the BCI. The system also successfully decoded entirely new words not included in training data, demonstrating remarkable adaptability.

AI model converts brain patterns into audible speech continuously

Revolutionizing Daily Communication

Real-time vocal restoration fundamentally transforms social inclusion for people with paralysis. Investigators at UC Davis emphasize this technology's advantages over earlier text-based systems, which often produced stilted, time-delayed exchanges. Users can now participate dynamically in conversations with authentic personal expression.

BCI enables natural social interaction for speech-impaired users

Neurosurgeon Dr. David Brandman, part of the research team, stressed the profound personal significance: "Our voice forms core to our identity. This innovation offers genuine hope for recovering this essential aspect of selfhood."

Development Path Forward

While results appear highly promising, researchers caution that the technology remains in early development. Following testing with a single participant, the system requires validation across individuals with varying speech-loss causes like stroke. The ongoing BrainGate2 clinical trial at UC Davis Health continues enrolling participants to refine and expand the technology.

Researchers emphasize this neurotechnology represents initial progress

Significance of the Advancement

Restoring natural expressive speech stands as a landmark achievement in brain-computer interfaces. UC Davis's breakthrough offers paralyzed individuals real-time communication using their original vocal identity, reconnecting them profoundly with loved ones. Though additional research is needed, this innovation shows significant promise for enhancing personal engagement and life quality.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Fire & Redemption: An Inmate Firefighter's Journey to Freedom
fields.summary: Fausto Lopez, sentenced to 7 years at 16, found redemption battling California's historic wildfires as an incarcerated firefighter. His bravery on fire lines and academic achievements earned him early release to pursue medical studies, turning a life marked by tragedy into a story of second chances.
fields.content:
At just 20 years old, Fausto Lopez joined thousands of firefighters combating the devastating Los Angeles wildfires - some of California's most destructive blazes. Amid swirling black smoke and fierce Santa Ana winds in January 2025, he fought not just flames but for personal redemption. Climbing a smoky Altadena mountain with his crew, Fausto witnessed neighborhoods transformed into graveyards of charred cars, glowing living rooms resembling lava, and palm trees turned to torches - over 34,000 acres already consumed.

"Damn," murmured Fausto, mesmerized by the apocalyptic scene. Wearing his orange uniform and 50-pound pack, he'd battled dozens of fires but never destruction on this scale - 12,000 structures ultimately destroyed, 30 lives lost. As he cleared vegetation to starve the advancing Eaton Fire, Fausto knew this mission represented more than containment: it was his pathway to freedom after sentencing for a 2021 felony involving a fatal shootout.

A turning point behind bars

Convicted at 16 for second-degree murder after a gang-related incident left two dead, Fausto served time at Alan M. Crogan Youth Treatment Center. The wake-up call came when he saw death firsthand: "When you see death happen in front of your face, it changes everything." After his father's passing during incarceration, Fausto focused on education, earning his high school diploma then becoming the facility's first associate degree graduate through Riverside City College.

Mentor Carlos Cervantes observed Fausto's transformation: "He had the drive. The mindset." When offered placement in California's inmate firefighter program, Fausto accepted despite uncertainty - seeing an opportunity to earn time credits toward early release from his seven-year sentence. This 108-year-old program employs approximately 1,800 low-security inmates across 35 camps during fire season.

Baptism by fire

At Pine Grove Conservation Camp in Sierra Nevada foothills, Fausto endured rigorous training - hiking in ill-fitting size 13 boots that bloodied his feet. "I don't want to quit," he insisted through the pain. His persistence paid off when he joined fire crews battling blazes across California. The work proved brutal: 24-hour shifts sleeping on charred ground, drinking a quart of water hourly to avoid dehydration, and facing temperatures exceeding 100°F during record-breaking heat waves.

Fausto learned to identify heat types - radiant, convection, and conduction - as flames sometimes lashed his cheeks. His crew created vital firebreaks by hand, clearing 300 feet of brush per hour without machinery. When the historic Palisades and Eaton fires erupted near his hometown in January 2025, Fausto's crew deployed immediately. "We're leaving!" they shouted, embarking on the seven-hour journey to Altadena where over 1,000 incarcerated firefighters joined the battle.

Flames of transformation

During rest periods at the Rose Bowl base camp, Fausto received life-changing news from mentor Michael Griggs. His re-entry plan had been approved - probation officials supported his college admission after reviewing his academic record. "You're going to college," Griggs told the stunned firefighter, who still wore his CDC prisoner uniform. Cervantes watched in awe: "A person getting ready to be released still on the front lines, risking his life."

Nine days into firefighting, a judge approved Fausto's immediate release. He arrived at Cal State San Bernardino carrying his possessions in a black plastic bag. Now majoring in biology, Fausto takes courses in human ecology, philosophy, and rock history while training for basketball tryouts. "He's exactly where he needs to be," says Griggs. "It represents what second chances look like."

Reflecting on his fire crewmate Gonzalo's definition of identity - "I'm a man of business" - Fausto embraces his own purpose: "I'm here and I've got to do things right and make amends. Now I'm trying to be who I am." His journey from incarceration to education, marked by blistered feet amidst the flames, demonstrates that even in destruction, renewal can take root.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: M&S Eyes Full Online Recovery Within Four Weeks After Cyber Attack
fields.summary: Marks & Spencer expects to fully restore online services including click-and-collect within four weeks as recovery progresses after an April cyber attack that halted half its digital operations. The incident caused significant profit losses and service disruptions across the UK and Ireland.
fields.content:
Marks & Spencer CEO Stuart Machin announced during the retailer's annual meeting that full online services should resume within four weeks following April's debilitating cyber attack. Although partial online ordering restarted in June, critical functions like click-and-collect remain suspended, affecting half of digital operations.

Machin detailed that once online systems recover completely, efforts will shift to restoring normal operations at the Castle Donington distribution center. He projected that the retailer would overcome "the vast majority" of disruption by August.

The April attack paralyzed M&S systems for six weeks, caused store stock shortages, resulted in customer data theft, and is predicted to reduce profits by £300 million. Insurance is expected to cover only part of these losses.

While England, Scotland, and Wales have regained online ordering capabilities, Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland remain without service. Machin confirmed: "Within the next four weeks we are hoping for the whole of online to be fully on. Then our focus will be getting the Donington site back and running."

After earlier warnings about extended June-July disruptions, M&S issued e-gift cards last week to customers affected by cancelled orders or delayed click-and-collect services. The incident inadvertently benefited rivals—Sainsbury's CEO Simon Roberts acknowledged "a little bit of benefit" as shoppers turned elsewhere amid M&S stock shortages, noting: "It stands to reason. If a particular store is lower on stock, a customer will go somewhere nearby."

Despite the setback, Hargreaves Lansdown analyst Susannah Streeter observed resilience in M&S's operations, citing pent-up demand for summer fashion and sold-out online products. She cautioned, however, that "there's still a lot to get back online before the company can put the cyber attack behind it," highlighting the retailer's strong pre-attack performance as a foundation for recovery.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Three Killed in Ukrainian Drone Strike on Russian Military Plant
fields.summary: Three people died and 35 were hospitalized after Ukrainian drones targeted a military factory deep inside Russia. The strike occurred at a plant producing missile systems more than 1,300km from the Ukrainian border amid escalating cross-border attacks.
fields.content:
Three people were killed and 35 others hospitalized following a Ukrainian drone strike on a military plant in Izhevsk, over 1,000km (620 miles) inside Russia. Udmurtia Governor Aleksandr Brechalov confirmed ten of the injured sustained serious wounds and reported briefing President Vladimir Putin about the assault.

The attack targeted the Kupol Electromechanical Plant—a facility manufacturing Tor surface-to-air missile systems, radar stations, and Osa air defense equipment. Ukrainian sources confirmed the plant has also developed military drones in the past.

A Ukrainian security official acknowledged to media that two Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) drones struck the facility from approximately 1,300km (807 miles) away. The source stated, "Each such special operation reduces the enemy's offensive potential, disrupts military production chains and demonstrates that even deep in Russia's rear, there are no safe zones for its military infrastructure."

Social media footage verified by international media showed an explosion erupting over a factory roof, followed by towering black smoke near industrial chimneys. Russian aviation authorities temporarily restricted flights at Izhevsk airport before later lifting the measures.

Geographical map highlighting Izhevsk located 1,300km from Ukraine

This marks the second Ukrainian strike on the Kupol facility since November, though no casualties occurred in the prior attack. The assault happened as Russia intensified its own operations against Ukraine, having launched a record 537 missiles and drones across the country during the past weekend.

In response to recent Russian air raids, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky posthumously granted the Hero of Ukraine award to F-16 pilot Lieutenant Colonel Maksym Ustymenko, who perished defending against the aerial onslaught. While Russia's offensive advance near Sumy appears stalled, unconfirmed reports suggest Moscow captured the first village in Dnipropetrovsk region.

Diplomatic efforts to halt hostilities remain troubled. Despite two peace negotiation rounds initiated by former US President Donald Trump since May, both sides reported deadlock. Last week, Vladimir Putin expressed readiness for diplomacy but noted Russian and Ukrainian peace terms were "absolutely contradictory." Zelensky countered on Monday, asserting Putin was stalling, stating: "Russia is not changing its plans and is not looking for a way out of this war."

US envoy Keith Kellogg supported Ukraine's position, warning on social media that Russia cannot "continue to stall for time while it bombs civilian targets." Moscow promptly rejected this characterization, insisting it wasn't "interested in stalling anything" and thanking the US for its involvement.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Workplace Rights Face Two-Year Implementation Delay
fields.summary: Key workplace protections including day-one unfair dismissal rights and a ban on exploitative zero-hours contracts won't take effect for two years under the UK government's phased implementation plan for the Employment Rights Bill, with business groups warning of disruption while unions demand faster action.
fields.content:
The government has confirmed workers will wait another two years for fundamental new employment rights, including day-one protection against unfair dismissal. The implementation schedule for the Employment Rights Bill indicates similar delays for bans on exploitative zero-hours contracts and improved flexible working access.

This newly published timeline marks the first official indication of when different components of the legislation will come into force. Ministers claim the approach provides business certainty, but employer representatives warn of disruptive impacts amid the staggered rollout.

Phased Implementation Details

Upon achieving Royal Assent this autumn, the bill will immediately repeal the 2023 strikes legislation and most of the 2016 trade union laws, establishing what the government terms a better union relationship framework.

Starting April 2025, expanded whistleblowing protections take effect alongside day-one paternity leave and new unpaid parental leave rights. The Fair Work Agency will launch during this phase, complemented by changes to sick pay rules and streamlined trade union recognition processes.

From October 2025, prohibitions on fire-and-rehire abuse take effect alongside revised tipping regulations ensuring fairer distribution of service gratuities to staff.

The most contentious reforms face the longest delay. Measures prohibiting exploitative zero-hours contracts, introducing day-one unfair dismissal protection, and enhancing flexible working access now won't implement until 2027. These regulations remain under consultation, with final details still undetermined.

Stakeholder Responses

Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds defended the timeline, stating it gives companies clarity to plan and grow through a balanced approach that reconciles worker protections with operational demands.

Trades Union Congress leader Paul Novak countered that the rights remain desperately needed and require urgent implementation without extended delays.

Federation of Small Businesses policy chair Tina McKenzie cautioned that the step-by-step rollout will create successive disruption waves for smaller employers, adding complexity and recruitment risks without sufficient industry input.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Small Boat Crossings to UK Surge 48% in First Half of Year
fields.summary: Nearly 20,000 people crossed the English Channel to the UK in small boats during the first six months of 2025, marking a 48% increase from the same period in 2024. The surge has intensified government efforts to combat people smuggling and prompted critical international discussions.
fields.content:
Over 19,900 individuals reached the UK via small boat Channel crossings in the first half of this year according to Home Office data, representing a significant 48% rise compared to 2024 and a 75% jump from the same period in 2023. Almost 1,500 crossings occurred in the final week of June alone.

Opposition Conservatives condemned the figures as a "national record for failure", while government ministers attribute the spike to favorable weather patterns and increasingly aggressive tactics by people smuggling networks. The Labour administration, in power since July 2024, has introduced stricter measures including a new criminal offense for endangering lives at sea.

Legislation is progressing through Parliament to deploy counter-terrorism powers against smugglers, enabling travel bans, social media restrictions, and communication limitations. The surge is expected to feature prominently in UK-France talks when President Emmanuel Macron visits later this week.

French authorities are considering police interventions in shallow waters to halt "taxi boats" collecting migrants from beaches. Negotiations are also underway for a bilateral agreement allowing the UK to return some Channel migrants to France in exchange for accepting asylum seekers seeking family reunification in Britain.

The proposal drew criticism from Italy, Spain, Greece, Malta, and Cyprus, who expressed concerns about potential deportations to their countries. The European Commission confirmed it is seeking clarity, emphasizing solutions must align with EU law while describing the channel crossing numbers as "alarming".

'Red Days' and Migration Patterns

Near Dunkirk, authorities intercepted a migrant boat carrying around 20 people attempting to pick up additional passengers before experiencing engine failure. Police removed occupants without questioning but destroyed the dinghy to prevent reuse. Multiple crossings were observed along northern French beaches as conditions permitted.

Crossing frequency fluctuates based on weather conditions and boat part availability. The Home Office identified increased "red days" - periods with weather favorable for crossings - during this period. Dr Madeleine Sumption of Oxford's Migration Observatory challenged that explanation, stating: "The data suggests crossings are broadly unrelated to red days over longer periods. Factors like migrant volumes and smuggling gang professionalization appear more significant."

Opposition figures attribute the surge to the scrapping of the previous government's Rwanda deportation plan. Shadow Home Secretary Chris Philp argued: "Without a removals deterrent relocating arrivals outside Europe, crossings won't stop." The Home Office maintains its "serious plan" targets smuggling networks at every stage.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Over-60 Fatherhood Rates Rise Notably in England and Wales
fields.summary: Official statistics reveal a 14.2% increase in babies born to fathers over 60 in England and Wales during 2024, while overall births in England rose slightly for the first time since 2021. Experts note declining birth rates among younger parents alongside growing diversity in parent origins.
fields.content:
Births to fathers aged over 60 increased by 14.2% during 2024 compared to the previous year, as per official data. Among 594,677 total live births in England and Wales, 1,076 infants had fathers in this age bracket, marking what the Office for National Statistics describes as a "notable" trend.

Shifting Parental Age Patterns

Professor Allan Pacey, a male fertility specialist, highlighted that research indicates men over 40 are approximately 50% less fertile than 25-year-olds, making this increase particularly significant. Conversely, births among parents under 30 declined, continuing the societal pattern of delayed family formation. Celebrity examples include Rod Stewart having a child at 65, Robert De Niro at 79, and Al Pacino becoming a father again in his 80s.

Regional Birth Trends

While global birth rates generally decline, England reported a 0.7% increase in live births during 2024 totaling 567,708 – the first rise since 2021. Wales experienced a 2% decrease to 26,832 births. Greg Ceely, head of population health monitoring at ONS, noted that this overall increase "reverses the recent trend" despite continued reductions among mothers under 30, with under-20 births dropping nearly 5%.

Social and Policy Dimensions

Rising living costs are frequently cited as a barrier to parenthood. The government has initiated a review of parental leave policies after acknowledging one-third of fathers forgo paternity leave due to financial constraints. Simultaneously, Health Secretary Wes Streeting announced a national investigation into English maternity care following service failures. Angela McConville of childbirth charity NCT emphasized that supporting families requires "accessible postnatal care, affordable childcare, and cost-of-living action."

Diversity and Birth Patterns

Births to parents born outside the UK rose to 40.4% in England (from 38.2%) and 19.4% in Wales (from 17.5%). For the third consecutive year, India remained the most common birth country for non-UK-born parents. Intriguingly, December 26th was the least common birthday for the twelfth straight year, while February 23rd saw the most births. Tuesday was the most frequent birth weekday, with weekends recording the fewest deliveries.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: University Staff Back Strikes Over Major Job Cut Plans
fields.summary: Staff at the University of Nottingham have voted overwhelmingly in favor of industrial action over plans to eliminate 258 professional service roles, citing drastic restructuring plans amid financial pressures.
fields.content:
Staff at the University of Nottingham have strongly endorsed strike action against proposed job reductions that target 258 professional service positions. These non-academic roles represent over 5% of the university's 5,000-strong workforce.

The University and College Union announced approximately 72% of its voting members backed industrial action after a turnout of around 63%. The union characterized the vote as demonstrating resolute opposition to cost-cutting measures that threaten employment stability.

University leadership defended the plans, with President and Vice-Chancellor Professor Jane Norman noting the institution faces significant financial headwinds. Citing declining revenues, reduced international student numbers, and persistent cost-of-living impacts, Norman described the education sector as grappling with unprecedented challenges.

A 90-day consultation period launched on April 8th additionally outlined intentions to cut a further 98 vacant positions. The university emphasized efforts toward sustainable cost reduction, including decreased budgets, a £40 million reduction in planned spending, and potential sale of the King's Meadow Campus.

UCU branch president Lopa Leach stated, 'We do not like to take industrial action. However, considering the drastic plans for job losses and restructuring, we are left with no alternative to protect jobs.' Leach warned compulsory redundancies would prompt decisive strikes while urging management to consider alternative proposals.

The union confirmed it will finalize strike dates spanning the next six months, as tensions escalate over the proposed staff reductions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Labrador-Sized Dinosaur Species Discovered After Decades of Misidentification
fields.summary: Paleontologists have identified a new Labrador-sized dinosaur species named Enigmacursor that lived 150 million years ago among giants like Stegosaurus. The specimen, initially misclassified for decades, will be displayed at London's Natural History Museum and provides crucial insights into dinosaur evolution.
fields.content:
A newly identified dinosaur species named Enigmacursor, meaning "puzzling runner," has been confirmed after decades of misclassification. Originally categorized as a Nanosaurus, scientists now recognize this Labrador-sized creature as a distinct species that roamed North America approximately 150 million years ago among much larger dinosaurs.

Physical Characteristics and Display

Measuring 64 cm tall and 180 cm long, Enigmacursor resembled a labrador dog but featured disproportionately large feet and an exceptionally long tail. Its small head suggested limited intelligence, and analysis of its dense hip bones indicated it was a swift runner. The dinosaur's forelimbs were likely used for gathering plants.

A graphic comparing Enigmacursor to a Labrador dog

Museum conservators meticulously mounted the nearly complete skeleton onto a custom metal frame for its upcoming display at London's Natural History Museum—the first new dinosaur added to their collection since 2014. The exhibit places Enigmacursor on a balcony overlooking "Sophie" the Stegosaurus.

Conservators mounting the dinosaur bones

Scientific Revelation

The breakthrough came when researchers discovered the original Nanosaurus archetype consisted only of rock impressions rather than actual bones. In contrast, Enigmacursor's detailed skeleton revealed unique leg bone structures confirming it as a new species. This led scientists to formally erase the Nanosaurus classification.

Professor Susannah Maidment with the fossil

Professor Susannah Maidment emphasized the importance of this reclassification: "It's foundational to understand how many species we actually have. If we've got that wrong, everything else falls apart." The discovery suggests many small dinosaur specimens from this era may represent distinct species.

Final preparations of the mounted specimen

According to Professor Paul Barrett, Enigmacursor helps fill critical gaps in understanding Late Jurassic dinosaur diversity and evolutionary transitions: "Small dinosaurs are very close to the origins of large dinosaur groups. Specimens like this show how changes occurred gradually over time." The rarity of complete small-dinosaur skeletons makes this find particularly valuable.

The findings on Enigmacursor mollyborthwickae are published in the journal Royal Society Open Science.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Musk's X Hires 'King of Virality' to Target Younger Audience
fields.summary: X appoints Nikita Bier, creator of popular youth social apps, as head of product to revitalize engagement with younger users amid platform challenges and competition from rivals Bluesky and Threads.
fields.content:
X, the social media platform owned by Elon Musk, has named Nikita Bier as its new head of product. Bier is renowned for developing viral social applications tailored to younger audiences. His appointment comes three years after he publicly suggested on the platform—then named Twitter—that they should hire him.

"I've officially posted my way to the top," Bier announced on X regarding his new position. His hiring unfolds against a turbulent period for X since Musk's $44 billion acquisition in October 2022. The platform has faced advertiser exoduses, high-profile user departures, and mounting competition from newcomers Bluesky and Threads.

Experts believe Bier may rejuvenate X's appeal to younger demographics. Drew Benvie, CEO of Battenhall, highlighted Bier's expertise with youth engagement tools like anonymous polling, suggesting he could inject an "X-factor" to revitalize the platform. "Getting that knack for what Gen Z users want is precisely what X needs to turn things around," Benvie explained.

Successful - and controversial

A UC Berkeley graduate, Bier established his reputation by creating anonymous apps targeting teens. His application tbh—a platform focused on positive polling among high schoolers—was acquired by Meta in 2017. Discord later purchased his app Gas in 2023 after it surged in downloads. The venture capital firm Lightspeed celebrated him as the "king of virality" last year.

However, Forbes questioned tbh's tactics after a leaked memo reportedly described "psychological tricks" for recruiting teens, including scouring Instagram profiles. On X, Bier called the platform the world's "most important social network," vowing to "leverage Grok's generative AI" to develop hyper-personalized content feeds.

Despite Musk's claim of over 600 million monthly users, Pew Research indicates U.S. adoption fell to 17% in late 2023 from 23% in 2022.

Talent tensions

Bier's appointment coincides with tech giants fiercely competing for AI specialists. Meta recently formed a "superintelligence" unit by recruiting engineers like GitHub's ex-CEO Nat Friedman and Scale AI's Alexandr Wang. Reports indicate Meta offered OpenAI researchers over $100 million packages.

An internal memo from OpenAI's Mark Chen acknowledged efforts to "recognize top talent creatively" amid talent raids, comparing the poaching attempts to a "break-in."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Squid Game Finale Spurs Reflections on South Korea's Social Realities
fields.summary: As Netflix's Squid Game concludes its final season, South Koreans contemplate how the dystopian series mirrors societal pressures including economic inequality, precarious labor conditions, and the human cost of hyper-capitalism in contemporary society.
fields.content:
Warning: This article contains spoilers for Squid Game's final season.

Millions bid farewell to the Emmy-winning series Squid Game as its third and final season concludes, cementing its status as a global phenomenon that showcased South Korea's cultural influence. The Netflix hit depicted desperate contestants battling through lethal versions of traditional Korean children's games, with losers executed after each round.

Since its 2021 debut, the candy-colored dystopia captivated audiences worldwide with its brutal critique of capitalism and human nature. While international fans process the finale, many South Koreans find themselves confronting the societal conditions that inspired creator Hwang Dong-hyuk's vision.

One YouTube viewer observed: "Squid Game 3 revealed Korean people's raw inner thoughts. It reflected reality perfectly - workplaces full of ruthless colleagues ready to crush you."

Relatable struggles

The series emerged from South Korea's intensely competitive society marked by widening inequality,record-low birth rates, and national college entrance exams that determine life trajectories. Characters like cash-strapped salarymen, exploited migrant workers, and morally compromised financiers reflect figures familiar to domestic audiences.

Protagonist Seong Gi-hun's backstory draws from real labor conflicts, notably the 2009 SsangYong Motor strike - one of the country's largest worker uprisings where laid-off employees clashed with riot police. Film enthusiast Jeong Cheol Sang noted: "Precarious labor, youth unemployment, broken families - these aren't just plot devices but our daily struggles. The drama feels more realistic than reality itself."

Squid Game Pink Guards posing with fan during parade event

Amidst these reflections, Seoul hosted a massive parade celebrating the finale featuring the show's killer doll and tracksuit-clad guards. Political leaders view the series alongside BTS and Parasite as cultural exports driving soft-power ambitions, with the Los Angeles-set final scene sparking spinoff rumors.

Star Lee Jung-jae told the BBC: "The ending poses questions that I hope audiences will ponder, discuss, and personally seek answers to - it's deliberately open-ended."

Mixed reactions

The concluding season followed Gi-hun's failed rebellion against the game organizers, culminating in his sacrificial death to save another player's child. This polarizing ending divided viewers between those who found the altruism unrealistic and others who considered it a poetic truth.

"Characters' excessive altruism felt disturbingly performative," argued one comment on Nate Pann forum. "Prioritizing strangers over family seemed unhinged." However, another YouTube user countered: "Gi-hun couldn't magically defeat evil - that's not our world. The ending honors the show's commitment to uncomfortable truths."

Creator Hwang acknowledged divided responses to the finale: "Season one had no expectations - shock value worked. By season three, expectations were sky-high with some wanting more games, others deeper messages, and some more character development."

For blogger Jeong Cheol Sang, the resolution offered hope: "The coexistence of cruelty and warmth made the finale moving. As an educator, I've doubted whether kindness changes anything. That's why I call this ending beautiful."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Thai Prime Minister Suspended Over Leaked Cambodia Call After Border Clash
fields.summary: Thailand's leader faces suspension after constitutional court ethics ruling over a leaked conversation with Cambodia's senate president, following violent border tensions that resulted in a soldier's death and widespread protests.
fields.content:
Thailand's Constitutional Court voted unanimously to accept an ethics violation petition against Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra and suspended her from office by a 7-2 margin. The court mandated she present evidence within 12 days to respond to charges stemming from a leaked conversation.

Border Dispute Triggers Diplomatic Crisis

The suspension links directly to controversy over Paetongtarn's phone discussion with Cambodian Senate President Hun Sen. Tensions escalated after the call leaked publicly amid fallout from a May 2025 border confrontation where Cambodian and Thai troops clashed, leaving one Cambodian soldier dead.

Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra Thailand-Cambodia border town

Conflicting accounts emerged about the border incident. Cambodia maintained its forces were conducting routine patrols when Thai troops opened fire, while Thailand asserted Cambodian soldiers entered disputed territory and initiated gunfire.

Following the phone recording's release, massive protests erupted across Bangkok demanding Paetongtarn's removal. Demonstrators condemned the communications as compromising national sovereignty during heightened bilateral friction.

Protesters in Thailand

Facing intense criticism, the prime minister publicly defended her intentions in the conversation: "My true intention 100% was to work for the country to maintain our sovereignty and save the lives of all our soldiers," Paetongtarn stated to media.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Warns DOGE May Target Musk as Feud Escalates Over Bill and EV Subsidies
fields.summary: Former President Donald Trump claimed the government agency DOGE might need to 'eat Elon' Musk, escalating tensions as Musk threatens to fund primary challenges against lawmakers supporting Trump's $5 trillion debt bill ahead of July 4 deadline, amid disputes over electric vehicle subsidies.
fields.content:
Former President Donald Trump suggested Tuesday that the government agency DOGE could target Elon Musk during remarks to reporters. "DOGE is the monster that might have to go back and eat Elon. Wouldn't that be terrible?" Trump stated. He added Musk receives substantial subsidies and has been distressed over the pending termination of electric vehicle mandates.

Trump made these comments while departing for Florida's Everglades to visit a migrant detention facility. When questioned about potentially deporting Musk, a South Africa native, Trump responded, "I don't know, we'll have to take a look." This exchange follows Musk's vow to fund primary challengers against lawmakers supporting Trump's "One Big Beautiful Bill."

Musk reacted on social media: "So tempting to escalate this. So, so tempting. But I will refrain for now." His political warning included an image showing Pinocchio engulfed in flames captioned "LIAR Voted to increase America's DEBT by 5,000,000,000.00"

Dispute Origins and Policy Impacts

Tensions reportedly began in June when Trump moved to eliminate California's electric vehicle requirements, impacting Musk's Tesla company. On June 12, Trump signed resolutions ending the state's diesel regulations and EV sales mandates, declaring this would "kill the California mandates forever."

Musk previously collaborated closely with Trump's administration through DOGE as a special government employee until May. He regularly attended Cabinet meetings and appeared alongside Trump at public events before their relationship deteriorated over policy differences.

Trump and Musk during Tesla demonstration

Bill Opposition and Debt Concerns

The $5 trillion budget reconciliation bill, now before the Senate, seeks to advance Trump's tax, energy, immigration, and defense agendas. Musk has joined critics like Senator Rand Paul in opposing the legislation, warning it would excessively raise the debt ceiling.

Following Musk's threats to campaign against supportive lawmakers, Trump countered on Truth Social, suggesting DOGE scrutinize Musk's business subsidies: "Without subsidies, Elon would probably have to close up shop and head back home to South Africa. No more Rocket launches... BIG MONEY TO BE SAVED!!!" Trump reminded followers he consistently opposed EV mandates despite Musk's endorsement, stating: "Electric cars are fine, but not everyone should be forced to own one."

Speaking from the White House, Trump commented on Musk's frustrations: "He could lose a lot more than that. I can tell you right now." Musk recently amplified calls to "KILL the BILL" and urged supporters to contact representatives, arguing the legislation would bankrupt America.

President Donald Trump sitting

As the July 4 deadline approaches, Musk renewed attacks, claiming America operates under a "PORKY PIG PARTY" system and demanding a new political force. He questioned fiscal responsibility: "What’s the point of a debt ceiling if we keep raising it? All I’m asking is that we don’t bankrupt America."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Gut Microbes May Help Combat Harmful 'Forever Chemicals'
fields.summary: Researchers reveal that beneficial gut bacteria might naturally shield humans from toxic PFAS compounds, known as 'forever chemicals' for their persistence, by binding and removing them from the body. Scientists are working on probiotic supplements to enhance this protective effect.
fields.content:
A groundbreaking study indicates that microorganisms in the human digestive system could help detoxify harmful 'forever chemicals' accumulating in our bodies. Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), synthetic compounds notorious for their extreme durability, are present in countless household products and environmental sources.

University of Cambridge researchers discovered through mice experiments that certain gut bacteria aggregate PFAS into clumps, facilitating their removal. Lead scientist Arjun Patil noted, "Due to aggregation of PFAS in these clumps, the bacteria themselves seem protected from the toxic effects." The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency confirms PFAS components break down exceptionally slowly.

Woman who lost loved ones to cancer listens about PFAS contamination

An expert involved in the research emphasized the deceptive danger of PFAS, explaining their initial perceived safety: "PFAS were once considered safe, but it’s now clear that they’re not. It’s taken a long time for PFAS to become noticed because at low levels they’re not acutely toxic. But they’re like a slow poison."

Woman holds PFAS informational folder in GA

Patil and colleague Lindell are developing probiotic supplements to boost protective gut microbes. Until these become available, scientists recommend minimizing exposure by using water filters and avoiding PFAS-coated cooking pans.

Civil engineer tests for PFAS contamination in GA

Highlighting widespread contamination concerns, Patil stated: "Given the scale of the problem of PFAS ‘forever chemicals’, particularly their effects on human health, it’s concerning that so little is being done about removing these from our bodies." Studies confirm PFAS are now detectable in virtually all humans.

Woman in GA holds up PFAS results

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Angler Breaks North Carolina Fishing Record with 56-Pound Almaco Jack
fields.summary: A Virginia fisherman shattered North Carolina's state fishing record by landing a 56-pound almaco jack at the Outer Banks, surpassing the previous record by more than 22 pounds after an intense 45-minute battle.
fields.content:
An angler has achieved a remarkable fishing milestone in North Carolina with a record-shattering catch. Warren Poirier from Charles City, Virginia, reeled in a massive almaco jack weighing 56 pounds and 4.8 ounces. The fish struck Poirier's Zest brand jig and engaged him in a strenuous 45-minute struggle before being landed.

Record-Setting Catch Details

The monumental almaco jack measured 46 inches in fork length from nose to tail and featured a substantial 31-inch girth. According to NOAA Fisheries, this species typically displays elongated dusky-colored bodies with distinctive light amber or olive stripes along their sides.

Outer Banks fishing location in North Carolina

North Carolina's previous record for the species stood at 33 pounds and 12.6 ounces, established just last year in 2024. Poirier officially weighed his historic catch at Teach's Lair Marina in Hatteras, confirming the new benchmark.

Almaco jack fish species

NOAA Fisheries notes that almaco jacks can grow beyond 5 feet in length and reach weights up to 136 pounds, making this record potentially vulnerable to future challenges. The species, scientifically known as Seriola rivoliana, inhabits offshore waters where anglers frequently target them.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Former teammate Bakhtiari jabs Rodgers over wedding invite snub
fields.summary: Green Bay Packers veteran David Bakhtiari humorously called out former teammate Aaron Rodgers for not inviting him to his private wedding, as Rodgers defends fiercely guarding his personal life from public scrutiny.
fields.content:
David Bakhtiari, Aaron Rodgers' longtime offensive linemate from their Green Bay Packers days, made a pointed yet playful remark about the quarterback's secretive nuptials on social media. The NFL star congratulated Rodgers but noted his exclusion from the wedding festivities.

"Love is love. Congrats to the Loves," Bakhtiari wrote publicly. "Just happy at least one of my quarterbacks invited me to their wedding."

David Bakhtiari vs Lions

Speculation about Rodgers' marriage emerged months ago when he appeared at the Kentucky Derby wearing a wedding ring - confirmed again in Pittsburgh Steelers contract-signing photos. Despite these public sightings, his partner's identity remains undisclosed, which Rodgers attributes to her preference for privacy outside celebrity culture.

Rodgers' fierce defense of privacy

David Bakhtiari and Aaron Rodgers

Rodgers delivered an impassioned response about the intense public scrutiny, criticizing societal expectations that demand access to his personal affairs. "It's a sick society. I've lived publicly for 20 years - relationships leaked, paparazzi called on me," he stated. "Now I'm with someone private who didn't sign up for fame, and suddenly I'm weird for protecting that."

The quarterback expressed frustration at what he called entitlement to his private details: "The demand to know everything is ridiculous. Sports media - try not talking about me for five weeks. See if you can stay relevant without my personal or professional life."

Rodgers also hinted at retirement from public view after his current NFL season, declaring, "When this is done, I'm out. You won't see me. For my final season, I'm playing football - but my private life stays private."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 9 Hidden Online Privacy Risks You've Likely Overlooked
fields.summary: Many users unknowingly expose sensitive personal data through daily digital activities. This article examines nine covert privacy risks, from health tracking to political leanings, and provides guidance on protecting your information from data brokers and advertisers.
fields.content:
Hidden Threats to Your Data

Privacy dangers often lurk in plain sight, with personal information constantly collected, tracked, and sold without awareness. Data brokers compile extensive profiles using sensitive details like sleep patterns, medical appointments, online habits, and relationship status. These profiles are sold to advertisers, insurers, political campaigns, and sometimes criminals. Alarmingly, this extensive tracking usually occurs without consent.

A man wearing a smartwatch to track health data.

Personal Details Unknowingly Exposed

Daily digital activities reveal more information than most realize. Fitness trackers, sleep apps, and phone settings report health metrics like sleep patterns and exercise routines to data collectors.

Entertainment habits through smart TVs and streaming services catalog viewing preferences, durations, and engagement to build behavioral profiles. This data forecasts moods, interests, and vulnerabilities enabling hyper-targeted advertising beyond mere recommendations.

Browsing durations on sensitive topics help identify fears, desires, and private concerns, creating data that can be exploited for manipulative ads or malicious attacks.

A man reading an article on his tablet.

Purchase histories, location check-ins, and frequent destinations disclose relationship status regardless of social media privacy settings.

Medical information frequently gets sold without consent—a study found 74% of health data transactions occurred unknowingly. This risks insurance premium hikes, claim denials, or intrusive targeted ads.

Public records provide brokers with home values, tax histories, and neighborhood crime statistics to push refinancing offers, security systems, or relocation services.

Household demographic data allows advertisers to target family units, incorporating relatives' activities into consumer profiles.

Political leanings emerge through tracked news reading habits, subscription patterns, and donation activities despite social media discretion.

A woman typing on her laptop.

Major life events like engagements, pregnancies, or moves are flagged when users browse related products, enabling early advertisement targeting.

Kurt’s Key Takeaways

Digital footprints reveal extensive personal information without requiring social media oversharing. Daily behaviors—from streaming habits to location history—get tracked, packaged, and sold to advertisers, data brokers, political organizations, and malicious actors. Awareness of what you share is crucial. Comprehensive solutions include using data removal services to reclaim privacy.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Senate Republicans Struggle to Secure Votes for Trump's Budget Bill
fields.summary: Republican leaders face challenges passing President Trump's tax and spending bill through the Senate, with four GOP defections threatening its passage. Vice-President JD Vance stands ready to break ties as negotiations continue past the July 4 deadline.
fields.content:
Vote Count Challenges

US senators negotiated for over 24 hours on amendments to a sprawling tax and spending bill, which stalled due to insufficient support. Four Republican senators—Susan Collins, Thom Tillis, Lisa Murkowski, and Rand Paul—declared opposition to the nearly 1,000-page legislation. With Republicans holding a slim majority, leadership needs to persuade at least one dissenter to secure passage.

Senate Majority Leader John Thune paced the chamber aisle on Tuesday morning, bearing the weight of the bill's uncertain fate. Despite initial confidence in securing votes for a Tuesday morning decision, negotiations extended as Republicans worked to flip critical votes. Vice-President JD Vance arrived at the Capitol at 6:00 EST to break potential ties, having already provided the decisive vote for one amendment.

Legislative Hurdles Ahead

The legislation, central to Donald Trump's second-term agenda, proposes extending his first-term tax cuts while offsetting costs through spending reductions. These include cuts to healthcare for low-income Americans and food subsidies. Debate within the Republican ranks centers on which programs should face reductions.

Trump had earlier demanded the bill reach his desk by July 4, but acknowledged the deadline would be difficult to meet. He told reporters, "I'd love to do July 4th but I think it's very hard... I would say maybe July 4th or somewhere around there." After Senate passage, the bill must return to the House—where Republicans hold a narrow margin—for renewed approval of amended provisions. Democrats remain uniformly opposed in both chambers.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Public to Help Determine MPs' Pay in Landmark Ipsa Review
fields.summary: The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority is recruiting 20 ordinary citizens through a postal lottery to directly participate in setting the salaries and expenses rules for UK Members of Parliament, marking the first time the public will shape these policies.
fields.content:
Parliament's expenses regulator has launched an unprecedented public consultation to determine how lawmakers should be paid. The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority (Ipsa) seeks approximately 20 citizens to join a forum that will recommend changes to MP compensation policies starting next year.

Selected through a lottery of 10,000 addresses nationwide, participants will form a demographically representative group. They'll attend four meetings this September, deliberating alongside a wider online consultation running through autumn. The unique initiative marks the first direct public involvement in such decisions.

MPs currently receive £93,904 annually following a 2.8% pay increase in April. Ipsa, legally required to review compensation after each general election, will also examine how UK parliamentary salaries compare internationally.

The citizens' assembly model, previously used in Ireland and by Scottish officials for constitutional debates, aims to make policymaking more democratic. Critics, however, question whether small volunteer groups can truly reflect national perspectives. Labour had considered adopting this approach broadly but shelved plans recently.

Annual pay awards

Ipsa was established after the 2009 expenses scandal to independently set MP pay, removing lawmakers from deciding their own salaries. Instead of a fixed formula, the watchdog balances public sector wage data against broader economic conditions and private sector comparisons.

Recent years saw Ipsa experiment with linking MP raises to October's public sector pay figures. However, adjustments occurred when it deemed the data insufficient - awarding above-average increases in 2023 due to cost-of-living pressures, but only 2.8% in 2024 aligned with Treasury plans.

A 2023 Ipsa survey revealed UK MPs earn more than French and New Zealand counterparts but less than those in Ireland, Germany, Canada, Australia, and the US. Recruitment for the citizens' forum requires no political background, only that participants be over 18.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Rise of Lab-Grown Meat: Revolution or Overhyped Solution?
fields.summary: As Oxford's Ivy Farm Technologies pioneers lab-grown steaks from cow cells, cultivated meat edges closer to UK restaurant menus. This technology promises environmental benefits but faces scrutiny over its true climate impact, ultra-processed nature, and ethical implications in a world grappling with rising meat demand.
fields.content:
At an Oxford facility, Riley Jackson fries a steak that sizzles with authentic aroma and texture — yet originates not from a farm but a laboratory. This cultivated fillet, grown from bovine cells by food tech startup Ivy Farm Technologies, appears indistinguishable from conventional meat.

"Our mission is to mirror conventional steak as closely as possible," states Jackson. Cultivated meat already has commercial approvals globally and may appear in UK restaurants within two years pending regulatory clearance. Unlike plant-based alternatives, this innovation involves genuine animal cells biologically replicating meat.

BBC A treated image showing a burger in black and white on a red background

Curbing greenhouse gas emissions

Global meat production has surged fivefold since the 1960s, reaching 364 million tonnes in 2023, according to UN data. Agriculture contributes one-third of planet-warming emissions, with beef production generating approximately 40kg of carbon dioxide per kilogram. Cattle methane emissions and land use compound environmental strains.

Professor Tim Lang from City St George's University warns, "The situation is dire. Politicians avoid confronting meat consumption despite UK targets requiring a 30% reduction by 2032." Advocates position lab-grown meat as a technological solution, potentially lowering emissions and land use.

Ivy Farm Technologies A knife slices into a lab grown steak

Lab-grown sausages, eel and caviar

Cultivation begins with animal cells nurtured in nutrient-rich solutions inside bioreactors before being processed into meat-like textures. Companies like Ivy Farm plan initial UK market entry with blended burgers combining conventional and cultivated mince.

"Burgers target mass consumer adoption for maximum environmental impact," explains Ivy Farm CEO Dr Harsh Amin. The approach enables carbon footprint reductions without requiring dietary overhaul. Other companies explore diverse products including caviar and cultivated eel.

"Hope not hard evidence"?

Environmental claims face scrutiny since production remains pre-commercial. Oxford researcher Dr John Lynch cautions that assessments rely on projections rather than real-world data. Energy-intensive cultivation processes could yield between 1.65kg and 22kg of CO2 per kg of meat.

Lynch explains that while long-term CO2 impacts merit concern, reduced land requirements may benefit cultivated beef: "It likely has the environmental edge as production scales. However, traditional chicken and pork farming currently boast superior efficiency."

Ivy Farm Technologies Pallab looks on as a lab grown steak is cooked

Farm Images via Getty Herd of Hereford beef cattle in the English landscape

Lab-grown salmon in fine dining restaurants

Singapore pioneered sales in 2020, followed by the US and Israel. Limited availability sees lab-grown salmon from Wildtype featured at Oregon's Kann restaurant and Good Meat's chicken in Washington DC. Suzi Gerber of the US Association for Meat, Poultry and Seafood Innovation notes consumers respond with "optimism and curiosity."

UK firms highlight regulatory delays allowing competitors to gain market footholds. Production challenges include scaling output and cost reduction in competition with conventional meat.

Good Meat, Inc. GOOD Meat’s chicken

Good Meat, Inc. GOOD Meat's lab

What farmers and fishermen say

Some US cattle associations actively oppose cultivated meats, while others remain neutral. Producers argue consumers will always prefer traditional meat. The National Fisheries Institute acknowledges cultivated seafood as part of future aquatic food systems. Producers position the technology as complementary rather than threatening.

Will "high-protein slurry" really save the planet?

Sydney-based VOW sells cultivated Japanese quail in Singapore, deliberately avoiding imitation of common meats. Chief Operating Officer Ellen Dinsmoor highlights flexibility: "Incorporating omega-3 oils into cultivated poultry exemplifies novel nutritional possibilities."

Critics like Dr Chris van Tulleken see prioritization of high-priced goods over accessibility: "Technological solutions shouldn't sideline simpler options like reducing consumption or impose processed products on vulnerable populations." Energy intensiveness fuels concerns about reinforcing industrialized food systems.

Vow Vow Japanese Quail Foie Gras and Japanese Quail Whipped Pate

Final acceptance hinges on taste and affordability rather than environmental or ethical arguments. Proponents champion cholesterol reduction and animal welfare advantages, while critics question overstated benefits. The future of cultivated meat ultimately depends on appealing to consumer preferences.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Cloudflare Deploys AI Bot Blocker for Millions of Websites
fields.summary: Cloudflare is implementing a new tool enabling millions of hosted websites to prevent AI bots from scraping their content without permission, while developing a payment system for authorized data access. This response addresses growing copyright disputes between publishers and AI firms over training data collection.
fields.content:
Millions of websites including Sky News, The Associated Press, and BuzzFeed can now block artificial intelligence crawlers from harvesting their content without authorization. Internet infrastructure provider Cloudflare, responsible for about 20% of global web traffic, is rolling out the new protective system that will eventually allow content owners to demand payment from AI companies for data access.

This development responds to widespread complaints from creators including authors, musicians, and artists who accuse AI companies of using their work without permission or compensation. In the UK, these tensions previously sparked disputes between the government and figures such as Sir Elton John regarding copyright protections. Cloudflare's technology specifically identifies AI crawlers—automated programs that gather web data critical for training AI systems. Over one million websites have already activated the feature.

Roger Lynch, CEO of Condé Nast which publishes Vogue and The New Yorker, praised the innovation as revolutionary. "This is a critical step toward creating a fair value exchange that protects creators, supports journalism, and holds AI companies accountable," Lynch stated. Industry experts assert that despite these technical measures, stronger legal frameworks remain necessary.

Surviving the Age of AI

The system activates by default for new Cloudflare clients and websites participating in prior bot-blocking initiatives. Publishers like the BBC have threatened legal action against AI firms including Perplexity for unauthorized content use, seeking compensation. While publishers willingly permit search engine crawlers from companies like Google—which drives traffic to original sources—Cloudflare argues AI crawlers disrupt this balance by using content to generate responses without directing users to the creators' platforms.

Perplexity accused the BBC of protecting "Google's monopoly," but Cloudflare's CEO Matthew Prince contends AI exploitation jeopardizes web sustainability. "To help the internet survive the age of AI, publishers need control and a new economic model," Prince emphasized. The company is advancing a "Pay Per Crawl" feature to let creators charge AI firms for content access.

Battle the Bots

Cloudflare reports enormous AI bot activity—over 50 billion daily requests on its network. Many crawlers ignore established exclusion protocols, prompting previous countermeasures like diverting offenders to decoy pages filled with meaningless AI-generated text. The upgraded system emphasizes technological barriers and monetization options for legitimate access.

Meanwhile, a legislative battle over AI training practices intensifies in the UK, where policymakers debate protections for creative industries. Legal confrontations have also increased internationally, with content owners suing AI firms for copyright violations in US and European courts. Ed Newton-Rex of certification group Fairly Trained acknowledges Cloudflare's effort as beneficial but limited: "This is a sticking plaster, not major surgery. Real protection requires legal reforms since safeguards vanish when content moves outside controlled platforms."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russia Declares Full Control of Luhansk Amid Escalated Ukraine Offensive
fields.summary: Russian officials claim complete occupation of Ukraine's Luhansk region while amassing 50,000 troops near Sumy, escalating hostilities despite U.S. ceasefire proposals and NATO warnings about Putin's broader ambitions.
fields.content:
Russian Advances in Ukraine

Ukrainian soldiers stand in destroyed Luhansk region.

Ukrainian officials have not responded to claims by Russian-installed leader Leonid Pasechnik, who stated on Russian state TV that Moscow now fully occupies Ukraine's Luhansk region. Pasechnik asserted this development occurred "literally two days ago," as reported by the Associated Press. Despite this declaration, Russia is assessed to control less than 20% of Ukraine's total territory—including Crimea and roughly 70% of three other annexed regions, according to Reuters analysis.

Military intelligence indicates Russia deployed approximately 50,000 troops along Ukraine's northern border near Sumy this week, raising fears of a renewed offensive. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy confirmed moving defense forces to the area a week prior in anticipation of potential attacks.

Burned out building in Kharkiv following Russian drone strike.

Diplomatic Standoff

President Donald Trump speaks during a meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte.

Russia has dramatically intensified military operations over the past two months, rejecting multiple U.S.-brokered ceasefire initiatives. While Ukraine accepted Washington's proposals, Russian President Vladimir Putin has consistently dismissed peace overtures and ignored deadlines set by Trump. During a recent NATO press conference, Trump expressed confidence that Putin "would like to settle" the conflict, calling it "a mess for him."

NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte cautioned that Putin may target other European territories within three to five years. This warning comes despite Rutte maintaining productive relations with Trump following earlier criticisms of the military alliance. In May, Trump had delivered a two-week ultimatum to Putin to demonstrate serious commitment toward ending hostilities, but that deadline lapsed without resolution.

President Donald Trump speaks during a meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte.

The White House has not clarified future diplomatic steps or timing for additional talks between Trump and Putin, leaving uncertainty about America's next moves to resolve the conflict.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Jessica Pegula Stunned by World No. 116 in Early Wimbledon Exit
fields.summary: American tennis star Jessica Pegula suffered a major upset at Wimbledon on Tuesday, eliminated by Italy's 116th-ranked Elisabetta Cocciaretto who described the victory as a 'dream come true' while Pegula acknowledged her opponent's 'insane' level of play.
fields.content:
American tennis professional Jessica Pegula faced a stunning early exit from Wimbledon after losing to Italy's Elisabetta Cocciaretto, who holds the 116th position in global rankings. The unexpected defeat occurred during their Tuesday match on Wimbledon's prestigious courts.

Underdog Triumph

An elated Cocciaretto shared during her post-match interview: "To play here in such an unbelievable stadium and such an unbelievable tournament, it’s a dream come true for me. I was so pumped to play Wimbledon this year." She expressed deep admiration for her opponent, adding: "I played a really great champion. She’s an unbelievable player, she’s a great example for us."

Jessica Pegula plays forehand during match

Champion's Disappointment

A dejected Pegula reflected on the unexpected outcome: "For this to happen today, it’s disappointing. I don’t know how else to put it. I’m upset that I wasn’t able to turn anything around." She acknowledged Cocciaretto's exceptional performance, stating: "I do feel like she played kind of insane. Hats off to her. Kudos to her for playing at a high level that I couldn’t match today."

Jessica Pegula leaves Wimbledon court

Tuesday's match evoked memories of previous competitive struggles for the American athlete. Pegula bluntly assessed the result: "This is definitely probably the worst result I’ve had all year," marking a significant setback in her 2025 campaign.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: New SparkKitty Malware Scans Phone Photos to Steal Crypto Data
fields.summary: A new mobile malware strain named SparkKitty is targeting Android and iOS users by scanning private photo libraries to extract cryptocurrency recovery phrases and sensitive data. Distributed through app stores, the malware uploads images indiscriminately, posing threats beyond crypto theft to include potential extortion.
fields.content:
Cybersecurity experts have uncovered a sophisticated mobile malware called SparkKitty that endangers both Android and iPhone users. This threat specifically scrutinizes personal photo collections to steal cryptocurrency wallet recovery phrases and other confidential information, expanding hackers' access to sensitive digital assets.

What is SparkKitty mobile malware

Identified by Kaspersky researchers, SparkKitty builds upon the earlier SparkCat malware that used optical character recognition to plunder crypto recovery phrases from images. SparkKitty intensifies this approach by automatically uploading all images from infected devices without filtering, exposing not just cryptocurrency keys but also personal photos that could enable extortion.

The malware has operated since at least February 2024, distributed through official and unofficial channels including Google Play and Apple's App Store. Researchers detected it embedded in the iOS app 币coin and Android messaging application SOEX, the latter exceeding 10,000 downloads before removal.

SparkKitty uploads images from infected phones without discrimination.
