On iOS devices, attackers deploy SparkKitty through counterfeit software frameworks disguised as legitimate components. The malware leverages Apple's Objective-C programming to initiate immediately upon app launch, scanning configuration files before beginning surveillance of the photo library.

Android infections occur through apps coded in Java or Kotlin, sometimes utilizing malicious system modules that activate during specific app interactions. SparkKitty connects to remote servers to decrypt configuration files, then begins exfiltrating images alongside device identifiers and metadata.

On iOS, attackers deliver the malware through fake software frameworks or enterprise provisioning profiles.

Unlike conventional spyware, SparkKitty focuses on bulk image collection rather than activity monitoring. It prioritizes photos containing cryptocurrency seeds, wallet screenshots, identification documents, and personal images - streamlining criminals' ability to extract valuable information en masse.

Kurt’s key takeaway

While Apple and Google removed identified malicious apps upon notification, the successful deployment of SparkKitty through official store reviews raises significant concerns. Without substantial advancements in app screening processes to match growing marketplace volume and complexity, security breaches of this nature will continue to bypass existing safeguards.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Hauser & Wirth Founders Move to Switzerland as UK Wealth Shifts
fields.summary: Art gallery magnates Iwan and Manuela Wirth have relocated their permanent residence from the UK to Switzerland amid tax reforms targeting the ultra-wealthy, though they maintain the move is personal. Despite UK sales declines, their empire continues expanding with a new London venue planned.
fields.content:
Iwan and Manuela Wirth, the influential owners of global art gallery Hauser & Wirth, have transferred their permanent residency from Britain to Switzerland. This shift coincides with Switzerland hosting the gallery's holding company, while several prominent UK art figures reconsider their bases following tax reforms.

Official documents filed with Companies House this month confirm the relocation, processed through the UK government agency overseeing corporate audits. The gallery acknowledged to media outlets that the owners are pursuing projects across Switzerland, the US, and Britain, calling the move a personal decision unrelated to taxation policy shifts.

Through their development firm Artfarm, the Wirths continue investing in UK operations despite market challenges. Plans remain intact for a new London gallery debut in 2026, despite declining regional revenues. Financial records reveal UK turnover dropped to £144 million in 2023, down 13% from £166 million the previous year, while post-tax profits modestly increased from £5.2 million to £6 million.

The transition occurs amid broader discussions of wealth migration triggered by Chancellor Rachel Reeves' elimination of non-dom tax status and inheritance tax reforms. However, recent London School of Economics research questions the scale of this exodus, suggesting many affluent individuals view international relocations for tax advantages as damaging to their reputations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 1930s Plan to Hide Cerne Abbas Giant's Genitalia Revealed
fields.summary: Newly uncovered documents reveal a 1930s proposal to conceal the genitalia of England's famous Cerne Abbas Giant chalk figure following a complaint that it offended Christian values, though authorities rejected the plan.
fields.content:
England's iconic Cerne Abbas Giant, a monumental 180-foot chalk hill figure depicting a nude man holding a club, narrowly avoided having its genitalia concealed nearly a century ago. Historian Karen Heaney discovered evidence that British authorities considered camouflaging the ancient landmark during the 1930s after a local resident's complaint about its explicit nature.

The mysterious chalk figure in Dorset, created by Anglo-Saxons, remains of uncertain origin despite written records dating back to 1694. Traditionally associated with fertility, the carving has attracted couples hoping its presence would help conception. Its massive erection measures 35 feet.

Heaney found correspondence showing Dorset resident Walter Long complained to the Home Office in 1932, claiming the giant's "impassioned obscenity" offended Christian values and endangered the youth. "We appeal to you to make this figure conform to our Christian standards of civilisation," Long wrote.

In response, Home Office official Cecil Yates proposed planting trees to obscure the giant's genitalia. National Trust authorities and Dorset Police discussed the matter, but ultimately rejected the modification to preserve the historic monument intact.

While elements of the prehistoric figure have changed over centuries due to natural erosion and maintenance, the Cerne Abbas Giant continues to draw visitors as one of Britain's most recognizable cultural landmarks.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Eiffel Tower Top Floor Closed Amid Europe's Scorching Heatwave
fields.summary: Paris' iconic Eiffel Tower shut down its top viewing level until Wednesday due to extreme temperatures exceeding 104°F (40°C), part of a record-breaking heatwave affecting multiple European nations. The closure aims to protect visitors and staff amid dangerous conditions that have also caused school shutdowns in France and wildfires across southern Europe.
fields.content:
Europe's intense heatwave has forced the temporary closure of the Eiffel Tower's summit starting Monday, June 30. The iconic Paris landmark suspended access to its top level through Wednesday to prevent health risks posed by temperatures exceeding 104°F (40°C) at its 900-foot peak. The monument's first and second levels remain accessible, though visitors face sweltering conditions.

A statement on the Eiffel Tower's official website explained: 'Due to the current heat wave, the Eiffel Tower is adapting to ensure the comfort and safety of our visitors and our teams.' Management automatically refunded tickets for the closed top level and installed cooling fountains around the site to help combat the extreme heat.

France recorded nationwide temperatures near 104°F (40°C), prompting about 1,350 school closures. Educational authorities cited unbearable classroom conditions resembling 'convection ovens' as incompatible with learning activities. Public facilities across the country implemented similar heat-response measures.

Continental Impacts

The heat emergency extends across Europe, with Portugal recording 116°F (47°C) June temperatures. Spain broke historical records, while Italy simultaneously faced flash flooding and wildfire alerts. The Mediterranean Sea registered several degrees above average temperatures, threatening marine ecosystems. Thousands evacuated in Turkey and Greece due to wildfires fueled by the unprecedented heat.

Travel experts advise visitors to European landmarks to prioritize hydration, minimize strenuous activities, and consider viewing attractions from shaded distances. Carrying portable fans and cold drinks can provide relief during the peak temperatures, with many recommending rescheduling high-exposure activities to cooler months when possible.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Nicolas Denolle's 'California Dreams': A Poetic Visual Journey
fields.summary: French multidisciplinary artist Nicolas Denolle presents 'California Dreams,' a breathtaking photography series blending observation and imagination to explore the timeless beauty of untouched landscapes.
fields.content:
Exploring 'California Dreams'

Nicolas Denolle, a French multidisciplinary artist and Art Director at Apple, presents 'California Dreams,' a photography series that explores the intersections of design, photography, and visual storytelling. Shot on medium format film across California’s diverse landscapes—from mineral coastlines to high deserts—the project captures an imagined geography of rocks, trees, and native flora. Denolle describes it as 'a visual essay shaped by long explorations,' evoking melancholy for a world that may no longer exist.

California Dreams series by Nicolas Denolle

Born in France and currently based in San Francisco, Denolle studied Graphic Design at ÉCAL (University of Arts & Design) in Switzerland. His work emphasizes simplicity, detail, and form, creating a poetic and atemporal visual language. 'California Dreams' reflects his fascination with the timeless beauty of nature, blending observation with artistic imagination.

Landscape photography from Nicolas Denolle's series

Medium format film photography of California

Denolle’s series inspires nostalgia for a world that may only exist in travelers’ tales. With an emphasis on form and narrative, the project challenges viewers to see familiar landscapes in new, artistic ways.

Composition of natural elements by Nicolas Denolle

For more of his work, visit Nicolas Denolle’s website and follow him on Instagram.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lyn Liu's 'H-Dropping' Exhibition Explores Alienation and Linguistic Paradoxes
fields.summary: Beijing-born artist Lyn Liu's latest exhibition 'H-Dropping' delves into themes of alienation and linguistic contradictions through unsettling yet thought-provoking paintings.
fields.content:
Lyn Liu, a Beijing-born artist now based in New York, presents her latest solo exhibition "H-Dropping" at Kasmin Gallery in Mexico City. The collection features cinematic tableauxs that explore psychological tensions and relationships, often drawing from her personal experiences of alienation and modern social realities.

Detailed painting by Lyn Liu

The exhibition's title references the linguistic phenomenon where certain dialects drop consonant sounds, particularly the letter "H". Liu extends this concept visually, creating works where familiar objects appear in nonfunctional states, generating a sense of unease. She studied at prestigious institutions including New York's School of Visual Arts, Columbia University's School of the Arts, and Paris' l'École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts.

Another painting from the series

Liu's paintings merge the familiar with the absurd, incorporating word play and misinterpretation to create psychological suspense. The works challenge viewers' perceptions by presenting objects that defy their intended purposes, prompting questions about their essential nature.

Artwork depicting contradictory states

Through her distinctive visual language, Liu examines how cultural and linguistic markers shape our sense of belonging. The exhibition continues her exploration of alienation, using painting to examine the tensions within contemporary social structures.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Brage M. Nørholm: Exploring the Psyche Through Art
fields.summary: Discover the striking paintings of Norwegian artist Brage M. Nørholm, whose work blends Expressionism, Realism, and Surrealism to reveal hidden psychological depths.
fields.content:
A selection of paintings by artist Brage M. Nørholm showcases his unique visual style, merging Expressionism, Realism, and Surrealism. Born in Oslo in 1989, Nørholm's art explores human emotions, portraying both the darkness and beauty of existence. His background in psychiatry, working with young people battling drug addiction, deeply informs his artistic perspective.

Artwork by Brage M. Nørholm

Nørholm's paintings act as a mirror to the psyche, uncovering psychological landscapes that often remain unseen. His work balances the absurdity and mystery of life, creating a visual dialogue with the invisible aspects of the human mind. Each piece reflects a deep understanding of mental and emotional struggles, shaped by his professional experience in mental health care.

Detailed portrait by Nørholm

Surreal composition by Nørholm

Artistic exploration of emotion

Brage M. Nørholm continues to explore the complex interplay between mental health and artistic expression through his thought-provoking paintings.

fields.title: Heathrow May Sue National Grid Over Substation Fire That Shut Airport
fields.summary: Heathrow Airport is weighing legal action against National Grid after an investigation revealed a substation fire that caused a shutdown stemmed from ignored maintenance issues.
fields.content:
Heathrow Airport is exploring legal options against National Grid following a report that blamed the power outage and subsequent shutdown on negligence at a substation. Investigators found National Grid had known about moisture damage risks since 2018 but failed to address them.

The fire at North Hyde substation on 20 March forced Heathrow to close, disrupting over 270,000 journeys and costing airlines up to £100m. Essential services like hospitals and transport networks also suffered knock-on effects.

A bird's eye view of how far the substation is away from Heathrow airport. It is to the north west of the airport

Missed Warnings

The National Energy System Operator report stated moisture levels detected in 2018 should have triggered immediate repairs. "Basic maintenance" scheduled for 2022 was postponed, allowing the condition to worsen until combustion occurred.

Heathrow spokesperson stated: "National Grid could and should have prevented this. We expect accountability for failures causing significant damage." The airport also highlighted that energy companies were unaware the substation served critical national infrastructure.

Regulatory Response

Ofgem launched an investigation into National Grid's maintenance practices, with director Akshay Kaul vowing to "hold companies fully accountable." National Grid maintains Britain's network remains highly reliable and says it's cooperating with the probe while strengthening inspection protocols.

The incident has sparked broader concerns about UK infrastructure resilience, particularly regarding communication gaps between utility providers and critical service operators.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Bank of England Seeks Public Input on Redesigning Banknotes
fields.summary: The Bank of England is redesigning its banknotes for the first time in over 50 years and is inviting the public to suggest themes, ranging from nature to historical events, for the new designs.
fields.content:
Banknotes issued by the Bank of England are set for their first major redesign in more than five decades. Historically, these notes have featured notable figures like Winston Churchill, but this tradition may change as the central bank explores fresh themes.

The public is being consulted on potential new designs, which could include themes such as nature, innovation, or key historical moments. This opens the door to British wildlife, landmarks, or even cultural icons appearing on future £5, £10, £20, and £50 notes.

'National Identity'

Since 1960, British banknotes have featured the monarch, with historical figures like William Shakespeare appearing on the reverse since 1970. Past choices have sparked controversy, such as the lack of women on notes aside from Queen Elizabeth II in 2013.

The Bank is now considering new thematic directions, though historical figures remain an option. Suggested themes include natural landscapes, scientific achievements, or cultural milestones. Public submissions are encouraged, with some humorous suggestions anticipated.

"Banknotes symbolize our national identity and offer a chance to celebrate the UK," said Victoria Cleland, the Bank's chief cashier. "I'm eager to hear the public's preferred themes."

Selection of UK banknotes with historical figures.

Cleland emphasized that banknotes are "little pieces of art in our pockets," though designs must balance aesthetics with accessibility and security. She remains open to suggestions but stresses themes should be enduring and unifying.

Other UK regions and the eurozone already feature landmarks and animals on their notes. International examples, like Bermuda's vibrant $5 note featuring marine life, highlight creative possibilities.

Bermuda's colorful $5 note with marine life.

Currently, UK notes span historical figures from Churchill to Alan Turing. The public consultation, open until July, seeks input via online forms or mail. The final decision rests with the Bank's governor.

Despite declining cash usage (now 12% of transactions), the Bank remains committed to circulating over 4.7 billion notes worth £86 billion for those who rely on physical currency.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Princess Catherine shares emotional insights on cancer recovery journey
fields.summary: The Princess of Wales opened up about the long-term challenges of post-chemotherapy recovery during a hospital visit, describing how cancer treatment changes lives and the importance of finding a 'new normal'.
fields.content:
The Princess of Wales made an emotional return to public engagements by visiting a hospital in Essex, where she shared personal reflections about her ongoing cancer recovery journey. Speaking with patients, Catherine discussed the often overlooked difficulties that come after active treatment ends.

"You put on a brave face during treatment, but the phase afterwards is really difficult," she said. The princess explained how patients suddenly transition from clinical care to managing daily life with changed capabilities, noting that this adjustment period can be particularly challenging.

Princess Catherine planting roses in Colchester, Essex

Catherine emphasized the ripple effects of cancer treatment, saying the experience is life-changing not just for patients but for their families too. "You have to find your new normal, and that takes time," she added, describing the recovery process as a "rollercoaster" rather than a smooth transition.

During her visit to Colchester Hospital's well-being garden, where she helped plant special "Catherine roses", the princess highlighted nature's healing power. The garden serves as a therapeutic space for patients recovering from illness, reflecting Catherine's personal view of nature as her "sanctuary" during her own health challenges.

This marked the princess's first major public appearance since missing Royal Ascot earlier this year as she continues to carefully balance her return to duties following cancer treatment that began last year. While she announced being in remission in January, her recent comments underscore the prolonged nature of true recovery.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Iran's IRGC at Crossroads: What Lies Ahead After Military Setbacks?
fields.summary: Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps faces an uncertain future following significant military defeats, with experts analyzing whether its ideological stronghold can survive amidst growing domestic discontent and strategic losses.
fields.content:
The Revolutionary Struggle

Originally formed as a revolutionary militia, the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) has long maintained power through ideological influence and fear. However, recent military defeats have left its future hanging in the balance. Analysts suggest the organization stands at a turning point, questioning whether its decades-long reign of repression and terror can continue.

Portrait of Iran-aligned leaders seen in Tehran

"The IRGC's mission has always been to preserve and defend the 1979 Islamic Revolution," said expert Taleblu. "However, their tactics of terrorism and hostage-taking have not diminished, even as their strategic successes falter."

Shifting Public Sentiment

Despite its entrenched power, the IRGC faces growing disillusionment among Iranians. "They constructed the U.S. and Israel as enemies to unify support," noted analyst Ostovar. "But today, most Iranians reject this narrative, preferring better relations with the West over continued isolation."

The IRGC remains deeply embedded within Iran's political and economic structures. Taleblu described them as partners in power with the clerical elite, leveraging Iran as a base to push revolutionary ideals abroad. However, some experts believe that past defeats may force the organization to shift focus inward.

Iranian revolutionary guard members marching

"Rebuilding would take too much time and effort," Taleblu explained. "Instead, we might see increased domestic repression while leaning on allies like China and Russia to restore military capabilities."

Possible Future Scenarios

Though unlikely to turn against the regime, the IRGC's path remains uncertain. Ostovar predicts Iran could adopt North Korea's isolationist model, doubling down on autocracy. "Repression at home is easier than sustaining terror abroad," he said, pointing to ongoing struggles in Gaza and Lebanon.

Others within the regime advocate for normalizing relations, with some reformists looking to Vietnam or China for inspiration. Yet, Taleblu warns that the IRGC's influence remains strong, making any significant shift improbable without internal upheaval.

In this photo released by the Iranian Red Crescent Society rescuers work at the scene of an explosion after an Israeli strike in Tehran, Iran, Friday, June 13, 2025.

Ultimately, the IRGC's survival depends on navigating tensions between ideological rigidity and geopolitical realities, with experts suggesting that while setbacks have weakened them, their control over Iran's power structures ensures resilience.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Breast Cancer Survivors May Have Lower Alzheimer's Risk, Study Suggests
fields.summary: A new study reveals breast cancer survivors may face a reduced risk of developing Alzheimer's, with radiation therapy showing significant protective effects — though experts caution about study limitations.
fields.content:
While cancer isn't typically associated with health benefits, new research suggests breast cancer survivors might experience unexpected protection against dementia. A study published in JAMA Network Open analyzed data from over 70,000 breast cancer survivors compared to a cancer-free control group over an average period of 7.3 years.

Cancer patient at doctor

The findings revealed radiation therapy patients showed particular benefits — experiencing a 23% reduction in Alzheimer's risk. This contradicts previous concerns about cognitive decline in cancer survivors, including the phenomenon known as "chemo brain."

Researchers noted that while "chemo brain" can cause subtle thinking and memory problems, it differs fundamentally from Alzheimer's disease. Some cancer drugs may actually help reduce the buildup of Alzheimer's-related proteins in the brain.

Study limitations

The research team acknowledged several limitations, including unavailable data about cancer stages and radiation doses. Follow-up periods were relatively short (maximum 11 years), potentially underestimating Alzheimer's diagnoses.

Lupus awareness

Experts caution against definitive conclusions. Maria Carrillo, a researcher not involved in this study, noted observational studies have shown both increased and decreased Alzheimer's risk among cancer survivors. The radiation therapy findings, she suggested, might relate to its anti-inflammatory effects.

Radiation therapy

With approximately 7.2 million Americans over 65 currently living with Alzheimer's, these findings could have significant implications, though further research is needed. The study adds to growing evidence about potential connections between cancer treatments and cognitive health.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Dangerous Erosion of Trust in Science and Public Health
fields.summary: A public health expert warns about the growing distrust in science and vaccines, drawing parallels to the COVID-19 crisis and highlighting how misinformation undermines healthcare systems.
fields.content:
The COVID-19 pandemic exposed deep vulnerabilities in global health systems, with distrust in science and institutions becoming a recurring challenge. When trust erodes, the consequences can be dire – from vaccine hesitancy to the breakdown of public health infrastructure.

A syringe administering a vaccine

History Repeating: The Threat of Science Distrust

During the early days of the pandemic, makeshift hospitals in New York City became symbols of a healthcare system stretched beyond capacity. The lack of trust in scientific guidance, testing, and protective measures worsened an already critical situation. Now, similar patterns emerge as misinformation resurfaces around vaccine safety, including debates over thimerosal, a mercury-based preservative long proven safe.

Politicization of Health and Its Consequences

The removal of experienced public health experts from key advisory roles in favor of ideologically driven figures illustrates a dangerous shift. Vaccination is not just medical care—it’s a social contract. Undermining it disproportionately affects marginalized communities, including people of color and low-income families, who already face systemic barriers to healthcare.

The rejection of science today goes beyond COVID-19 vaccines—next could be HPV, MMR, or routine childhood immunizations. The ripple effects extend to pharmaceutical innovation, as scientific uncertainty discourages investment in vaccine research.

Rebuilding Trust Through Equity and Engagement

Meaningful solutions require recognizing why distrust exists. Marginalized communities have long faced medical racism and systemic neglect, making vaccine hesitancy understandable. Effective strategies involve:
1. Mobile vaccination units to reach underserved areas
2. Collaboration with trusted community leaders
3. Transparent, inclusive communication

The fight against misinformation demands urgency—disinformation costs lives. History shows that once trust is lost, it takes years, if not generations, to restore. This is not just a public health crisis but a societal one.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Carson Monahan's Surreal Art Blends Reality and the Spiritual
fields.summary: Detroit-based artist Carson Monahan crafts thought-provoking paintings that merge ordinary moments with surreal, spiritual undertones, drawing from mythology, dreams, and folklore.
fields.content:
Detroit artist Carson Monahan transforms everyday scenes into extraordinary visions, blending reality with an otherworldly presence. His works defy simple interpretation, merging natural elements with mystical symbolism—often featuring animals—to explore the tension between human intuition and the unknown.

Monahan's surreal painting with symbolic imagery

Monahan draws inspiration from fantasy, folklore, Renaissance art, and mythology, infusing his pieces with themes of mortality, renewal, and impermanence. His dreamlike compositions evoke emotions of anxiety, alienation, and longing, prompting deeper contemplation of existence.

Detailed artwork exploring time and intuition

The artist’s ability to heighten reality while questioning perception has gained recognition in contemporary art circles. His recent exhibition at Monya Rowe Gallery in New York showcases this unique vision.

Symbolic painting with animal figures

Viewers of Monahan’s work often describe an emotional resonance—his paintings seem to capture fleeting moments suspended between the conscious and subconscious.

Mystical composition with surreal elements

For those interested in exploring more of Monahan’s art, his website and Instagram provide further glimpses into his evolving body of work.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Court Orders New Inquiry into MI5's False Evidence Scandal
fields.summary: The UK High Court has demanded a fresh investigation into MI5's provision of false evidence to multiple courts, labeling previous inquiries as 'seriously deficient' in a case involving a neo-Nazi state agent.
fields.content:
The High Court has ordered a thorough and independent investigation into MI5's submission of false evidence in court proceedings, rejecting earlier reviews as "seriously deficient." The case emerged after revelations that the security service lied in hearings related to a neo-Nazi agent accused of abusing women.

A panel of three senior judges—Lady Chief Justice Baroness Sue Carr, Dame Victoria Sharp, and Mr Justice Chamberlain—called for a new review overseen by Investigatory Powers Commissioner Sir Brian Leveson. They emphasized that contempt of court proceedings would only be considered after this investigation concludes.

Sir Ken McCallum, MI5 Director General, speaking at an event

The case traces back to 2022 when MI5 attempted to block a BBC report exposing a state-backed neo-Nazi agent, referred to as "X." The BBC later proved that an MI5 officer confirmed X's status as an agent—contradicting the service's policy of "neither confirming nor denying" such details.

Two previous inquiries—one internal and another led by former government chief lawyer Sir Jonathan Jones KC—were dismissed by the court for procedural failings. The judges criticized Sir Jonathan’s review for not investigating key individuals or assessing critical BBC evidence.

Silhouette of 'Beth,' a victim of the neo-Nazi agent

MI5 Director General Sir Ken McCallum reiterated an apology for the errors, emphasizing cooperation with the new investigation. "MI5's job is to keep the country safe. Maintaining the trust of the courts is essential to that mission," he stated.

The court also noted that internal investigators and Sir Jonathan reviewed additional BBC evidence "in good faith" but failed to adjust their conclusions adequately. The judges stressed that the truth had to be "extracted" from MI5 rather than volunteered.

Blurred image of neo-Nazi agent 'X' holding a machete

The ruling underscored "major" oversights in prior inquiries, including investigators’ failure to interview involved parties. The judges concluded that MI5's explanations to the court were "piecemeal and unsatisfactory," omitting crucial facts.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Dalai Lama Announces Successor Plans Amid China Tensions
fields.summary: The Dalai Lama has confirmed the continuation of his spiritual lineage, stating his successor will be chosen by his trust—a move that clashes with China's claims over the process.
fields.content:
The Dalai Lama has put an end to speculation about the future of his spiritual leadership by confirming that his institution will continue after his death. In a video message broadcast from Dharamshala, India, he clarified that the Gaden Phodrang Trust holds the authority to appoint his successor, rejecting any external interference.

Tibetan monks pray at the Dalai Lama Library

Tibetan tradition holds that Dalai Lamas are reincarnated, but China, which annexed Tibet in 1950, insists any future leader must be approved by Beijing. The Dalai Lama, however, reiterated that his successor must be identified outside China, a statement that drew immediate opposition from Chinese officials.

Hundreds of followers gathered in Dharamshala to hear the announcement, part of the celebrations for the Dalai Lama's 90th birthday. Hollywood actor and long-time supporter Richard Gere was among the attendees.

Dalai Lama speaks with Richard Gere at birthday celebrations

The Dalai Lama had previously suggested that his successor might be a girl or that the institution might end with him. But with overwhelming support from the Tibetan exile community, he has now affirmed the continuation of his lineage under the guidance of his office.

China's foreign ministry dismissed the announcement, stating that any reincarnation must follow Chinese laws and religious rituals. Analysts predict that China may attempt to appoint its own Dalai Lama, but Tibetan leaders in exile insist such a move would lack legitimacy.

Buddhist devotee waits for Dalai Lama at temple

Robert Barnett, a Tibet scholar, noted that the Dalai Lama's statement serves as a signal to China that his legitimacy stems from popular consent, not government approval. Meanwhile, Tibetan MP Youdon Aukatsang expressed confidence that a Beijing-appointed successor would be rejected by Tibetans and the global Buddhist community.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Five Key Findings from Heathrow Airport Fire Report
fields.summary: A report reveals critical findings about the fire that disrupted Heathrow Airport, uncovering maintenance lapses, systemic failures, and potential legal consequences for National Grid.
fields.content:
A recent report into the fire at an electricity substation near Heathrow Airport has outlined crucial details about the incident, which forced the shutdown of one of the world's busiest travel hubs for nearly 24 hours, affecting over 200,000 passengers.

1. Cause of the Fire

The investigation found that moisture infiltration into a high-voltage transformer was the primary cause. The device, known as a supergrid transformer, regulates voltage for Heathrow and surrounding areas. Moisture led to a short circuit, triggering sparks and a catastrophic failure that ignited the cooling oil inside.

2. Missed Maintenance Warnings

National Grid had detected early signs of moisture in 2018, labeling it an 'imminent fault' requiring immediate action. Despite this, no repairs were made. Maintenance was further deferred in 2022, and multiple rescheduling attempts failed, leaving the transformer vulnerable to failure.

3. Heathrow's Electrical Weakness

Heathrow relies on three grid connections but knew that losing one would force a shutdown lasting 10–12 hours while backup systems activated. Although costly upgrades were considered, the risk was dismissed as unlikely. The report highlighted opportunities to improve power resilience.

Firefighters working at the substation after the incident

4. Communication Failures

Energy providers National Grid and SSEN were unaware that a power loss at the substation would mandate a full airport closure. The report emphasized the need for clearer communication between critical infrastructure operators and their energy suppliers.

5. Legal Fallout

Heathrow faced public backlash after the incident, particularly over its CEO being asleep during the shutdown decision. The airport now contemplates legal action against National Grid, citing 'clear and repeated failings.' National Grid has pledged full cooperation with regulatory investigations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Chancellor Rachel Reeves Receives Backing After Emotional Commons Appearance
fields.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves was visibly emotional during a Commons debate, prompting questions about her future, but the government swiftly confirmed her position was secure.
fields.content:
Downing Street has reaffirmed its support for Chancellor Rachel Reeves following an emotional appearance in the Commons during Prime Minister's Questions. The session saw tensions rise over welfare reform changes, with Tory leader Kemi Badenoch accusing Labour of fiscal mismanagement.

Reeves, visibly upset, reportedly wiped away tears during the heated debate. Badenoch pressed Prime Minister Keir Starmer on whether Reeves would retain her role, stating Labour MPs were already privately questioning her position.

Reeves and Starmer in Commons debate

Starmer avoided directly confirming Reeves' future during the session, but his spokesperson later clarified she had his "full backing," stating firmly: "The chancellor is going nowhere." The exchange followed Labour's abrupt reversal on welfare reforms, which reportedly undermined Reeves' budgetary plans.

Speculation also swirled around whether Work and Pensions Secretary Liz Kendall retained Starmer's confidence after her absence from PMQs. The press secretary confirmed Kendall's position remained secure.

Allies of Reeves suggested her emotional state stemmed from a tense pre-debate encounter with Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle. While neither side commented officially, sources indicated the dispute may have related to Reeves being asked to shorten her responses during prior Treasury questions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ancient DNA Reveals Connections Between Egypt and Mesopotamia
fields.summary: DNA analysis of a 4,500-year-old skeleton reveals the first biological evidence of links between Ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia, reshaping our understanding of early civilizations.
fields.content:
A groundbreaking DNA analysis of a man who lived 4,500 years ago in the Nile Valley provides the first biological evidence connecting Ancient Egypt with Mesopotamia. The skeleton, discovered in Nuwayrat village south of Cairo, shows that 20% of his ancestry originated from Mesopotamia, located 1,500km away in modern-day Iraq.

Liverpool John Moores University/Nature Nearly full skeleton missing his right lower arm as well as fingers and toes on each hand and foot appearing against a black background

Researchers believe this finding helps explain how Egypt evolved from scattered farming communities into one of history's greatest civilizations. The discovery supports theories that concepts like writing and agriculture spread through direct contact between these ancient societies.

Professor Pontus Skoglund from the Francis Crick Institute explains that ancient DNA offers historians a powerful new tool: "If we get more DNA information and put it side by side with what we know from archaeological and written records, it will be very exciting." This approach provides insights beyond traditional historical accounts which focused mainly on the elite.

Garstang Museum/Liverpool University/Nature A black and white picture showing a collection of bones including the person's skull in a circular vessel

The skeleton was buried before mummification became common practice, which helped preserve his DNA. Chemical analysis of his teeth suggests he grew up in Egypt. Anthropologist Joel Irish studied the bones to reconstruct details about the man's life - he stood about 5'2", likely worked as a potter, and showed signs of arthritis from years of labor.

Adeline Morez Jacobs, who analyzed the remains, stated: "This is the first clear-cut evidence of significant migration between these centers of civilization." The research, published in Nature journal, offers compelling evidence that technological revolutions spread through human contact across ancient empires.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art At the top are eight crudely drawn bowls below which is a seated potter on the right using his left hand to turn a potters wheel on which sits a vessel they are creating. On the left is another figure bending over about to lift a bowl

Remarkably, these bones survived multiple hazards - they were excavated in 1902, donated to World Museum Liverpool, and endured bombings during WWII that destroyed most of the museum's human remains collection. Researchers consider it fortunate that these particular bones were preserved, allowing us to uncover this significant piece of ancient history.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Tesla Deliveries Drop 14% Amid Rising Competition and Political Tensions
fields.summary: Tesla's vehicle deliveries fell by 14% in Q2 as challenges from competitors and political disputes continue to affect the automaker's performance.
fields.content:
Tesla has reported a 14% drop in vehicle deliveries for the second quarter of the year, marking its second consecutive quarterly decline. The company delivered just over 384,000 vehicles between April and June, reflecting ongoing struggles amid increasing competition and political controversies.

Competitors, particularly China's BYD, are intensifying pressure on Tesla. Meanwhile, Elon Musk’s public conflicts with former U.S. President Donald Trump have added to the company's challenges. Trump had previously threatened to reduce subsidies for Musk’s businesses, escalating tensions further.

A green promotional banner with black squares and rectangles forming pixels, moving in from the right. The text says: ‘Tech Decoded: The world’s biggest tech news in your inbox every Monday.’

Despite the declining numbers, analysts like Gene Munster of Deepwater Asset Management suggest this might be the lowest point for Tesla, with potential recovery ahead. Munster noted that uncertainty over U.S. EV tax credits could drive short-term sales before potential policy changes. Tesla’s recent push into robotaxi development, though uncertain, could also play a pivotal role in its future performance.

Investors remain cautiously optimistic, focusing on Tesla’s advancements in autonomous driving technology as a key factor for long-term success.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Bob Vylan dropped from music festivals after Glastonbury controversy
fields.summary: Punk duo Bob Vylan has been removed from two international music festivals following controversial political chants at Glastonbury that sparked widespread criticism.
fields.content:
British punk band Bob Vylan has been dropped from upcoming performances at Manchester's Radar Festival and France's Kave Fest after their contentious appearance at Glastonbury Festival drew political backlash.

The group's scheduled headline show at Manchester's Victoria Warehouse this Saturday was canceled by organizers. A German concert with Gogol Bordello in September has also been called off.

Political backlash at Glastonbury

The controversy stemmed from lead singer Bobby Vylan chanting "death to the IDF" (Israel Defense Forces) during their Glastonbury performance. UK Prime Minister condemned the remarks as "appalling hate speech," while Chief Rabbi Sir Ephraim Mirvis criticized the BBC for broadcasting the live set.

Bob Vylan performing live on stage

Band's response

In an Instagram statement, the duo clarified they aren't advocating violence against any group: "We are for the dismantling of a violent military machine." They characterized the controversy as distracting from what they view as the core issue of Palestinian suffering.

The BBC acknowledged in a statement they should have interrupted the live broadcast, calling the antisemitic sentiments "utterly unacceptable." Media regulator Ofcom says it is investigating the incident, stating "the BBC clearly has questions to answer."

Bob Vylan maintains they'll return to Manchester in the future, telling fans: "Silence is not an option. We will be fine, the people of Palestine are hurting."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Hamas claims readiness for ceasefire but demands Israeli withdrawal from Gaza
fields.summary: Hamas states willingness to negotiate a ceasefire but insists on Israel's complete withdrawal from Gaza as mediators prepare for talks in Cairo following Trump's 60-day proposal.
fields.content:
Hamas official Taher al-Nunu declared the group's readiness to "accept any initiative that clearly leads to the complete end to the war" while maintaining their long-standing demands. The statement comes as Egyptian and Qatari mediators prepare to meet with Hamas representatives in Cairo to discuss former President Trump's ceasefire proposal.

Donald Trump at the White House

Trump announced on Truth Social that Israel had agreed to conditions for a 60-day ceasefire, urging Hamas to accept the deal as mediators deliver the final proposal. "I hope, for the good of the Middle East, that Hamas takes this Deal, because it will not get better - IT WILL ONLY GET WORSE," Trump wrote.

Hamas has indicated willingness to release approximately 50 remaining hostages, though acknowledging fewer than half may still be alive. Their conditions include Israel's complete withdrawal from Gaza and an end to hostilities. Meanwhile, Israel demands Hamas's surrender, disarmament, and exile from the territory.

Israel-Palestinians

Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Sa'ar reaffirmed Israel's commitment to securing a hostage deal and ceasefire, stating "Israel is serious in its will to reach a hostage deal and ceasefire in Gaza." The proposed agreement would involve the release of about 10 hostages initially.

Source: Original Article
